. I was in the employ of Mr. Fisher, a linen draper . On the 27th of June, at a quarter past one o'clock, the two prisoners came in together; the man desired to look at some blue silk handkerchiefs; the woman took a seat, and the man stood beside her; I took a piece of handkerchief out of the window, he examined it, and desired to look at some others - he opened one piece, and covered the others that were on the counter; he paid me 4s. 6d. for one, and I saw the woman slip her hand under the piece I had opened - the man then said he did not wish to have that one, but another; I said I would exchange it - he said, No, and they went out; I missed the handkerchiefs, and pursued them - I took hold of the female, and brought her back - she made some resistance. and said she was not going to run away; I took hold of her two hands in the shop, and at that moment saw the piece fall from her.

JOHN VANN
. I am a patrol, and was sent for to Mr. Fisher's, and found the female prisoner there; she cried, and said she knew nothing about it; I was going with her across Finsbury-square, the man came up, and said,"What is the matter?" she said she was going to the office for nothing; he said, "What are you about?" I said, I was an officer, and if he made any attempt to oppose me, I would take him also; he wanted to fight me, and I took him to the office - just as we got there, he put put his head on one side, and said he would give me 2l. to make it right; I found the handkerchief he had bought, in the woman's basket - he said that was his property.

Prisoner MARY TAYLOR. I went to buy a handkerchief - the man followed me, and said I must go back; I went back, and the young man in the shop was told to throw the handkerchiefs on one side; this piece of handkerchiefs laid on the floor, and he said, "There it is."

JOHN ALDRED COOPER. I desired the young man to move the other handkerchiefs, that this piece might not mix with them - she dropped this; I did not see it fall, but I am certain it was not on the floor when I went out, because I passed the same ground in going out and coming in; she could not have brushed it from the counter, for they were removed before she got back.
COURT. Q. Then she had left the shop? A. Yes - and I missed the piece, pursued, and brought her back - after some time she dropped it.
NOT GUILTY .

1543.
ROBERT WILLIAM WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of August , 1 sheet, value 12s.; 1 gown, value 5s.; 2 petticoats, value 5s.; 8 pairs of stockings, value 3s. 6d.; 1lb. weight of quicksilver, value 3s., and 2 pairs of shoes, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Austin
.

HANNAH AUSTIN
. I am the wife of Thomas Austin, of Radcliff-terrace, Goswell-street-road
, we keep a silversmith's shop . On the 22d of August I left the things out to dry all night; on the 23d of August the watchman called in the morning, and found the articles; this quicksilver is my husband's.

WILLIAM BARKER
. I am the watchman, and saw theprisoner coming out of President-street, about five o'clock in the morning - he crossed the road, I stopped him, and asked what he had got there; he said, linen, which he brought from the City-road, and was going to take to Old-street - it being damp, I left him at the watch-house, and went to the house to which he said he was going, and between 8 and 9 o'clock in the morning I found the owner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked them up in the square, within the rails.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1544.
WILLIAM WELLS
,
GEORGE ALLEN
, and
THOMAS TAYLOR
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 sheet, value 3s. , the goods of
William Collyer
.

ELIZABETH COLLYER
. I am the wife of William Collyer - we live in Prospect-place, Ball's-pond
. This sheet was missed about half-past eleven o'clock on the morning of the 8th of September; my grand-daughter told me she heard the cry of Stop thief! and ran out to see what was the matter; she had picked up the sheet and given it to me.

JOSEPH HACKETT
. On the 8th of September I was watching these lads, and saw Wells and Allen draw this sheet through the window of an empty house, next door to Collyer's; I had lost sight of Taylor then - Wells wrapped it up, and put put it under his arm - they made off- when they saw me they began to run, and I pursued them.

WILLIAM HACKETT
. I heard an alarm, and went out; I have the care of these houses - I went into one house, and saw Taylor there - he said he came to ease himself; he was not in the room where the sheet came out of.(Property produced and sworn to.)
WELLS' Defence. I was going to wash in the New River, and turning down there I heard the cry of Stop thief! and was taken.

WELLS -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

ALLEN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

TAYLOR -
NOT GUILTY .

1545.
WILLIAM WOLFE
,
WILLIAM KEEFE
, and
JOHN POOLE
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 crown, 1 shilling, 1 sixpence, and 11 1/2d. in copper monies , the monies of
Thomas Langley
.

JEREMIAH STEDMAN
. I was in the service of Thomas Langley, in Mile-end-road
. On the 31st of August I was at work in the shop, with my back to the door, for five or ten minutes - when I turned round I saw Keefe behind the counter, shutting the till; he stooped, came round, and walked out at the door; Poole was at the door, looking through the window; they crossed the road, and met Wolfe, and they all joined together; I went and looked at the till. and the money was all gone except a penny or three halfpence; I ran out, and secured Keefe and Poole- Wolfe attempted to run off, but two Excisemen came up, and I asked them to stop him; I brought them back, and Keefe dropped the silver on the stones; he had the money when I took him. I took off Wolfe's hat, and found this wire in it, and some string.
KEEFE'S Defence. I went into a house to buy some bread and cheese, and this man came and took me.

WOLFE -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Seven Years .

KEEFE -
GUILTY . Aged 11.
Whipped and Discharged .

POOLE -
GUILTY . Aged 11.
Judgment Respited .

1546.
JOHN WEBB
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 tea-kettle, value 3s. , the goods of
George Tucker
.

GEORGE TUCKER. I keep the White Bear, public-house, St. John-street
. I went to the bar to have my supper, between nine and ten o'clock at night, and when I returned the prisoner was gone, and the tea-kettle; the watchman brought it back in about ten minutes.

HENRY MORGAN
. I am the watchman. I saw the prisoner and another run down St. John-street; I took him with this kettle under his arm, about one hundred and fifty yards from the prosecutor's house.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I went in to have a pint of beer with the other young man - he came out, and then asked me to carry the kettle, and meet him at the Horse and Groom public-house, Hosier-lane.
GUILTY Aged 25.
Confined Three Months .

1547.
WILLIAM WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 pocket-book, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 1 1/2d. in copper , the monies of
Charles Logan
.

CHARLES LOGAN. I am a baker , and live in the Harrow-road
. On the 5th of July, my wife being ill in bed, I went up with some breakfast to her, and when I came down I found the prisoner with the pocket-book in his hand, shuffling down the lid of my desk; I took hold of him, and took him to my till, where I had left 1 1/2d. - they were then gone; the handkerchief had been in my hat in the parlour; I took him to the constable, and the 1 1/2d. were found in his pocket.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1548.
JOSEPH WIDDOWSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 hat, value 5s. , the goods of
Daniel Sprange
.

DANIEL SPRANGE. I live at Islington
. I left this hat in my parlour on the 4th of July, about ten o'clock - I missed it that morning.

JOHN CHARLESWORTH
. I am a green-grocer, and live at Islington. On the 5th of July I saw the prisoner stoop into Mr. Sprange's window, and take this hat out; I went over to him, and he dropped it - I collared him, and took it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. On that morning I went to bathe, I picked up the hat - I knew it did not belong to me, and put it down; the witness came and took me.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1549.
WILLIAM WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 6 pieces of printed cotton, containing 77 yards, value 40s. , the goods of
Henry Hammer
.

ROBERT FISHER
. I am apprentice to Henry Hammer, who lives in Ratcliff-highway
, and is a linen-draper . On the 14th of August, about half-past seven o'clock, I was putting some things outside the door; the prisoner and two others came by - one of them put his hand to a pile of prints, and suddenly withdrew it; they went on about seven doors, and kept coming backwards and forwards; I went and stood behind a pile of goods; they came again, and one man took some prints; I went out, and the first man had part of them on his shoulder; some were on the pavement, and the prisoner was picking them up; the first man dropped the prints; the third man ran off - I secured the prisoner, who was stooping.

Prisoner. The other two men were tipsy, and I pushed the other against the cottons; some of them fell - I stooped to pick them up, and was there near a quarter of an hour, picking them up. Witness. He was not there a minute.

JOHN SHIELDS
. I took the prisoner into custody - he said he was merely picking them up, to give to the young man.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .

1550.
THOMAS WORCESTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 20 yards of printed cotton, value 14s. , the goods of
John Scott
.

JOHN SCOTT. I am a linen-draper , and live in High-street, Shadwell
. I received information on the 26th of June, between six and eight o'clock in the evening; I sent my young man out, and he brought back the prisoner, with this print in his apron.

WILLIAM PITT
. I followed the prisoner, and found a piece of print on him, which had hung on a rail outside the shop. I told him he had taken a piece of print - he said he had not; I asked what was in his apron - he said Nothing - I found the print in it.

EDWARD STEARN
. On the 26th of June, between seven and eight o'clock, I saw three men skulking about my window, at No. 226, High-street; I went out and saw the prisoner go to Mr. Scott's, and take the print; I could not leave my door, but I went to my next neighbours, and told them of it; the prisoner was brought back in about five minutes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I saw this piece of print on the pavement beyond Mr. Scott's door.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1551.
THOMAS WILMORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of June , 1 coat, value 2l., and 1 pair of trousers, value 1l. , the goods of
John Gwynn
.

JOHN GWYNN. I live in Vernon-place, Old-street. On the 21st of June I had been knocked down, and was much injured - the prisoner came to my house, on the 22d, and said he heard I had had an accident; he said "I have a leech at home, and if you will come I will give it you;" I said "What can I do with my clothes;" he said "Take them with you," and he put them into his handkerchief; he employed his son to put on the leech, while he dried my clothes and brush-them, and, while my head was down, he took my clothes out and pawned them - I did not miss them for two or three days.

Prisoner. Q. What was the cause of my coming to your house on that morning. A. I do not know; on the day before I took a watch away, belonging to Mr. Edwards, which you told me to pawn, I did not know but what it was yours, but it proved to be another person's.

Prisoner. On the 20th of June, at eleven o'clock, this man was sitting in company with me, at my door, taking some porter - two young men came by, and one asked me to let him drink - he would leave his watch with me, and I said he should have it when he called for it - the prosecutor called for it the next morning, with a young man, named Berridge, and said "Let me look at that watch," which I said they might - he then ran away with it.

Witness. No - it was not the next morning - but he gave it me to pawn; I was going to Bow, and in going along I said "This cannot be the watch the young man left," but I took it to pawn - I saw Berridge that day.
COURT. Q. Did he complain of your taking the watch? A. No; I did not desire him to pawn my things.

Cross-examined by MR. CRESWELL. Q. Have not you got the duplicate of these clothes? A. No, I gave it to the officer - they were pawned in the name of Wilmore - I never saw anything of the money - he did not give me the duplicate - I found it in his house - it was given me by his landlord, who said "If you will keep a secret I will give you the ticket."

JOHN BOARDS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a coat and trousers, pawned at my house on the 22d of June, by the prisoner; I knew him very well - he said he pawned them for a person of the name of Gwinn.

JOHN COOPER
. I heard the prosecutor tell the prisoner to pawn these things for 2l.
NOT GUILTY .

1552.
CHARLES WORMLAYTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 48 cakes, value 2s. , the goods of
James Scruby
.

JAMES SCRUBY. I am a baker , and live at No. 3, William-street, Curtain-road. On the 19th of July I was in the Shepherdess-fields
with a tin of cakes, and a green cloth; I suppose there were two hundred young people about there - a young man was there with pies, and one of the persons came and asked for a penny pie; they seized hold of him, and threatened to throw him into the canal; I made the best of my way home, they ran after me, and asked me for change for a 6d. - I said "I could not give it," then the prisoner came up, and they all took my cakes together - after the prisoner had got some, he asked another, who had a pocket full, to give him one.

Cross-examined by Mr. CRESWELL. Q. What time was this? A. About half-past nine o'clock; I was afraid to take him that night; it was just twilight; I had seen him once before; I went up again on the Thursday evening with a friend or two - the prisoner came up, and the first thing I saw him do was to take a pair of boots - the officercame to ask me if I had been robbed - the prisoner was taken on the Friday evening; I have seen the prisoner's father; I did not say to him, that if he would pay me 15s., I would make such a representation, that the Grand Jury should throw the bill out; I did not intend anything dishonest, but they were always at my house; they were willing to give me money, but I would not accept of it till the trial was over.
NOT GUILTY .

1553.
THOMAS JAMES BACON
and
THOMAS GARRAWAY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
James Mason
, from his person .

JAMES MASON. I am a baker . On the 3d of July I was in Shoreditch
, between twelve and one o'clock - the brass founders were walking; I did not see who took my handkerchief, but I saw it in Bacon's hand, who was not five yards from me - a man behind me ran and collared him, and he threw it on the ground; I had not felt any pull at my pocket; it was quite safe when I was by Bishopsgate-church.

JOHN GIRTON
. I was going down Shoreditch, and saw Bacon take a handkerchief out of Mason's pocket; I saw him put it into his left-hand breeches' pocket; I then saw him throw it down - another man took it up - I took hold of him, and Garraway endeavoured to throw me down to get Bacon away - I had before seen them close together- Bacon could not have taken it without Garraway seeing it; Bacon got away, and I saw no more of him till one of the officers had them in custody at Guildhall.

ROBERT TYRRELL
. I saw the two prisoners together; Garraway was struggling with Girton, and they got away; Girton told me of the handkerchief being stolen; I said I knew them, and should see them again; I did not see them till the 11th, which was a week afterwards - they were then in Old-street; I followed them, and saw them commit a felony in Aldersgate-street; I knew Bacon, but Garraway had altered his dress, and got his hair cut short.
BACON'S Defence. I was at Reading, in Berkshire, on that day.
GARRAWAY'S Defence. I was at Clapham with my uncle.

BACON -
GUILTY . Aged 23.

GARRAWAY -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1554.
JOHN BURNS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the good of
Rowland Ingram
, from his person .

DANIEL REARDON
. I am a patrol of St. Giles'. On the evening of the 20th of July I was in St. Martin's-lane
- I saw the prisoner, and another lad, at a distance from him - there were two gentlemen before them, and I saw the prisoner take this handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, who gave his name as Rowland Ingram, but begged not to be bound over to prosecute, as he was going into the country - as soon as the prisoner had taken it, I ran over and took him with it in his hand.

WILLIAM McGREGOR
. I was with Reardon in St. Martin's-lane, and saw the prisoner take the handkerchief.
Prisoner. Then why did he not take me - I crossed over directly.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Whipped and Discharged .

1555.
JAMES CLARKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 1 coral necklace, value 15s., the goods of
Peter Bouchard
, from the person of
Elizabeth Bouchard
, spinster
.

LOUISA BOUCHARD. I am fourteen years of age, and live with my father, in Wellington-row. On the evening of the 26th of June I had a loaf in my hand, and was going round the corner of Wellington-row
- the prisoner snatched my necklace off my neck - two other boys came up, and held me while he ran away - I think he must have given it to the other boys, as he put his hands behind him while he ran - when they let me go, I took hold of him - he stopped and said, "I won't run, for I have got nothing;" the officer then took him.

WILLIAM HALL
. I was in my front room, at the corner of Wellington-street. I heard the cry of Stop thief! - I ran out, and saw the girl and prisoner together - I heard him say, "I have not got it - you may search me;" I took him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going to bathe with a boy, who went up to this girl - he came away, and said run - I unthinkingly did run; she called Stop thief! and I stopped.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 14.

Recommended to Mercy -
Whipped and Discharged .

1556.
THOMAS DONOVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Benjamin Schofield
, from his person .

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD. On the 29th of August I was in Charlotte-street, Rathbone-place
, at seven o'clock in the evening - as I was taking the prisoner in charge, with three others, for causing a riot and fight in the street - I had hold of his left arm, and felt his right hand in my pocket; I took hold of him, and he came in front of me, and said, "Me pick your pocket," and threw the handkerchief down in the street.

JAMES BRUCE
. I saw Schofield holding the prisoner - he charged him with picking his pocket; I saw the handkerchief taken off the ground; I would not say the prisoner did not do it, but so little time elapsed that I could almost say as much.
NOT GUILTY .

1557.
ISAAC GRAVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 hat, value 8s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
James Jennings Forward
, from his person .

JAMES JENNINGS FORWARD. I am a tailor , and live at Hackney. On the evening of the 27th of June I was near Church-street, Shoreditch
, between eleven and twelve o'clock; I stood up at a door-way, out of the rain - two men were there, who asked which way I was going; I told them, and they said they were going the same way; I had not gone far before I found my arms pinioned, my hat taken off, and another put on; I gave an alarm, and the men ran away.

BENJAMIN BEAVIS
. I am headborough. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and saw a person in a white great coat run down an alley; I said, he was gone down the alley, and they went and got him - when he returned there was no hat on his head.

WILLIAM ANTHONY
. I am a watchman. I went in company with Buck and Taylor - the prisoner was taken at a door at the bottom of the steps; I saw this hat on his head; I took it off, and gave it to Buck.

JOSEPH BUCK
. I heard an alarm, and saw the prisoner in the passage - he was taken to the watch-house, and this hat was given to me.

GEORGE TAYLOR
. I saw the prisoner, and helped to secure him; I saw the hat taken from him; a handkerchief was in it.

CHARLES BRETT
. I went down the alley, and saw the prisoner in a passage with a hat on his head.

Prisoner. I saw the hat in the road; I took it up, and, as it rained, I put it on my head; I took my brother's supper, and was returning - they came and asked me what I had got there - I said a hat which I had found.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Four Months .

1558.
THOMAS HATWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 pair of shoes, value 2s.; 1 hat, value 5s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 1s.; 1 comb, value 1/2d., and 1 sovereign, the property of
William Miles
, from his person .

WILLIAM MILES. I live in the City-road, and am a Smith . On the night of the 29th of July I went to a beanfeast at Holloway; I was rather tipsy, and sat down by the side of the road to wait for my companions - the watchman came - and then two men came, who said they could take me to the cottage in the bric-kfield - one of them left me, and the other went with me to a high hill - I awoke at about six o'clock - I missed a sovereign, a coat, and 2 1/2d., which I am sure I had after I left the beanfeast - I also lost my shoes, my hat, and two handkerchiefs; I do not know who the man was, but he had a straw hat and a white jacket on - the hat and handkerchiefs were left in the field.

JAMES MEDLEYCOT
. I am a patrol. I took the prisoner on the 31st of July in Tenter-row, Shoreditch - I found these shoes on his feet, and on his person a comb, a knife, and a shilling.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the shoes on the Sunday morning, at Battle-bridge - I have had the coat six months.(Property produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .

1559.
MARGARET KEANE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 watch, value 4l., and 4 shillings the property of
Richard Heap
, from his person .

RICHARD HEAP. I am a watchmaker . I met the prisoner on Friday night, the 7th of July, between eleven and twelve o'clock; she invited me to her apartment, Bennet-street, Westminster
, and I went to bed there - I put my breeches under the pillow with my watch; I awoke at five o'clock, and missed her - I found my breeches on the pillow, but the watch gone - I have never seen it since.

ALEXANDER CANNON
. I live in Bennet-street. The prisoner hired a room in my house on this day, and said her husband was in the Coldstream Guards.

Prisoner's Defence. He went home with me. I asked what money he had - he said he had but one shilling, and would give me no more till the morning - I went in the morning and got a watchman; but he said he would not take any man in the room; he had no watch that I saw.

PROSECUTOR. I swear I had a watch, and 4s. in a small leather purse, which was likewise taken - she asked for no money that night, but said, in the morning, she would make all right - I was a little in liquor when I met her.
JURY. Q. When did you see your watch last? A. About an hour before - it was then past eleven o'clock - I did not see any other young woman - she took the key inside and locked the door.
NOT GUILTY .

1560.
JOHN LAWRENCE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Pritchett
, from his person .

EDWARD PRITCHETT. On the 30th of July I was under an arch-way, leading to Palace-yard
- when I had been there half an hour the officer told me I had lost my handkerchief - I saw the prisoner then in custody - I had not seen him before, nor felt any pull at my pocket - I felt my handkerchief safe just before.

WILLIAM WHEATLEY
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner following the prosecutor - he put his hand into his pocket, and then put it into his left breast - I ran after the gentleman, and Tyrrell took the handkerchief from the prisoner.

ROBERT TYRRELL
. I took this handkerchief from the prisoner's left breast-pocket - we had followed him, but I did not see him take it - he said "Don't hurt me, I will go quietly."
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1561.
MARY MORIARTY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of July , 1 purse, value 2d.; 1 crown, 2 half-crowns, 5 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the property of
John Hurst
, from his person .

JOHN HURST. I was in the tap-room of a public-house, in St. Giles'. On the 23d of July, in the evening, the prisoner came in with one or two more persons, who went out again - she came and sat down by my side a little while, and then went out; she had some of my beer when she returned, and sat by me again, and then we went to another house and had some porter; I then went to a room with her; I sat down on a bed; she turned herself, and put her hand into my trousers pocket, and took out my purse, which had one crown, two half-crowns, five shillings, and two sixpences in it; I felt her hand coming out of my pocket, and said "You hussy, you have robbed me of my purse;" she denied it, and went to quit the room; the people below asked what was the matter; they then sent for an officer, who searched her; but I have never got the purse again.

DANIEL REARDON
. I was sent for. I said "You had better give the man his money;" she said "God bless you, I have not got any of his money;" I could not find the purse, but I found some duplicates which had been init, I found one crown piece in her mouth and four shillings loose in her pocket.

WILLIAM ADAMS
. I am an officer. I saw the crown found in her mouth.
Prisoner's Defence. He took me to this place, and gave me 5s. and paid 3d. for the room; when we were coming out, he said "Give me the 5s.;" I would not; he seized me, and gave me a black eye.
NOT GUILTY .

1562.
JOHN NORRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of June , 1 coral necklace, value 7s., the goods of
Thomas Harding
, from the person of
Henry Perry Harding
.

HENRY PERRY HARDING. I live in Goldsmith-place, Hackney-road. On the 29th of June I was in Hackney-road
with the child, who had a coral necklace, and a gold soap; the prisoner, with some others, made a terrible rush, and he took the necklace from the child's neck; I caught him by the arm and called for assistance - Carter came and held him - it fell on the ground - I could not see who took it up.

JOHN CARTER
. I saw the prisoner in Harding's custody, and secured him.

WILLIAM SHUERS
. I am a patrol. I received the prisoner in custody - I found two handkerchiefs and two duplicates on him.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined Six Months .

1563.
MARGARET O'BRIEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 sovereign and 12 shillings, the monies of
John Kipling
, from his person .

JOHN KIPLING. I am a bricklayer . I went home with the prisoner to Brewer's-yard
, on the 13th of August, and while there I found her hand in my breeches pocket, in which I had a sovereign and 15s.; I told her to take her hand out, and I thought I had prevented her from taking it; I went out of the house with her, and when I left her I missed my money; I went for an officer, and we found her in the watch-house, in three or four hours after; she was tipsy, and had been abusing another man; a sovereign was found on her and a number of shillings, which I could not swear to.

JOHN BARNLEY
. I am the officer. About seven o'clock I found the prisoner in the watch-house, disorderly - I searched and found this money on her - she said she had saved it up.

Prisoner's Defence. He would go home with me - he had been with me several times - he gave me 5s.; we came out, and went to the Crown public-house, in West-street - we could not get in, and he bade me good night.
KIPLING. I saw her next day, and she said she was sorry that she took the money from a man she knew.
GUILTY . Aged 25.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

1564.
JAMES PARKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a man unknown
from his person .

ANGELIOUS BERTRAUN
. I was in Bond-street
, near the corner of Brook-street, on the 16th of July, and saw the prisoner with a companion, who took this handkerchief from the pocket of a gentlemen who gave his name as"Mr. Bright, Chandos-street;" he gave the prisoner the handkerchief, and I ran and took hold of him; I went to Chandos-street, but could not find the gentleman.

Prisoner's Defence. I was returning home - a young man asked me to lend him 6d., and said he would leave this handkerchief with me till morning; the constable came up, and asked me where I got it - I told him, and he made me go to two gentlemen, whom he asked if they had lost their handkerchiefs - they said No, and then he said some one had.
ANGELIOUS BERTRAUN. This is false - the gentleman gave me his address, but I could not find him.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

1565.
WILLIAM POPE
,
HENRY EVANS
, and
JOSEPH CARROLL
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , one handkerchief, value 2s., the good of
John Gittins
, from his person .

JOHN GITTINS. I lost my handkerchief on the 8th of August, while I was in King-street, Covent-garden
; I did not feel it go, nor see the persons, but, on missing it, I turned round and saw none of the prisoners near me - I had had it within half an hour.

JOHN GROOM
. I saw Pope pick this gentleman's pocket, while I was walking up King-street; the gentleman was walking with a lady, and the prisoner followed him; Pope drew the handkerchief several times a little further out of the pocket; he then took it quite out; the other two were close by, and must have seen what he did; I ran across, and gave Pope into the prosecutor's custody, and ran to Covent-garden, but the others had got away - I took them next morning. I had seen Pope hustling the handkerchief up in his hand, but whether he passed it to the others or not I cannot tell - it has not been found.
POPE'S Defence. I was out, looking for work, and this officer came, and said I had picked a pocket; as to those boys, I had never seen them before.
EVANS' Defence. I was at home at tea, with my father, before six o'clock.

POPE -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

EVANS -
GUILTY . Aged 14.

CARROLL -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1566.
ANN GRIFFITHS
, and
REBECCA BARKER
were indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 shirt, value 1s.; 1 necklace, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shirt, value 1s.; 1 spoon, value 1s., and 1 pillow-case, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Jonathan Hatch
; and 1 shirt, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 cap, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
William Brown
.

MARY HATCH
. I am the wife of Jonathan Hatch, who lives in Park-street
, and is a fruit salesman . The prisoner Griffiths, was nurse in my family. On the 21st of August, I missed all this property out of the drawers, except the shirt which was dirty.
Cross-examined by Mr. BARRY. Q. When had you seen the necklace? A. The morning before it was taken.

JAMES WILLIAM CRESSEY
. I am a pawnbroker, and produce a tea-spoon, which was pawned on the 29th of June, by Griffiths - this shirt was pledged at a different time.

JOHN ANDREW SIMPSON
. I am servant to Mr. Merrett, of Long-acre. On the 21st of August, Griffiths pledged a necklace with me.

ELIZABETH BROWN
. I am the wife of William Brown, and we lodge in the prosecutor's house - the shirt and cap are ours.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GRIFFITH'S Defence. I did not mean to defraud, but to return them.

GRIFFITHS -
GUILTY . Aged 46.
Confined Fourteen Days .

BARKER -
NOT GUILTY .

1567.
WILLIAM FARRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 3lbs. of bacon, value 3s. , the goods of
Richard Morris
.

JAMES MARK
. I am shopman to Richard Morris, a cheesemonger , of Somer's-town
. Between eight and nine o'clock on the evening of the 12th of August I saw the prisoner put his hand into the window, and take out this bacon; I followed, and never lost sight of him till I took him with it - he had 14s. about him.
Prisoner's Defence. I meant to buy the bacon, but he would not take my money.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Whipped and Discharged .

1568.
MARY SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 11 scarfs, value 6l. 12s. , the goods of
Archibald Douglas
.

ARCHIBALD DOUGLAS. I am a silk manufacturer , and live in Bow-lane
. On the 14th of July I missed eleven searfs; I saw them all right about the 9th, when I left town. I found six of them at a pawnbroker's on the 14th- they bore my mark on the 9th, but the tickets have been taken off, except one.

EDWARD STORER
. I am shopman to Mr. Balfour, of Chandos-street, a pawnbroker. These six scarfs were pawned, by the prisoner, on the 14th of July; she said her name was Mary Smith, but she pawned them in the name of
Eliza Hudson
, of Villiers-street, Strand.

Prisoner. Q. Was I not some time in your shop? - A. Yes; you said something about a lady having just come from France. On the Saturday following you came to redeem three of them, when I told you they were stolen, and I must give you into custody.

JOHN DEAN
. I am shopman to Mr. Douglas. I missed the shawls on the 13th of July - I cannot say how many, but I can swear to some of those produced; they were made to a particular order, and no other had been made at the time. The ticket on one of them is our's - I had them in my hand a quarter of an hour before - they must have been taken. I know nothing of the prisoner.

WILLIAM JOHN MEAD
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in Tottenham-court-road. Two of the scarfs now produced were pledged on the 14th of July, by the prisoner, in the name of Mary Steerer.

WILLIAM COZENS
. I received the prisoner into custody, and found the ticket upon her, in the name of Steerer.

Prisoner's Defence. I was applied to by a person, who said she was a widow, and that her husband had been in the army; she said she did not like to pawn them herself, because they had not paid the duty.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1569.
JOHN READING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a man unknown
, from his person .

EDWARD BOOTHMAN
. I am a chair-maker. I was returning from the Haymarket Theatre on the 4th of July. about half-past eleven o'clock at night, and saw the prisoner and another man following a gentleman and lady; I saw the other pick the gentleman's pocket of a white handkerchief; the prisoner was close to him; I immediately went and told the gentleman - the other wiped his nose with the handkerchief, turned round, and walked down the Haymarket, and the prisoner with him - they then followed a gentleman who came from the Theatre, and I saw a light-coloured handkerchief drawn from his pocket; I called the watchman, and when they saw us coming they both ran down Panton-street
; the prisoner was taken, but the other got away; we found a light-coloured handkerchief on the prisoner, resembling the one I had seen taken, and the duplicate of one pawned the day before.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you see the prisoner's companion take the handkerchief? A. Yes. I went to the gentleman - he felt, and said he had lost it; he would not prosecute. I expect to get what expenses the Court will allow. The prisoner's companion took the first handkerchief, and the prisoner the second.
COURT. Q. Do you believe this light-coloured handkerchief to be the one he took? A. Yes.

THOMAS CUSS
. I was night constable. The prisoner was brought in, and I found this handkerchief and a duplicate on him.
NOT GUILTY .

1570.
WILLIAM DARVILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of September , 2 crowns, and 1 half-crown, the monies of
Edward Leeworthy
, from his person .

EDWARD LEEWORTHY. I am a carpenter . On the 3d of September, between twelve and one o'clock at night, I had been paid with three or four others - we had been drinking rather freely, but I knew what I was doing - I slipped off the curb on St. Paul's-terrace
; the prisoner came up, and in assisting me up my jacket and waistcoat came off together; he was quite a stranger to me; he shook the money out of my pockets; I had three crowns and two half-crowns; I had seen it all right a quarter of an hour before; I did not see the money fall, but the officer did; I collared him, and he was taken to the watch-house.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were you not very tipsy? A. I had drank a little - I left work at six o'clock.

SAMUEL PRENDERGRASS
. I am an officer. On the 3d of September, between twelve and one o'clock, I was returning from Kentish-town to Battle-bridge - I saw three or four persons together, and the prosecutor was on the ground; I saw the prisoner lift the prosecutor, and take up something, which I ascertained afterwards to be his waistcoat; I did not see any stripping - that was done before I got there - I saw him shake the waistcoat twice,and I heard something fall; Wescott stooped, as if to pick up something - the prisoner did the same; Wescott said, "You have got something;" the prisoner denied it, and used very bad language; I said, "I thought you was very busy about that man," and I asked what he had in his pockets, and whether he knew the prosecutor; he said he did, and, I think he said, he had been drinking with him; the prosecutor then got up, took hold of his collar, and said, "You have got my money - I don't know you at all;" I asked again what money he had got - he said 29s.; I searched him, and in one of his breeches pockets I found 8s., in the other 2s. 6d.; I asked him how he came to say he had 29s. - he said that was no consequence - I asked if he had no more money - he said No, but from his left-hand coat pocket I took this crown-piece; he said somebody must have put it there, and he accused us of so doing.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not find three crowns and two half-crowns? A. No; the prosecutor had been drinking, but was sensible. I have found the prisoner is a coachman in place, and bears a good character.
NOT GUILTY .

1566.
SARAH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 sovereign, 2 half-crowns, and 5 shillings, the monies of
William Mudd
, from his person .

WILLIAM MUDD. I am a tailor , and live in St. Helena-place. On the 13th of August, about a quarter-past twelve o'clock at night, I was going from Sadler's-well, to the top of Rosamond-street
- the prisoner accosted me, and asked me to go with her; we got into conversation for about three minutes; she was throwing her arms about my waist - she then turned off from me, and though at first she wanted money, she did not then ask for any; I had taken liberties with her, and had not paid her, but I was to have done so; as she was turning away, I put my hand into my pocket, and missed one sovereign, two half-crowns, and five-shillings, from my left-hand waistcoat pocket - I seized her arm - a sovereign and a shilling were left; I asked her to give me my money - she denied having it - I took her to the watch-house, and stated to the night constable what I had lost; she said she would soon show what money she had - put her hand in her pocket, and pulled out the two half-crowns and five shillings; the officer told her to put her hand into her pocket again - she did so, and pulled out three penny pieces and between them was the sovereign.

THOMAS MARKHAM
. I am an officer, and was in the watch-house when Mudd brought the prisoner; he thought at first he had one shilling more, but he recollected afterwards he had spent a shilling; the prisoner said she had had good luck that night, and would soon show what money she had; she pulled out two half-crowns, five shillings, and a sixpence, and said that was all she had; I said, "Come, now I must have a search;" she put her hand into her pocket again, and pulled out 3d., and between them was the sovereign, which she said she did not know she had, but gentlemen were in the habit of giving a sovereign, instead of a shilling, in the dark.

Prisoner's Defence. This man was in the company of two women - he left them and came to me - he took me up a court and offered me a shilling, which I took, and put into my pocket; he wanted to take very indecent libertles with me - I would not let him, and he gave charge of me.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1572.
EDWARD BUSH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of June , 1 bed tick, value 6s.; 1 bolster, value 3s.; 1 curtain, value 2s.; 2 blankets, value 12s.; 2 quilts, value 10s.; four pictures, value 2s.; 2 sheets, value 5s., and 1 looking-glass, value 2s., the goods of
Thomas May
, in a lodging-room .

SUSANNAH MAY
. I am the wife of Thomas May, and live in Smith-street, Westminster
. The prisoner's wife hired my lodging - he came afterwards; they lived together as man and wife from Tuesday till Saturday night; they went away without giving me notice - the door was locked, and I expected them to return - I missed all the property stated; the prisoner was taken on Westminster-bridge with some property, but not mine; I do not live in the house - it is all let out.

JOHN CULLINGFORD
. I am in the Coldstream Guards, and live in Smith's-rents, York-street. On the 14th of June I saw the prisoner and his wife turning down the bed together; my wife remarked, "those people are going to bed early" - but in half an hour I saw them get up and go out together, with each a large bundle; I saw them return in about an hour.

Prisoner's Defence. I have no wife; I was going through Westminster, and the woman said, "Will you go home with me," which I did, and in the morning I paid her her due; I went again the next night, but I know no more of her than any one here.
NOT GUILTY .

1573.
THOMAS KENDRICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 blanket, value 8s.; 1 sheet, value 9s., and 2 pillow cases, value 3s., the goods of
William Gilling
, in a lodging room .

SARAH GILLING
. I am the wife of William Gilling - we live in Cow-cross-street, Smithfield
. I let the prisoner, on the 24th of April, a furnished room, on the second floor, at 6s. per week; he stated he was married, and he brought a woman with him - they remained till the 10th of August; his wife asked me for a clean pair of sheets, which I gave her, and in about half an hour I saw her go out with something under her apron; I watched her to the pawnbroker's; the prisoner was at home at that time, out of work; I am confident he was in their room, it was between eleven and twelve o'clock in the day.

THOMAS CARPENTER
. I am apprentice to Mr. Croas, of Turnmill-street. I have a blanket pawned for 3s., two pairs of pillow-cases for 1s., and one sheet for 3s. 6d., by the prisoner's wife, in the name of Kendrick - I knew her before.

JOHN LOADSMAN
. I am an officer. Gilling sent to me on the 10th of July; the prisoner gave me up these duplicates, and said he had pawned the goods.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. It was distress that urged me to do it.
GUILTY . Aged 30.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

1566.
FRANCES NEWMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of July , 2 sheets, value 4s, the goods of
John Burton
, in a lodging room in his dwelling-house .

SARAH BURTON
. I am the wife of John Burton, of Tothill-street. I let a lodging to the prisoner in Baker-street
; that house is all let out -
it is not our dwelling-house. NOT GUILTY .

1574.
MARY WILEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 5 pillows, value 16s.; 1 blanket, value 4s.; 3 sheets, value 14s.; 1 counterpane, value 6s.; 2 bolsters, value 12s.; 1 bed-tick, value 6s., and 2 flat irons, value 2s., the goods of
Mary Stote
, widow , in a lodging room .

MARY STOTE. I am a widow, and live in Eagle-court, St. John's-lane
. I let the prisoner a room on the second-floor, furnished, on the 6th of May, at 4s. 6d. a week; I had great difficulty to get my rent - she owes me 9s. now; on the 4th of September a person gave me information; I went to the prisoner's door, but she would not let me in; I sent for an officer, she did not refuse to let him in; I said, "Good God! have you been robbing me, with my family?" the officer found some duplicates - she admitted she had robbed me, but refused at first to tell where the property was, but she told the officer afterwards; she works at her needle; a person cohabited with her as her husband, but I let the room to her, and did not see him; the next day she told me her husband paid the rent; he was with her all the time she was there.

CHARLES CROOK
. I am shopman to Mr. Chapman, a pawnbroker, in St. James-street. I have one blanket and one sheet, pawned by the prisoner on the 16th and 17th of June.

RICHARD PERRY
. I am shopman to Mr. Brown, a pawnbroker, I have a blanket and a pillow-case pawned by the prisoner, I believe, on the 7th of July.

JOHN JONES
. I live in Middleton-street, Spa-fields, with Mr. Blackburn, a pawnbroker. I have a bolster and pillow - I cannot say whether they were pawned by the prisoner or her mother, as both were in the habit of pawning goods with me.

WILLIAM BRADFORD
. I am shopman to Mr. Bailey, a pawnbroker, Aldersgate-street. I have two pillows and a bed, pawned on the 15th of July, by a woman, but I do not know who.

ROBERT CLARK
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner - she said if we would stop till Saturday she would send the property back again; I asked her where the duplicates were; she said she gave them to her sister; I took her, and she said she had them of the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. She said, if she had the money, that was all she wanted, and she had it for what they were pawned for.

JOHN MCTYRE
. I am a carver, and live in Tash-street, Gray's-inn-lane. On the evening the prisoner was taken, word was sent to me, that it was for things she had pawned through distress, and if I could in any way assist her, she would be obliged; I went and saw Mrs. Stote - I told her that I could not make up the money to release the things that night, but I could the following morning, and I paid 1l. 12s. 6d. to a man named Ward, who lodged there, with this proviso, that I was to pay 16s. more.
COURT. Q. Did Mrs. Stote agree, if you paid this money. to forego the prosecution? A. Yes - and I paid 1l. 12s. 6d. to the man, but the Magistrate ordered him to pay it back again.
MARY STOTE re-examined. Q. Did you ever agree to take this money? A. No, never in my life - I never received a single farthing.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months .

1575.
THOMAS CUNNINGHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 6 sets of castors, value 3l.; 4 planes, value 8s.; I saw, value 3s.; and 1 hand-vice, value 2s., the goods of
Charles Kensell
, his master .

CHARLES KENSELL. I am a cabinet-maker , and live in Temple-street, York-place. The prisoner had been seven years in my employ - he was at work for me on the 1st of August; he got castors in my name, unknown to me - I knew nothing of it till the clerk came and told me of it; they had not been in my possession - he had pawned them before he got home - I have not paid for them - the duplicate of the planes were found afterwards; he had them to work with.

EDWARD BELL
. I am in the employ of Mr. Reynolds, an ironmonger, of Compton-street
. The prisoner came for a set of castors on the 1st of August, in the name of Mr. Kensell, which I served him with, and booked them to Mr. Kensell.

HERRY STOWELL
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner into custody; he denied knowing any thing about the castors, but I told him he did - and asked him for the duplicates - he said, he had none - but in going along he produced one for the castors - I then found others for the different tools, which he said, he got from Mr. Reynolds; he said he had been drinking some time, and did not know what he had been about.

GEORGE CHAPMAN
. I am shopman to Mr. Bailey, pawnbroker, Mary-le-bone-street - I have four castors pawned by the prisoner on the 14th of July.

CHRISTOPHER GRAVES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two sets of castors, two planes, and a saw - one set of castors I took in of the prisoner - I did not take the rest in - they are pawned in the names of Cox, Wilson, and Carter.

EDWARD STOKES
. I am shopman to Mr. Ross, a pawnbroker - I have two planes, but the person who took them in has left me.

HENRY KING
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Tottenham-court-road - I have two sets of castors; one set was pawned by the prisoner on the 1st of August - the other on the 14th of July; but I did not take it in.
NOT GUILTY .

1576.
THOMAS DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 gill of oil, value 3s., and 2lbs. weight of spermaceti, value 2s., the goods of
Alexander Barclay
and others, his masters .

HUGH BARCLAY. I am in partnership with Alexander and William Barclay - we are refiners and oil men . The prisoner worked for us about three months - we received information, and one evening, when he was about to leave work, I taxed him with having oil about him; he denied it - I said, "Yes you have abottle of oil in your jacket pocket" - he said, "Yes, I have Sir - I took a little to oil my hair;" there was about a gill of it - I got an officer, and on searching his lodging, about 2lbs. of spermaceti was found - I believe it is ours; the value of the oil is about two-pence.

THOMAS INGRAM
. I am foreman to Messrs. Barclays. The prisoner had been at work three or four months; in consequence of a former robbery, I searched the pockets of the work people - I found the prisoner's pocket very oily, and told Mr. Barclay; I know the spermaceti; here is a piece of a lump I can swear to.

JAMES MEDLEYCOTT
. I took the prisoner and went to his lodgings; I found the spermacetti, and asked what it was - he called it skimmings; he told me voluntarily that it came from Mr. Barclay's, but said the foreman gave it to him.

Prisoner's Defence. It was given by the foreman, for the men to wash their dirty aprons in; I asked the man who worked in the cellar for a drop of oil to kill a few bugs- he said "Take a drop, but don't say any thing about it."
NOT GUILTY .

1577.
WILLIAM HANCOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of August , 19 yards of cloth, value 15l.; 74 yards of kerseymere, value 22l., and 1 wrapper, value 6d., the goods of
Zachary Langton
, and others, his partners, to whom he was a servant
.

ROBERT LAMBERT
. I am in the employ of Pickford and Co. - Zachary Langton is one of the partners. I saw this bale of goods at Bow-street
- the prisoner has been in our employ three or four years - we pay the Captain, who pays him.

THOMAS WISE
. I am porter at Messrs. Pickford's. I remember a bale of goods coming, directed to Mr. Sclater, Knutsford; I saw it opened the next day, and it contained seventy-six yards of kerseymere in one wrapper - it was brought to our warehouse from the Castle inn, Wood-street, on the 3d of August; I saw it in the warehouse - it was to go to Knutsford, by Pickford and Co.'s canal boat. It was the duty of the shipping clerk to put it on board; the prisoner was boatman to Messrs. Pickford and Co.; this truss was to have gone by a Liverpool boat; I saw the prisoner going across the warehouse with it - he had no business with it, because he was not loading that boat then - this was about nine o'clock at night; I was at work in the warehouse, and he set the truss against the door, near the scale where they weigh the goods; I went out, and when I returned I saw the prisoner - the truss was gone; I went up to the door to see where he was gone with it, and he was carrying it in his arms, up to the far end of the boat - it fell into the water - he took it up, and put it in a place where they put coals- not where they put goods - when he came back I asked what he had been at, and what that was which he let fall in the water; he said he supposed it was a block fell off the boat; I then went and told the gentleman of it - they came out and we went and pulled the boat back, and found the truss - the prisoner was then gone out.

EDWARD POWNER
. I am clerk to Messrs. Pickford and Co. The prisoner was a boatman - it was not his duty to remove this truss - he had nothing to do with it; on Thursday evening Wise said they had got something in the boat which they had no business with; I went and took it out, and saw the direction on it; it was not to have gone by that boat - it was loading for Leicester; the prisoner belonged to that boat; the bale was found among the coals - not a proper place to stow goods; I saw it opened afterwards - it contained seventy yards of kerseymere.

ROBERT LAMBERT
. This kerseymere is worth 22l., and the broad-cloth 15l. - making 37l. together.

JOHN CHURCH
. I am a porter. The prisoner gave me 6d., to go and get a drop of beer, and while I was gone he made away with the truss.

ALEXANDER MOORE
. I was sent for, and took the prisoner; he said he knew nothing about it.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1578.
MARY SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 2 pillow-cases, value 1s. 6d., and 2 towels, value 1s., the goods of
John Depcke
, as master .

JOHN DEPCKE. I am a grocer . I live in Long-acre
. The prisoner was in my service eight days when she appeared to be ill, and wished to leave; I told her it our custom to search servants' boxes, and kept her an hour, to induce her to open her box; she said she had objected to it in two former services, and she would not submit to it; I begged her to do it but she would not - the officer was then sent for, and the box opened - these articles were found - she said they were not ours.

EDWARD VALLANCE
. I am a constable. I asked the prisoner to open her box, which she did - two pillow-cases and two towels were found in it; the name had been picked out; she begged forgiveness, and said she would met do so any more.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating, that she intended to return the property when she recovered. She received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 21.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1579.
JOHN RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 coffee biggin, value 16s , the goods of
John Simson Tiddeman
.

MARY TIDDEMAN
. I am the wife of John Simson Tiddeman, an ironmonger , of Upper East Smithfield
. On the 26th of August, about eight o'clock, the prisoner came with a green-spectacle case, to know if I could mend it; I sent the servant girl to tell him he must go to a spectacle-maker's; as soon as he was gone I missed my coffee-biggin, and was much alarmed; a young woman then came and told me I had lost it; I ran to the door - the young lady pointed him out to me another time - he was a perfect stranger to me; I have not seen the coffee-biggin since.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Will you swear this young man was in the shop? A. No; I saw the coffee-biggin while he was in the shop - I missed it about ten minutes afterwards; I went into my parlour - there was no one in the shop - I had a child in my arms, which sucks - it was not crying; I had been robbed fivedays before of some spoons; I do not swear to this young man at all, but I am sure it was him.
COURT. Q. How came he to be taken up? A. Because the young lady, who came to tell me I had lost it, said she would point out the man - she did so, and he was taken.

LOUISA HUGHES
. I am a waistcoat-maker, and live opposite this shop. Between eight and nine o'clock I saw the prisoner, in company with two men; they stood next door but one; the prisoner went into the shop; I am quite sure it was him; it was broad day-light, and my window was open; he had nothing with him that I saw; the other two then crossed; the prisoner then came out of the shop, and, in a few minutes, went in again, and the second time I saw him draw a coffee-biggin from the corner of the shop, and put it under his coat; he and his two companions then went away; I was so much alarmed I could not cry out, but I went over and told what I had seen - on the following Tuesday I pointed the prisoner out; I am sure he is the man; I had never seen him before, but I particularly observed him.

Cross-examined. Q. Then you did not see any thing in his hand when he wentin? A. No; he could not have had a spectacle case in his hand; he had his face towards me for about five minutes - when he came out of the shop with the biggin, they all walked away; I was but a little way from him; it is not a wide street - he had lightish-coloured napkeen trousers on, and a blue coat; I observed him particularly; he has a particular walk, and is rather a bow legged man; this was on a Saturday; I saw him again on the Tuesday, when they all three went past the house again, I went and told Mrs. Tiddeman - she went to try to get an officer, but could not; they got away - the prisoner was taken on the following Saturday; I could see the coffee-biggin in the shop as I sat at my window; it was just as you go in on the right hand.
Prisoner's Defence. I was at work at Hackney-common.

JAMES PLOWMAN
. I am a constable. I took the prisoner on Saturday, the 2d of September, he made no resistance - Mrs. Tiddeman told me of him; they were all three walking together.

Mrs. TIDDEMAN re-examined. He is the man who came into my shop; he took the spectacle case out of his pocket - I have no doubt he is the man; I was sure it was him; I said, "You know me, I suppose;" he said, "I don't know you by God;" I told him if he would give me my property back, or the duplicate, I would not proceed.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .
FIFTH DAY. TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 19.
Third Middlessex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1580.
JOHN HENRICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of July , 38 yards of cotton, value 1l. , the goods of
William Dobinson
.

WILLIAM DOBINSON. I am a draper , and live in High-street, Shadwell
. This piece of cotton is mine, and has my private mark upon it; it was in my shop on the 21st of July; I had been showing it to a customer; I did not miss it till the officer brought the prisoner back half an hour after I had seen it; I placed it on a pile with others, a yard and a half from the door; the shop-ticket was found in his right hand.

JAMES BEECHEY
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner with this cotton, at the corner of King David's-lane, eighty or ninety yards from the shop, on Friday, the 21st of July; he was walking very fast, and putting his handkerchief over the cotton; he spoke Englis very well.

Prisoner's Defence. (through an interpreter.) A man gave it to me to carry, and said he would pay me to take it to his house.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, being poor and away fom his own land.
Judgment respited .

1581.
RICHARD MYATT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 2 chairs, value 5s. , the goods of
William Taylor
.

ELEANOR BILLETT
. Lewis Billet, my son, is fifteen years of age; he was sent with two chairs by his master to take them to Hoxton.

LEWIS BILLETT
. I live with William Taylor; he is a chair japanner , and lives in Charlotte-street, Fitzroy-square. On the 31st of July he sent me with two chairs, which I was to try to sell at the broker's shop; I took them as a sample of the half dozen; when I was at the corner of Charlton-street, the prisoner, whom I knew before, said he would go with me; I left the chairs at Mr. Jessup's shop, at Somer's-town
; I went with the prisoner along the City-road; a mad bull came by, and I lost the prisoner; I went to the City, and when I came back to Jessup's, the chairs were gone.

JOHN FARREN
. I am twelve years of age. I am in the employ of Mr. Jessup; I was in the shop on the 31st of July; the prisoner and Billett left the chairs; the prisoner afterwards came back, and sat on a chair; I told him to go off; he did not say any thing, but got off and sat on the step of Mr. Grove's door; he went to sleep, and I awoke him; he went to sleep again for two hours; he then said,"The other don't seem to come, so I shall take the chairs;" he said he was going to take them home to his master, with whom he had lived about a week.

ROBERT WILLANS
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner - the chairs have not been found.
Prisoner. The boy has taken a false oath; I was not at the place at all.
JURY to FARREN. Q. Can you positively swear to the prisoner being the person who took the chairs away? A. Yes; he put one upon the other, and took them away.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .

1582.
JOHN MORTIMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 watch, value 12s. , the goods of
Charlotte Daines
, widow .

SECOND COUNT, stating it to belong to
Ann Saunders
,

ANN SAUNDERS. I live in Cross-street, St. Giless
, I lost my watch from the mantel-piece of the second floor, front room, which I occupy - I saw it safe about the 6th of June - I went out to nurse; I called at home afterwards, and it was gone - I saw it in the hands of Schofield - this is it - I have known the prisoner from his birth; he lived in the same house with me.

THOMAS BARRETT
. I saw the prisoner on the 22d of June, showing this watch at South-end, in Kent - I walked on, he followed me, and said, he found it at the milestone, near Bromley; that he met a drunken sailor just before with some seals in his hand, and he thought it had belonged to him; and did I think it was worth five shillings? I said, "I do not know; I may perhaps find an owner for it," and gave him the five shillings.

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD
. I received information, and went to Barrett's uncle, who had pawned the watch in the Kent-road, and there I got it.

JURY to ANN SAUNDERS. Q. Was your room locked? A. No; it was in the care of a woman who lived in the court - I afterwards taxed the prisoner with it; he acknowledged it, and begged for mercy - he had a very respectable father, who is dead - his mother is a nurse.
GUILTY . Aged 11.

Recommended to Mercy -
Judgment Respited .

1583.
THOMAS TAYLOR
was indicted for
bigamy .
In the absence of any proof of a second marriage, the prisoner was ACQUITTED .

1584.
JOSEPH RICHARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 piece of gold, value 1l. , the goods of our Lord
the King
.
MESSRS. BOLLAND and LAW conducted the prosecution.

JAMES CAMPER
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Whitechapel-road. On the 6th of September, the prisoner came to my shop, about six o'clock in the evening; he showed this piece of gold, and asked if it was gold; I had my suspicion, and asked, why he supposed it was gold, as it looked more like copper than any thing else - he said, by the weight of it, and he had picked it up opposite Whitechapel-church - I asked if any one saw him pick it up; he said, they might or might not; it was close by a stall, where some women were selling fruit - I asked if he worked at the Mint; he said no, nor any of his relations or friends; that he worked at the West-India Docks, and his name was Thompson; he lived at No. 33, Chicksand-street; I weighed it; I supposed it to be a blank sovereign, I told him to follow me, and show me where he lived; I went there - he said, he wanted to go up stairs, but I prevented it - a young woman then came forward, and I asked if he was her brother? she said, Yes; I asked if he worked at the Mint? she said, No; nor any of her friends or relations - the prisoner heard this, and they endeavoured to communicate with each other, but I prevented it - I then brought the prisoner along Chicksand-street, and when I got near the top, his sister came running after us, and wished to speak to him again; I would not allow it - and she then said, she would tell me the whole truth, his name was Richards, and he did work at the Mint
- I took him to Lambeth-street officer, and seven shillings were found on him - I gave information at the Mint; Mr. Bingley, the assay master, cut a piece off this blank, which I have here - it was wet and muddy; it had rained, and the roads were muddy.

ROBERT FINCH
. I am one of the moneyers of the Mint. I was on duty on Wednesday, the 6th of September; I was attending the whole process from room to room; he prisoner had been employed there eighteen months, and was gernerally employed in the cutting-out room - he was in the cutting-room; he had the opportunity of taking away blanks; there were thousands of them there - he had access to them, and must know what they were; he left a little after five o'clock - when gold comes in it is received in bars, each bar is worked separately, and weighed up with a ticket each night; and if in the several weighings which that bar goes through, it is found to be correct - it is then taken to the cutting-out room, and is cut into blanks like this, with the exception of this piece, which is cut off it - there had been some gold there that day, the property of the Bank of England;
Henry William Atkinson
is a provost of the Mint, and there are others; the Mint is liable to the owner of the gold sent to be coined, to make up the weight - on the day in question, there was, I think, three ounces more gold missing than is usual, from the quantity worked.

HENRY BINGLEY
. I am assistant to the King's assay-master, at the Mint. This blank was brought to me to be assayed; I cut this small piece of it off in the presence of Mr. Atkinson and Mr. Camper - this is such a blank as would make a sovereign if it were stamped; it is the right quality and quantity of gold, and worth one pound.

JASPER ATKINSON
. I am one of the moneyers of the Mint. I attended at Lambeth-street, on the 7th of September; I had a blank delivered to me, which Mr. Camper brought to the Mint, and I weighed it there; it was a standard piece, 5dwts. 3qrs., and a fraction, the exact weight a blank would be, and worth one pound; it was weighed before it was cut.

HONILY . I am an apprentice to the moneyers of the Mint. It was my duty to weigh the gold. On the 5th of September, I weighed all the gold bars delivered out that day; the tickets were all attached to be bars - I put the account of the pieces cut out of these bars, and delivered it to Mr. Finch, who was the moneyer on duty that day.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined Six Months .

1585.
HENRY CLARKE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July
, 464 bobbins, value 10s.; 64ozs. weight of silk, value 8l.; 2lbs. weight of worsted, value 5s., and 1lb. weight of cotton, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Morris
, his master ; and
SAMUEL CLARKE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same, well-knowing it to have been stolen .
MR. ANDREWS conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS MORRIS. I am a fringe-manufacturer , and live in Bedford-street, Covent-garden
. Henry Clarke was in my service in July last - I know Samuel, and he knew Henry was in my employ. In consequence of information, on the 7th of July, I got Chamberlain, the constable, to go with a warrant to Wild-street, where Henry Clarke lodged; I saw his wife, whom I knew - I then went to his father's house, to make inquiries; Samuel is a twister , working at home with his father - his father was not at home. I was shewn some silk and some worsted, dyed; there were two hundred and fifty-seven bobbins of silk; I cannot tell the weight of silk on them, but 45l. is the value, speaking under the mark - there were thirty-three bobbins with silk and worsted, and one hundred and seventy-four empty bobbins, worth, perhaps, 10s. - there is my stamp on them, but a number of the marks are defaced- Samuel Clarke was in the house during the time I examined the property - he did not give any account of it, nor say any thing about it; neither his father, nor any part of his family had the means of being lawfully possessed of these goods.

Cross-examined by MR. CURWOOD. Q. The house you searched was the father's? A. Yes; Samuel lives and works there; I will not swear the silk was mine; they have learned the weaving trade, and must use such sort of silk as this; his father have had silk of me; he might have been in possession of my bobbins, and wound other people's silk on them; if I had found empty bobbins I should not have ventured to affirm they were stolen. The father has not bought twelve bobbins of silk of me in twelve months; the silk I die is peculiarly fine, Italian tram, not usually kept; there may be then or twelve houses in London where it might be bought.

MR. ANDREWS. Q. Does Samuel lodge in that house? A. I believe he does; his father never dealt with me in my life, to a tenth part of the extent of this property - I believe, from the nature of it, it is mine, and that I had not sold it to the father.

COURT. Q. Is there any thing to convince you that this silk had not been sold off your premises? A. I know I have lost property. I was not present when the young man said he could not account for it in the absence of his father. I have sold to Henry, but not more than once in twelve months - that was what is called gut coarse worsted or yarn.

Mr. ANDREWS. Q. Have you ever sold to Henry, for himself, or for Samuel, or for the father, such property as you found? A. He has bought silk, but never such a quantity as we found there. I have sold silk to Henry, for the father, but very little.

WILLIAM ECKITT
. I went to Wild-court, to the house where the father lives - I found Samuel Clarke up stairs, his mother and the children; I told him I had a warrant to search his premises - he said, very well, I was very welcome; he went up stairs, through a trap-door, to a very long workshop; Mr. Robertson went first, Samuel Clarke followed him, and I went behind; I turned on my right hand, and in the corner of the window I found bobbins, with cotton or worsted on them; they had Mr. Morris' name on them; they were not concealed, but quite open. Mr. Robertson identified them; Mr. Morris was not there - Mr. Robertson said, "Who has got the key of this desk?" Samuel said, "I have;" in that desk several bobbins of silk were found; Mr. Robertson said, "How came you by these;" he said he did not know - we then went to the other end of the room, and found some bobbins of cotton in a basket, which was behind a butter-flat- we collected together all the property which Mr. Robertson thought he came to search for; some was found up stairs and some below - the desk was on the right-hand in the work-shop; we came down to a little room on the first floor - Samuel unlocked it - I suppose he got the key out of his pocket; we found some of the property in some drawers, and all that Mr. Robertson identified as Mr. Morris' property was put into a bag - before we had done searching the little room Mr. Morris came - he said, in the presence of Samuel, that it was his property - I cannot say whether Samuel made any answer; Edward, another brother, came while I was there; he asked if I had been below - I said No; he said, "I dare say there is a cart load below - it is a bad job;" Samuel did not say any thing to this. Samuel was then taken to the watch-house - Henry was there before.

Cross-examined. Q. You know the father is a weaver and twister? A. I do not know it. The property was in the work-shop and store-room; Samuel said he did not know how it came there - he was not at work - he was at dinner. I said at Bow-street that Edward said it was a bad job - he did not say we were all wrong.
The witness's deposition being read, stated, "Edward Clarke said it was all wrong, and there was a cart load down stairs."

JOHN ROBERTSON
. I was in the employ of Mr. Morris, and know his mark - I left his employ about two years and three months ago. I accompanied the officer in this search, and picked out what property I supposed to be Mr. Morris' - I should think the value is 8l. or 10l. Edward Clarke came in, and he said it was a bad job, and if we went down stairs we should find a cart load - that was in the hearing of Samuel - the silk is in such a state as it would be if it had been sold, but the worsted is not; we find that bobbins do sometimes change hands, and the property of A may become the property of B, but it is not usual to erase the mark.

Cross-examined. Q. Do not you find some of these bobbins marked I K? A. Yes; I do not know how many; there are some of other persons'; I did not take every bit of silk round a bobbin of Mr. Morris's, to be Mr. Morris's silk, because I knew the prisoner had bought silk of Mr. Morris; I could not distinguish which, but the officer took away that which had his mark on it; I know his father is a twister, and has had his sons taught weaving; I have employed them myself; the goods there found were such as weavers would use.

COURT. Q. You said the silk was mostly in the state it would be if it was sold? A. Yes; but some of it has been used; here is one which had not been sold, because it has the winder's note on the top - but it is ready to be sold; I should think, from finding other letters on a bobbin, it was merely to obliterate the former letters - but if a person of that name had bought these bobbins, and chose to keep them, he might put his I. K. upon them, and then they might pass to other hands.

ROBERT CLARKE
. I am the prisoner's father. In July last, I was in Bartholomew-Hospital - I went there on the 17th of May, and was discharged on the 24th of August; I was only out for the air one Sunday, when I went home and dined - Samuel lodged at my house, and was one of my hands.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. I am a weaver and lace-maker. These are my patterns, and what I make; all these articles are such as I use in my work, I have bought of Mr. Morris, and a number of others - I left a large quantity of goods there; I have not examined these goods, but I believe them to be mine.
NOT GUILTY .

1586.
HENRY CLARK
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 5 bobbins, value 3d.; 3oz. weight ofsilk, value 6s., and 6oz. weight of worsted, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Morris
, his master .

JAMES CHAMBERLAIN
. I am a constable, and was placed outside Mr. Morris' shop, by his order, on the 7th of July, to stop the prisoner when he came out, which I did, just about one o'clock; I said he must not go, as I suspected he had some property belonging to his master about him; I took off his hat, and in it I found this worsted; I then proceeded to put my hand in his pocket, and took out this bobbin of silk - he staggered across from one side to the other, and said it was his first offence, and he did it for want; I told him he made his case worse - I then took him to Covent-garden watch-house; he said he hoped his master would forgive him - it was the first time.

WILLIAM MORRIS
. I gave directions to the witness to do what he has done; I heard the prisoner say it was his first offence, and he hoped I would forgive him; this property is worth about 6s.; I then caused a search to be made at his lodgings; I had property of this description on my premises.

Cross-examined by Mr. CURWOOD. Q. How long had he worked for you? A. Eight years and a half - I would wish to speak on his behalf, in consideration of his wife, who is pregnant, and has five children.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1587.
RICHARD PARKIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 36 silver spoons, value 26l., and 24 silver forks, value 24l. , the goods of
John Turner
and
Charles Turner
.
Mr. BRODRICK conducted the prosecution.

JOHN TURNER. I am a silversmith
, and live in New Bond-street
. I am in partnership with my brother, Charles Turner; the prisoner was our apprentice three or four years; he left us nearly four years since - he had not served his time out. On the 17th of July a letter was received, which was handed to me on the 18th - this is it; there was then the other half-sheet containing a direction; I gave direction to Vogler, my shopman, to get the order done immediately, according to this letter; I think the value of the articles sent was about 49l.

EDWARD VOGLER
. I am shopman to Messrs. Turner. In July last I put up three dozen silver spoons, and two dozen forks - they were all the fiddle-pattern, and worth about 50l.; I gave them to William Simmons, to be taken to Mr. Buck's, No. 13, Cumberland-street, who has been a customer of my masters' many years; I was at Messrs. Turners' at the time the prisoner was an apprentice there, and I know his hand-writing; I believe this letter to be his writing, but it did not strike me then, as I had it not long in my hands before the order was executed; I think I destroyed the other part of it, and put this part on the file.

Cross-examined by Mr. ANDREWS. Q. Why did you destroy the other part? A. It is customary in our business; the other part had contained the direction, "Messrs. T. and C. Turner, No. 58 and 59, New Bond-street, London; by favour of Capt. Montgomery;" it came by the two-penny post; this is the prisoner's hand-writing - I have no hesitation in swearing it.
COURT. Q. Are you sure it came by the post, and had Capt. Montgomery's name on it too? A. Yes; it had his name on the fore-part, immediately over the direction, and yet came by the post. (read.)

Mr.
George Buck
will thank Messrs. Turners' to let him have the undermentioned articles:- twelve silver tablespoons, twelve forks, twelve dessert-spoons, twelve forks, and twelve tea-spoons, all of the fiddle pattern; they must be positively left at Mr. B's. house, in Cumberland-street, on Monday the 17th, as Capt. Montgomery will call there on his return to Hampton.

Another letter came on the 8th of August, which, I believe, to be the prisoner's writing, but there was something in it which excited my attention, there is one word mis-spelt in it, the word has instead of as; I went to get directions in consequence of the suspicion I entertained, and I went to the office and to Mr. Buck's house; this is the letter(read)

Mr. G. Buck's compliments to Messrs. Turner, and informs them, the plate gave every satisfaction - has Mr. B. wishes to make the set more complete, he will thank Messrs. Turner to let him have six more of each, (except the teaspoons) and a soup ladle.

WILLIAM SIMMONS
. I am porter to Messrs. Turner. On the 18th of last July I received a parcel, which I conveyed to the house of Mr. Buck, in Cumberland-street, and gave it to Elizabeth Fry; it was the same parcel I received from Mr. Vogler.

ELIZABETH FRY
. I am servant to Mr. George Buck. I was taking care of his house, in Cumberland-street, Mary-le-bone; Simmons brought a parcel on the 18th of July, about two o'clock - the prisoner had called before that morning, and said his name was Captain Montgomery; that he was going to Glass Hayes, and Mr. Buck had ordered a parcel which he would send his servant for, as he was going to Lindhurst the next morning by the stage; he came himself again, about five o'clock, and asked me for the parcel - I fetched the same parcel and gave it him in the same state I received it; he said it was a large parcel, he understood it was to be small - I asked if I should send it - he said No, he had only to go into Park-street - I gave him two letters beside - he called again on Tuesday, the 8th of August, but a person had called before that to tell me what course to take when he came - he asked if there was not a parcel to go to Lindhurst - I said there was, and my fellow-servant had got it - I gave information, and he was taken by Whitear.

GEORGE AVIS
. I am a constable of Marlborough-street.
