The prisoner was brought to the office, and when I was about to search him, he delivered to me one duplicate first; I left him, and then returned and ask where the others were - he said he had thrown them down the gutter coming along - I went to inquire, and then I came back, and said, I was come to search him all over; he then gave me six other duplicates, which he said were all he had belonging to Messrs. Turners' property; I asked him how he came to do it; he said it was through distress; I searched him, but found nothing further on him - I went to the different pawnbrokers.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am shopman to
Daniel Budden
, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned twelve table-spoons with me for 5l., on the 18th of July - he came on the 8thof August, and took six of them away; the other six were left for 2l. 10s.

WILLIAM BRADFORD
. I am shopman to Mr. Baylis. I gave four of the duplicates produced to the person who pawned the articles, but I cannot say that the prisoner is the man; they were all pawned on the 21st of July, six dessert spoons, six silver forks, six tea-spoons, six table forks, and six dessert forks.

JOSEPH BURGESS
. I am shopman to Mr. Purse, pawnbroker. I gave this duplicate to the prisoner on the 24th of July, when he pawned six table forks and six dessert spoons for 6l. 10s.; he said they were his own - he had redeemed them a few days before from a house in the neighbourhood.

JOHN HUGHES
. I am shopman to Mr. Dobree, a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned a pair of diamond earrings with me, and then six dessert spoons and six forks on the 27th of July; he called on the 3d of August, and we advanced another 1l. on them; I am certain he is the man; I have had previous transactions with him.

EDWARD TURNER
. I believe this to be the property I sent; it tallies in number and appearance.

Mr. TURNER. After the prisoner was taken into custody, I believe this letter came to our house; I was at Brighton, and it did not come to my hands for three weeks afterwards; I have a brother, but I do not know that he made any promise of favour to this young man; I have no reason to believe it; my brother was the person examined before the Magistrate; I believe these to be my property, but I cannot swear to them; the same workman that made these spoons works for other shops I believe.
Mr. VOGLER. This letter came in the evening, immediately after the prisoner was taken (reads.)
My Dear Sir, - Starvation compelled me to commit the crime; pray see me before you proceed to extremities.
Your unfortunate servant, R. PARKIN.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Judgment Respited .

1588.
JEMIMA PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 2 gowns, value 2s.; 1 pelisse, value 2s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 1s., and six 10l. promissory notes , the property of
George Wyman
.
MR. ANDREWS conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE WYMAN. I live at Coddicot, in Hertfordshire
. The prisoner was in my service, and left me abruptly on the 14th of July - I had gone to bed the night before, about ten o'clock - I had in my bureau in my bed-room six 10l. notes; the bureau was locked, and the key was in my waistcoat pocket; I had not locked my bed-room door, but the prisoner could come from her room to mine, as she slept in an adjoining chamber - I missed the key on the 13th, and on the morning after the prisoner was gone I found that the bureau had been opened, and the notes taken - I have known her from a child; I sent to London in pursuit of her.

GENT HUDDLESTON
. I am a tobacconist, and live at St. Pancras. I hired the prisoner, as my servant , on Saturday the 15th of July, without a character; she afterwards shewed me six 10l. notes of the Hertfordshire Bank; she said her father and mother were recently dead, and that shortly before her mother died, she called her to her bedside, and said, "My dear Jemima, these are all I have to give you." I got the notes exchanged for her, and shortly afterwards, Mr. Wyman, jun. came to my house, and she was taken into custody; I saw her box searched, and several articles of wearing apparel were claimed by him.

JOHN WYMAN, JUN.
By my father's direction I came to London to find the prisoner - I asked her, if she had not some property of my father's, and some wearing apparel? - she said, she had; her master had got the money, and she had the clothes in her box; I had a constable with me; we went up to her room, and she pointed out her box; I found the clothes there; she said, she took them at different times, and did not know what possessed her; she wanted to get away from the place - she said, when my father went to bed, about half-past eight o'clock at night, and she found he was snoring, she picked the key out of his waistcoat pocket, and the day before she left, she went up stairs, at twelve o'clock, opened the bureau, and took 60l. - she has no mother nor father - she has only an aunt and an uncle, to my knowledge.

PETER STAFFORD
. I am a clerk in the Banking-house of Masterman and Co. Mr. Huddleston exchanged six 10l. Hertford notes at our house, on the 5th of August; he had five 10l. notes for them.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Transported for Seven Year .

1589.
WILLIAM EVANS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Jacques Louis
, from his person .

JACQUES LOUIS. On the 22d of August, between eleven and twelve o'clock at night, I was coming out of Exeter-Change
- Mr. Cross was with me; I did not feel any thing done, but a witness came and asked if I had lost any thing - I felt in my pocket, and missed my handkerchief.

HENRY RICHARDSON
. I am a watchman. I saw the prisoner and three others go behind Mr. Louis, and the prisoner take the handkerchief from his pocket; I did not know him before, but I had a perfect view of his person; Mr. Louis turned round with a person, named Tyler, and said, "I have lost my handkerchief" - Mr. Tyler seized the prisoner - the other three then disappeared; they had been near enough to have taken the handkerchief from him; it has not been found.
Prisoner. Every word he says is false; the other gentleman took me first, and then he came, and said I was the man.

GEORGE JAMES JENNINGS
. I am an officer; I knew the prisoner, and took him into custody directly.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Transported for Seven Years .

1590.
MARY WARNER
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM WALPOLE
. I am a publican , and live at Enfield-highway
. The prisoner was in my service, and received money for me from time to time; she never paid me any money for Mrs. Jeaps or Mrs. Lawrence, on the 21st of June ; when she took out beer at noon or at night, and received money; she was to bring it home immediately.

ELIZABETH JEAPS
. I am in the service of Dr. Smart,at Enfield; I paid the prisoner for Mr. Walpole, on the evening of the 21st of June, for beer, 5 1/2d.

ELIZA LAWRENCE
. I am in the service of Mr. Hobbs. I paid the prisoner, on the 21st of June, for Mr. Walpole, 4s. 2d. in halfpence; she gave me this receipt.

WILLIAM WALPOLE
. I went out with some beer, and took this bill of 4s. 2d. to Mr. Hobbs, which Eliza Lawrence paid to the prisoner, and she gave a receipt for it.

JOHN WILSON
. I took the prisoner on the 26th of June; she said she took the money, because her master owed it her.
WILLIAM WALPOLE. I did not owe her a farthing she was in debt to me; and she then absconded.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1591.
WILLIAM MARLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of September , 5 trusses of clover hay, value 15s. , the goods of
James Ball
.

JAMES BALL. I live at Irongate Wharf, Paddington
, and am a hay salesman . On the night of the 4th of September, I was going home at a quarter past nine o'clock, and looking round my premises I saw the large shed-door moving; I cried out, "Who is there?" I got no answer - I called to my daughter, and she brought a light; we saw the prisoner standing at the door, and pulling this truss out of the shed; he had come up with the boats of hay that day, but he was not in my employ, and had no right to take my hay; we found five trusses of hay ready for taking away - he said he was going to stop there, because his boat leaked.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you never given leave to any persons to sleep there? A. Yes, at haymaking time, but not lately - there was no young woman with him upon the hay; and I had given no one leave to sleep there; I fastened the shed myself, bolted, and pinned it.

ELIZA BALL
. My father called for a light; I saw the prisoner, and knew him directly; I saw by his hat that he had been carrying hay, and told him so; he said, "No, I have done no such thing" - we found one truss inside the shed, and five trusses outside the door.
Cross-examined. Q. Then this young man spoke to you, and you to him? A. Yes, my father took hold of him; he could not run.

FRANCIS BRADBURY
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner; I found nothing on him but some money; he said, that Mr. Ball could not swear he took them out.
NOT GUILTY .

1592.
WINIFRED HAYLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of June , 1 pair of boots, value 6s. , the goods of
Henry Reeve
.

HENRY REEVE. I am a boot and shoe-maker , and live in Fetter-lane
. On the 20th of June I was entering my shop, and saw the prisoner there; the shopman was serving her with a pair of shoes; I saw her look at him with a watchful eye, and take a pair of lace boots from a rail at the end of the counter; she wrapped them up very carefully, and put them under her shawl; I seized her directly - walking towards the shopman.

Prisoner's Defence. I took them up, and was going to put them down again on the counter - he took hold of me, and said all my country people were going to steal things; I said, I was not going to steal them, I was going to speak to the shopman.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Recommended to Mercy by Prosecutor, believing her in distress.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .

1593.
MARY GRIFFITHS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 cap, value 5s. , the goods of
Joseph Goodwin
.

MARTHA GOODWIN
. I am the wife of Joseph Goodwin- we live in Cow-cross-street, Smithfield
, and keep a grocer's shop . On the 8th of September this cap was safe when the prisoner came into my shop to offer me a large baking dish to sell; I told her I did not want it; she pressed hard for me to buy it, and put it on the counter; I laid the cap down, she took it up, and said "Very well, it is of no use to buy if you don't want it;" she went out; I ran after her - she was taken, but had not the cap then.

BENJAMIN PHILLIPS
. I am a constable. I saw the prisoner come out of the shop with the dish in her hand; she walked at a quick pace; the prosecutor came out, and called "Stop that woman" - she turned into a lane; I pursued and took her - she had several persons round her, who said "Go the watch-house" - no cap was found on her.

JURY. Q. Were you the first person who took her? A. Yes; she said I might search her, but I should find no cap on her, but she was in a crowd, and, to the best of my belief, it had been given to another person.
NOT GUILTY .

1594.
WILLIAM GRAHAM
and
WILLIAM SCOWN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 1 coat, value 2l., and 1 waistcoat, value 10s., the goods of
George Richards
, and 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 1l., and 1 handkerchief, value 2s. , the goods of
John Percy
.

ANN RICHARDS
. I am the wife of George Richards - he lives at Chiswick
. Scown was our apprentice ; I left home on the 24th of August, leaving him at home with my child; I desired him to look after the house; I returned about half-past eight o'clock; I found the house all safe; I went up stairs, and found an earthen plate on the bed- four boxes had been broken open, and a coat and waistcoat missing from them, which were the property of my husband, and from the box of John Percy, a lodger, a pair of small clothes, a silk handkerchief, and a waistcoat were taken; Graham had worked on the premises before, but he had nothing to do there then.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not Scown work for a bricklayer? A. Yes; he did at first - my husband was in distress; Scown did not wish to go home; I kept him with some money I received, which my husband had worked for; my husband is now in Whitecross-street- Scown might have had work if he would.(Property produced and sworn to).
JOHN PERCY. I lodge at Mr. Richards'. I had my property safe in my box at nine o'clock in the morning, and when I came back at night I heard it was gone.
Cross-examined. Q. Had Scown the means of support? A. He always had plenty while I was there - he has asgood clothes at home as you have - these articles are mine.

WILLIAM HENRY HALLETT
. I am a constable, of Hammersmith. Percy came to me, and I went and apprehended Scown - I told him it was for some clothes - he denied it; I took him before the Justice the following day, and he said Graham had done it; I took Graham on the evening of the 25th, and on the 27th Graham said he had pawned them; I asked where the duplicates were - he said under a tree in Lord Holland's park, at Kensington.

EDWARD EDGSON
. I apprehended Graham on the 25th- when he got to the cage the officer asked him if the articles were pawned or not; he said they were in pawn, and the duplicates were at Kensington; he did not make him any promise in my hearing.

GEORGE KING
. I am a pawnbroker. These articles were pawned with me by Graham; I am quite certain of his person.

ROBERT SEWERS
. I am a pawnbroker. Graham pawned this waistcoat and pair of breeches with me.

GRAHAM -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

SCOWN -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1595.
RICHARD FARNSBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 7lbs. of lamb, value 5s., and 1 iron hoop, value 2d. , the goods of
William Dix
.

WILLIAM DIX. I am a butcher , and live at Limehouse
. On the 18th of July I fell asleep in my counting-house; this quarter of lamb, and the hook were taken; I had not missed them till the officer brought the prisoner back.

THOMAS GRAY
. I am an officer. About five o'clock on the evening of the 18th of July I was in the New-road - I met the prisoner with a quarter of lamb under his arm, and a hook hanging to it; I asked where he got it - he said, from one Thomas Day, at Bow; he had some conversation with Marsden, and we went to Mr. Dix's.

ROBERT MARSDEN
. I was with Gray - the prisoner at first said he had it from a butcher, at Bow; I said I would walk till morning, but I would find where it came from; he then said he had it from Limehouse, and he took it through distress.
GUILTY . Aged 33.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1596.
GEORGE FORD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 1 watch, value 20s. , the goods of
Sara Luckuch
.

The watch being the property of
Saving Luckuch
, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .

1597.
HANNAH DRISCOLL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 6 half-crowns, value 15s. , the monies of
Thomas Platt
.

THOMAS PLATT. I live with my mother,
Ann Platt
; she is a victualler, and lives in Covent Garden
; the prisoner was her servant . On the 28th of July, about twelve o'clock, I missed six half-crowns, which I had seen safe in a bag three days before - I sent for an officer, and we at last found them between the mattress and the sacking of a bed, in which a lodger used to sleep - the prisoner was making it at that time; they were tied up in a bit of rag; as we went to the office, she said if I would forgive her she would tell the truth; I said I could not.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner; on the way to Bow-street I heard her say to her master, if he would forgive her, she would tell the whole truth; she afterwards said at the office that she had taken them, and if he would forgive her, she would tell the whole truth - as we were going along she said if I would intercede with Mr. Platt she knew he would forgive her.
THOMAS PLATT. All the half-crowns were found, but I had lost some more money in shillings - they were all dated 1825 - the drawer was locked, and I kept the key always in my possession.
Prisoner's Defence. Mr. Morgan found the money under Mr. Platt's brother's bed.
NOT GUILTY .

1598.
HANNAH DRISCOLL
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 1 sheet, value 4s., the goods of
Ann Platt
, her mistress .
THOMAS PLATT. I am the son of Ann Platt. I know this sheet to be my mother's - it is marked A. P., and is of the same quality and appearance.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. In searching her box I found this ticket.

CHARLES NEWMAN
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker, in Drury-lane. I produce the sheet, but I did not take it in.
WILLIAM MORGAN. When I found the duplicate; she said her father had given it to her, and she had pawned it - she said a woman at Lisson-grove gave it to her afterwards.
NOT GUILTY .

1599.
MARY DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , 1 jacket, value 15s. , the goods of
William Thompson
.

WILLIAM THOMPSON. Between twelve and one o'clock on the morning of the 2d of September, I was coming from Tower-hill; I met a woman, who asked me to go home with her; I said, I would, provided she would behave well to me, being a stranger; I went home with her, and gave her a shilling to get some liquor - she went down stairs, and never returned - that was not the prisoner; I pulled off my jacket and put it beside the bed, and laid down to see if any body came - a little while afterward, the prisoner came, and said, "Young man, you can't stop here, my husband and two children are coming to sleep here;" I got up, and said, "Where is my jacket;" she d - d me, and said what did she know about it, but she would take me to the girl who brought me there; I followed her to many holes and corners - she tried to trip up my heels, and got from me, and ran in doors - I sung out for the watchman; he came, but could not find her not the jacket; I cannot tell how long I laid on the bed; I suppose not more than a quarter of an hour; I laid dozing there; I was a little in liquor; I saw some person come into the room, but did not get up to see who it was.

JOSEPH HALL
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned this jacket with me on the morning of the 2d of September.

JAMES LEA
. I am the officer. The prosecutor applied to me; I knew the prisoner by his description; I went with him to the pawnbroker's, and found the jacket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I found it behind some chairs in my room; I had not seen him then.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

1500;
JOSEPH DICKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August
, 9 napkins, value 4s.; 5 towels, value 2s.; 2 jackets, value 6s.; and 4 aprons, value 4s. , the goods of
William Colley
, and
ELIZABETH COSTELLOW
was indicted for
feloniously receiving part of the same goods, well knowing them to have been stolen .

ANN COLLEY
. I am the wife of William Colley; and am a laundress. On the 24th of August, I had these articles to wash, and I missed them that day; I had left them safe the night before, when I went to bed, in my wash-house; I fastened the windows and doors; I did not see that any violence had been done; I suppose they got in at the wash-house window, which was wide open; there was a square of glass out.

SARAH LONGLEY
. I am the wife of
Abraham Longley
, and live in Tothill-street; I deal in old linen articles. On the 24th or 25th of August, Elizabeth Costellow brought some towels, and two coarse aprons, which I bought of her; it is called huckaback; there were two letters on them, but I cannot say what; I sold them again - she came again the same afternoon, and brought the articles which are here; Mr. Pace came on the 30th of August and claimed them.
Prisoner COSTELLOW. Q. Did you not say you bought them of a person called Carrotty? A. That is you.

WILLIAM RICHARDSON
. I was on duty in Vauxhall-road, on the 24th of August, about half-past four o'clock in the morning, and I saw Dickinson and another man coming up Belvoir-terrace, towards Pimlico; they made off at the back of Belvoir-terrace, and I saw them turn their heads frequently; I thought there was something wrong, and I made up to them, and overtook them; I asked them what was the matter; they said, Nothing - they had been at the Cobourg, and staid drinking all night; I did not detain them; it was directly opposite Mr. Colley's place that I first saw them.

THOMAS PACE
. From the information I received I suspected Dickinson to be concerned in the robbery, and I went to the back of a house in Duck-lane, Westminster; I found Costellow standing at the door with another woman; I went into the back part of the house, and found Dickinson in bed; I said to him, "What is your name?" he said, "Pace; you know my name very well;" I said,"Get up," which he did, and under the bed I found this chissel, and these three centre-bits in a cupboard by the fire-place; I took him to the office, and took the female the same day, when she came to inquire about him; they had been living together. I sent Mrs. Colley to Mrs. Longley's - before I got there she hung up the jacket; and I went and said, "Who did you buy this of?" she said,"Of a woman, in the family way, named Carrotty Bet - you know her very well."
MRS. COLLEY. I lost some huckaback towels and aprons which were marked.(Property produced and sworn to.)

DICKINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

COSTELLOW -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1601.
JAMES DONOVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 1 tin-cap, value 6d; 24 penny-pieces, value 2s., and 72 halfpence , the property of
Martha Morgan
, widow .

MARTHA MORGAN. I am a widow. I had 5s. in copper money, which I left with my pails in Upper Gower-street
, about a quarter before three o'clock in the afternoon of the 14th of July; I went to serve two customers further on, and when I came back the can and money were gone.

DANIEL REARDON
. I was in Bainbridge-street, St. Giles' about a quarter past three o'clock on the 14th of July - I saw the prisoner, with three others; I saw he had something under his coat; he ran, and I ran after him - he dropped this can, and some of the halfpence fell out; he told me his mother was a milk-woman, and he had been selling milk all day. There was 4s. 11 1/2d. in it.(Can produced and sworn to).
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged .

1602.
JOHN CROCKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 1 pair of shoes, value 1s. 6d., and 2 pairs of boots, value 2s. 4d. , the goods of
Sarah Bavis
, widow .

SARAH BAVIS. I keep a shop in Paul-street
. On the 15th of July, between two and three o'clock, I saw the prisoner standing at my shop door while I was in the yard- I ran up to him, and he asked if I had got any peppermint drops; I said I believed I had - I turned, and he ran off; I pursued him, but lost sight of him; a young man pursued, and brought him back in a few minutes; I went back, locked my door, and went to Willow-street, where I met the young man coming back with the shoes and the prisoner - these are them; they were missing. I sell shoes.

JOHN WHITE
. I heard a call of Stop thief! I ran down Willow-court, and took the prisoner; the moment I took him I saw the shoes laying by his side - he said "It is not me."

SAMUEL BRIDGES
. I am the officer. I came up, and took the prisoner and the shoes to the office.
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Fined One Shilling, and Discharged .

1603.
JAMES CANE
was indicted for
feloniously cutting and destroying, on the 7th of July , 3 cones of silk, in a certain loom belonging to
Samuel Gravenor
, his master .

SAMUEL GRAVENOR. I live in Wood-street, Spitalfields
, and am a weaver . The prisoner was my apprentice - I have complained of his conduct several times to the Magistrate, and he had been in the House of Correction previous to July last; he had a cone, in a loom of mine, on the 7th of July, and on that morning Jemima Margon came to my bed-room door, and gave me information; I went to the prisoner's house, and found the silk that was in the loom, was entirely cut; he had taken the rods out, and taken it out of the harness, so that the cross was lost - it was cut besides; on the following Wednesday morning he came home, and I charged him with it - he made no reply; I then asked what he had done with the things he took away; he said some he had lost, and some he had pawned.

JOHN VINCENT
. I am apprentice to Mr. Gravenor. As I was getting up on the 1st of July, the prisoner said,"Will you go to Fairlop-fair?" I said I had no money; he said, "I will go, and before I go, I will cut my b - y work out;" I went down, and when I came up again, he had a knife in his hand; he first cut two inches of it, and then he looked round and cut the whole of it; he said, "I must go, I have done it."

JEMIMA MARGON
. On the 5th of July I met the prisoner in Brick-lane; he asked if I should go to the fair - I said, No - he said he should go, and before he went he should cut his work out of the loom; he said it was bad, and troubled him; on the Wednesday following he came home, while I was at work, and I asked him if he was not sorry for what he had done; he said No, and for two pins he would cut all the work out, and then he should only have three months imprisonment, and get away from his master.

ROBERT DAVIS
. I took charge of the prisoner - I asked if he had cut his work in the loom - he said, "Yes, because it went so bad."

Prisoner. I have always done my best towards my master - and when I had bad silk I was always taken before the Magistrate - and he said I was lazy when I could not do my task of work - it was very bad indeed.
SAMUEL GRAVENOR. It was the best silk I could get, but he was always altering it, and therefore it was disabled from working as it should do, he was so fickle minded.

Prisoner to JOHN VINCENT. Q. Did not you know that I could not get on with the work? A. You said so several times - it was a new harness and not quite settled - if he had made three quarters of a yard, it would have done very well.
JEMIMA MARGON. I know he complained of his work, and I went with the boy to look at it - it appeared to be bad.

SAMUEL GRAVENOR re-examined. Q. Supposing the work to have been wrong, could it have been put to any use? A. Yes - it could have been made in another loom; the harness was new, and every thing in a complete state; the value of the silk, spoiled, is about 8l.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Twelve Months .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1604.
WILLIAM BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of June , 2 baskets, value 5s., and 21 loaves of bread, value 12s. , the goods of
James Rutland
.

DAVID JOHNSTON
. I am journeyman to Mr. James Rutland, of Old Burlington-street. I was out on the 26th of June, and left my two baskets in Bond-street
, I was absent about twenty minutes serving customers, and when I returned the two baskets, and 21 loaves were gone - I found the prisoner with one basket, in St. Giles'.

JOHN MENELAUS
. I am a journeyman baker. I met the prisoner in St. Giles', between one and two o'clock on the 26th of June, he was selling this bread, and taking the money for it - I had seen Johnston - I asked the prisoner where he came from - he said he came there every day - I looked into his basket, and compared the bread with a loaf Johnston had given me - it corresponded exactly; I took him to the master's.
Cross-examined by Mr. ALLEY. Q. Did not he tell you a person of the name of Flood gave it him to carry? A. No.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am an officer - I took the prisoner, and produce the basket, which he had; I have 4s. 10d., which he said was the produce of the bread he had sold.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not he tell you a man named Flood gave it him to carry? A. He said a man gave it him - he mentioned no name.(Basket produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had never been in London before - I am a baker, and I met a young man who employed me to carry his basket, which I had done two or three mornings.
NOT GUILTY .

1606.
MARY LEARY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of July , 1 gown, value 5s. , the goods of
Joseph Harris
.

ANN BUNN
. My husband is horse-keeper to Mr. Biggins, of Swan-yard, Westminster. On the 18th of July I was passing Mr. Harris, the pawnbroker , in Tothill-street, Westminster
- I saw the prisoner open his door; I went home to my own house; the prisoner followed me into my own room; she asked me for King's-head-court - I said, I did not know it; she then pulled this gown from under her apron, and said, she had bought it for four shillings - she wanted to sit down; I told her I was going out; she went away, and I went out - I had never seen her before - she appeared much agitated, and I went and told Mr. Harris; his young man followed and took her; he took the gown from her left hand.

JOHN ROBINSON JACKSON
. I am in the employ of Mr. Joseph Harris; I went with the witness after the prisoner; I took her in Broad-way, Westminster, and said, she had a gown belonging to Mr. Harris; she said, she had not; I took it from her left hand - I had hung it on the doorpost myself.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked up the gown, and inquired if any one about knew who it belonged to.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined One Month .

1607.
JOHN PRUDON
and
THOMAS COX
were indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of August , 1 watch, value 10s., the goods of
Joseph William Yeates
, from his person .

JOSEPH WILLIAM YEATES. I am a cutler , and live on Lambeth-hill, Doctors'-commons. On the 2d of August, about nine o'clock in the evening, I was on Clerkenwell-green, going to my club; I saw Prudon, who stooped and picked up, or pretended to pick up, a shilling; he asked if it was mine; I said, No - I had only two half-crowns to pay my club money - he then asked me to have something to drink, and we went into the General Graham public-house
, and sat down on a settle facing the bar; Cox was there when we went in; Prudon sat down by me, and asked, if any body in the room had got a bit of tobacco for his tooth; one, who I believe, was Cox, said, here is some; handing him a box - he then went out, and Prudon openedthe box, and there was a sixpence upon the tobacco; he took it out, and put in a farthing - the one who lent him the box came in again - Prudon gave him the box; he shook it to his left ear, and said, "D - n it, you have acted honestly - you have left my money as you found it;" they talked a bit, and then Prudon offered to bet a crown that it did not contain the same money as when he received it, and asked if I would be half of it; I said, I would not - I did not like to lay wagers - I then took out my watch and gave it to the pot-boy, to take care of, because I thought I was in bad company - I do not know whether he gave it to his mistress, but he walked towards the counter - I did not go out, because I saw a party of about a dozen round the door, who are in the outer court now - I was on the settle facing the bar, and could see the door; the mistress said to the boy, "Give the watch back to the person who gave it you, I will have nothing to do with it;" he brought it back to me - I was putting it into my pocket when Prudon snatched it from me and gave it to Cox, to the best of my knowledge; and Cox ran to the street-door; I got off the settle, followed and collared him; another man came behind, collared me and pulled me backwards; by that means they both got clear off - I have heard the other man was Prudon - on the Monday following I went to the same house with a watchman and officer - I found Prudon there, dancing with two girls of the town; Cox was taken on the 10th of September.

GEORGE MIDDLEMASS
. I am pot-boy at this house. I remember the prisoners being there - they generally come into the house of an evening to drink - I saw Cox first - they were with Mr. Yeates - I do not know who came in first - I did not hear the betting going on, but Yeates gave me the watch to hold - he did not tell me to do any thing with it - my mistress was busy at the bar and knew nothing of it - I did not speak to her about the watch, but I gave it back, because she called me, as she wanted me; I gave it to Yeates, and said I would have nothing to do with it - my master and mistress had always told me to have nothing to do with things in the tap-room - I then went and sat down on a seat, and soon afterwards there was a bustle to the door - I rather think the prisoners were there - the prosecutor did not complain that he had lost his watch till after all was done, and he came in - Cox came in afterwards in a disguise with a smock-frock on - he had before a blue coat on and was very clean - Yeates did not give me the watch to take to my mistress - I do not know that any of the persons about were bad characters - there was a rush to the door.
COURT. Q. Had Cox a smock-frock on at first? A. No. I have known him in the tap-room before, and in company with Prudon.

CHARLOTTE SPARKHALL
. I assist my cousin in the bar at the General Graham public-house. I saw the prosecutor and Prudon come in and call for a pint of beer, which I drew - an oyster man then came in; I thought I heard them quarrelling, and I called the boy to come away - I have been there two years, and have seen the prisoners there frequently; there were more than a dozen in the tap-room; I did not hear of the watch being stolen till after they were all gone; I saw Cox rush to the door; some one collared him, but I do not know who; I called out that there was going to be a row, I would send for an officer and clear the house.

MATTHEW FOY
. I am a watchman of Castle Baynard Ward. Yeates told me, on the Sunday, that he had lost his watch - he described the persons - I said I thought I knew them; I went with the night constable to several houses till we got to the General Graham, where we found Prudon; we took him to the lock-up place, and told him what it was for; he denied all knowledge of the prosecutor or of the transaction; the watch was delivered to the prosecutor at the door of the Distillers' Arms public-house, Saffron-hill; Prudon admitted before, the Magistrate, that he had the watch in his hand, but said he held it for a bet of 5s., and would not give it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

PRUDON'S Defence. When I returned the man his box, he said he had got his money all right; the prosecutor said he would lay 5s. he had not got it right; he then bethought himself that he had but 6d., but he had got a beautiful watch; and gave it to the pot-boy to hold; the mistress then called the boy away; he said to me "You hold it and if I win I will give you 6d. for it;" the man then opened the box, and there was another 6d. under the tobacco; the prosecutor lost the bet, and he would not give up the watch - the other man then snatched the watch and ran off.

COX'S Defence. I went to have some beer; I heard a row, and turned round and saw a mob - I heard the prosecutor say, "I will lay my watch against 5s.;" he put the watch into the pot-boy's hand, and the landlady called"John, come away, have nothing to do with it;" I did not stop to see the remainder of the business - I drank my beer and came away.

ROBERT CHANDLER
. I am a chimney-sweeper, and live at No. 5, Silver-street, Clerkenwell. I was at the General Graham on this night; I saw Prudon and the prosecutor come in and ask for a pint of porter; Prudon asked the prosecutor to give him a bit of tobacco - he said he had not got any - then another person lent him a bit, and went out, and the prosecutor took the box and played some trick with it - Prudon gave it back to the man - and after a little while the prosecutor told him he had not got what ought to be in the box; the man rattled it and said he was sure it was all right; the prosecutor said he would lay him a wager of it - that he had got no money, but had got a good watch, and would lay that against 5s.; the watch was put into the boy's hand; the housekeeper would not let him hold the stakes; he then asked Prudon to hold it, and he would give him 6d. if he won - Prudon took it to hold; the box was then opened; I did not see what was in it, but directly the prosecutor ran out to get an officer; the others remained there drinking their porter.
COURT. Q. Who was at the door? A. There were some persons there; I was drinking with Rose; there were a great many people at the door; I have known Prudon four years, he is quite a good sort of man.

Q. Did the prosecutor complain of losing his watch. A. He ran out after the man who won the watch - he said if he could see the man he would leave it at the bar for the money; I remember the pot-boy returning the watch, because the lady would not let him hold it; Prudon gave it to the man who won the wager; the prosecutor put it on the table, and then took it up and put it into Prudon's hand.

Q. Will you swear that Cox did not run off with the watch? A. I do not know Cox; I do not know whotook it; he gave the watch to the man who won it; and he went away almost immediately; he did not stop; there were other persons there; the man might stay a minute or two in the house; I cannot say who took the watch; he gave it to the man who won the wager.
Q. Will you swear it was not Cox? A. I cannot swear a thing I do not know.
CHARLOTTE SPARKHALL. My Lord, this witness was not in the tap-room, he was in the bar; he saw nothing at all of it.

PRUDON -
GUILTY . Aged 21.

COX -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

1608.
JOHN MACK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of August , 1 hat, value 7s.; the goods of
James Melville
, from his person .

JAMES MELVILLE. I am a carpenter . On the 13th of August I went to the Crooked Billet public-house, Wych-street, St. Clement's
, about half-past six o'clock in the morning, and remained there with a friend; we had a little porter. I got rather drowsy, and set my hat on the table, and went to sleep; when I awoke it was gone; I saw it again on the head of another person, on the 21st of August.

THOMAS JONES HICKS
. I am a porter. I called in at this house on the 13th of August; I put my hat on the table; the prisoner and another man came in; the prisoner wanted to drink with me, and we had another pot of porter; I had been very ill a long time; I put my head on the table, and soon afterwards I felt the prisoner's hand in my pocket; I told the landlord of it, and asked if he would suffer strangers to be robbed in his house; my hat was then gone; and I told the prisoner I would not go out without it; he then sent his companion into the parlour, and took Melville's hat, and put it on my head, and pushed it down; I do not know where they got the hat, but they turned me out altogether, and said, what did I want more - I went home.

OWEN MURRAY
. About half-past one o'clock, on Sunday, the 13th of August, the witness came into my house, and sat down on a seat facing the bar; the prisoner and some other person came in, and sat down in the box where he was; the prisoner sat on one side, and the friend on the other; they asked him to treat them, and they drank two pots of beer - Hicks then laid his hat on the table, and seemed to be dozing; he awoke in about five minutes, and said to me, "Landlord, I have lost my hat" - I came outside, and said, "If you have played any tricks with the man's hat, give it him, and don't have a piece of work on a Sunday about it" - the prisoner and his companion then went into the parlour, and brought out Melville's hat, and put it on Hicks's head; Hicks took it off, and said he would not have that; I thought Melville was then gone; I went into the bar, and was busy serving, when Hicks cried out, "Landlord, here is conduct; he has got his hand in my pocket" - I took the prisoner's hand out of Hicks's pocket, and said, "I will not let you be in the house any longer;" the prisoner and his companion used bad language, and I walked them out.

SAMUEL GILES
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner on Monday night, and afterwards found this hat on Hicks's head.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1609.
HENRY JONES
and
JOHN BROWN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 1 book, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Michael Gandy
, from the person of
Christopher Gandy
.

CHRISTOPHER GANDY. On the 19th of August, about one o'clock, I was in St. James's Park, near the Horse-Guards
; I had a spelling-book in my coat-pocket; I had just left school; the officers told me I had lost my book, and they would take me to the boys who stole it; I had not seen them near me.

THOMAS ROBERTS
. I was with Bertraun, and saw the two prisoners behind the prosecutor; I saw Jones take the book from his pocket; I went up, and took it from under Brown's coat, and gave it to Bertraun; Groom and Bertraun fetched the prosecutor, who owned the book; I had watched them for a quarter of an hour.

JOHN GROOM
. I am a street-keeper. I saw the prisoners close behind Gandy; I saw Jones take something from his pocket, and pass it to Brown - I went and took them; Bertraun brought Gandy, who owned the book.

ANGELIOUS BERTRAUN
. I was with the two officers. I saw the prisoners behind Gandy - I suspected they had taken something, and asked him; he said he had lost a book; I brought him back, and saw the book taken from Brown.(Property produced and sworn to.)
BROWN'S Defence. My fellow prisoner is quite innocent - I did it myself.
The prisoners received good characters.

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 19.

Recommended to Mercy -
Whipped and Discharged .

1610.
WILLIAM JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 watch-chain, value 14s.; 2 seals, value 25s.; 1 watch-key, value 7s., and 1 ring, value 5s., the goods of
Joseph Southwell
, from his person .

JOSEPH SOUTHWELL. I am a journeyman tailor , and lodge in Compton-street. I was in Leicester-square
on the 10th of September, about one o'clock in the morning; I had passed the evening at a public-house in Carnaby-market; two persons came up to me, and I thought they were the same trade as myself - one of them spoke, but I cannot tell what he said; I was the worse for liquor - we walked and talked together, and all at once one of them ran away; I put my hand to my pocket, and my watch was gone. I had it safe just before.

JOHN EVANS
. I am a watchman. I was on duty in St. James'-street, Haymarket - I heard the cry of Stop thief! and saw four or five persons pursuing the prisoner down Whitcomb-street; I took him round the street, and met the prosecutor, who appeared to have been drinking; he said he had lost his watch.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Was he sober enough to know what o'clock it was by his watch? A. Yes.

WILLIAM BOND
. I am a patrol. I was passing Leicester-square, and saw two persons running - the prosecutor said he had lost his watch, and the man before him had got it - I pursued him, and found him in the charge of the watchman. The watch was found in the street.
COURT to JOSEPH SOUTHWELL. Q. Do you persist in saying you do not know who took it from you? A. Yes.
NOT GUILTY .

1611.
THOMAS GINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 watch, value 20s., the goods of
George Birch
, from his person .

GEORGE BIRCH. I am a carpenter , and live in Bear-street, Clare-market. On Sunday, the 6th of August, about twelve o'clock in the day, I was turning out of Broad-street, St. Giles'
, into Drury-lane, and saw four or five persons there, together; one of them, who, to the best of my knowledge, was the prisoner, came and put his hand on my shoulder, and pulled out my watch, above my head- he ran away; I gave an alarm, and cried Stop thief! the prisoner was taken on the Wednesday, and, to the best of my belief, he is the man.

GEORGE JAMES JENNINGS
. I am a Bow-street patrol. From information I received from Griffiths, who has absconded, I took the prisoner.

JOHN BARBER
. I live in Drury-lane, and am a hatter. On the 6th of August, about twelve o'clock, I was in my shop - I heard a voice exclaiming, "Don't take the man's watch;" I went, and saw the prosecutor on the ground, and a man going across the road, up Vine-street, but I do not think it was the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

1612.
BENJAMIN CHATTERTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 4 sovereigns, 3 half-sovereigns, and 15 shillings, the goods of
Edward Parr
, from his person .

EDWARD PARR. I am a broker , and live in Harp-alley, Strand. On the 8th of August, about six o'clock in the evening, I was in a house which may be deemed a lodging-house; it is a private house, and has been mine for upwards of twenty years - I had lived there one night- there had been soldiers quartered there upwards of eleven years; I had recently come out of trouble, as I was convicted illegally; I went to my house, where I found the prisoner; I had known him before; I gave him a bottle, and he got some gin. I begged him to dine with me, which he did - there were four persons in the house. After dinner I laid down on the sofa, and fell asleep; I had four sovereigns, three half-sovereigns, and fifteen or sixteen shillings in my purse, in the left pocket of my small clothes; it appears I could not have slept two minutes before the house-keeper,
Mary Jenkins
, awoke me; the servant said to her, "Did so and so give you my master's money?" - I felt in my pocket, and my money was gone, and the prisoner also; he sat at my right hand, very near me, before.
COURT. Q. Are you sober now? A. Yes - I have taken nothing.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Where did you dine to day? A. I have had no dinner, upon my solemn oath; I may have drank some porter; I do not recollect taking only part of a pint.

ELIZABETH CHATTERTON
. I lived servant with Mr. Parr. I was hired by Mrs. Jenkins, the house-keeper - I have often seen the prisoner - he was an acquaintance of Parr's, and he knew Mrs. Jenkins; on the 8th of August, tween six and seven o'clock in the evening, Parr came home - the prisoner was there - they shook hands and Parr asked him to dine, which he did; Mr. Parr laid down on the sofa - I went into the kitchen, and when I returned, the prisoner was lying upon Parr, and his hand in his left trouser's pocket, and his waistcoat was unbuttoned; I said"What are you doing, Sir;" Nothing, said he, and he gave me a push with his arm, and put a brown purse into his pocket - he said, "I am in haste, I can't wait any longer;" I called the house-keeper, and said, "I will not move out of this place till you send for an officer;" the officer came, and I was searched; I did not know but what his roguishness might have said (as there were nobody in the room but him and me,) that I had taken it.

Cross-examined. Q. You would not for the world be in a house with a bad character? A. I am forced to do many things I do not like for a bit of bread; this is a lodging-house; I do not know whether they let lodgings for an hour.

ISAAC SAYER
. I am an officer. The housekeeper was accused of the robbery by Parr - she wished to be searched, and I searched her very strictly - she then informed me that Chatterton had gone off with the money; I went to his house and searched him, but found nothing.
NOT GUILTY .

1613.
JANE GRANT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 6 yards of printed cotton, value 6s.; 10 napkins, value 4s.; 5 music-books, value 5s.; 1 tea-caddy, value 3s., and 3 music-slates, value 2s., the goods of
George Francis
, her master .

MARTHA FRANCIS
. I am the wife of George Francis - he is a musician , and is now at Boulogne - we lived together till he went abroad; he has been gone a year and a half, and I have no expectation of seeing him again - he has engagements in France, which suit him better than being here; I have been married to him eleven years - I live at No. 16, Lisle-street, Leicester-square
- the prisoner was my cook eight or nine months; I had been absent from home for ten days or a fortnight previous to the 10th of August; I left her to sleep in my house; I found her there on my return; I received information from a person who works for me, and went with an officer to the corner of Cecil-court, Castle-street, on the 12th of August; I found the prisoner there in company with two or three persons, with whom she had gone to lodge; she had left me on the 11th by my request, but I had not missed any articles till I received information; I found this property there in a box which I knew to be her's; I had left two servants in the house; she said the tea-caddy was her's - I said I had such a one - the towels and the cotton I can positively speak to.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe there was a young lady, named
Eliza Johnson
, who lodged with you? A. Yes; she was in the habit of making her presents; she might have given her these things - the prisoner asked me to search her boxes when she left - herboxes were not locked - I could not say these things were taken dishonestly.
NOT GUILTY .

1614.
JACK COHEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 1 reticule, value 1s.; 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Elizabeth Jones
, from her person .

ELIZABETH JONES. I am single , and live in Brydges-street, Covent-garden. On the 8th of July, about seven o'clock in the evening, I went to Covent-garden to purchase some fruit; I was near King-street
; I had a basket and a reticule, which contained 2s. 6d. - I felt my basket going, and the reticule taken from it; I turned round, and saw the prisoner's hand on my basket - he dropped the reticule; I am quite sure he is the person; I picked it up - there was a lid on my basket, which he had lifted up; I said, "You thief! you have not got it;" he walked away, but was taken in about a quarter of hour; I said he was the person who took my reticule; I am sure his hand was on my basket.

CHARLES PLATT
. I am a cooper. I work for Mr. Day, in Wood-street, Crown-street; I saw the prosecutrix in the market with a basket - the prisoner was near her - I heard some money drop, and saw the prisoner walk away - she said he had taken her money; I went and told an officer, who was close to me - he was not out of my sight after the money was dropped - he is the person the lady pointed to.

WILLIAM MORGAN
. I am a Bow-street patrol. Platt pointed the prisoner out to me; he was fifty or sixty yards from where Mrs. Jones was - she never hesitated about him, but said he was the man; he did not say any thing; I found 4s. 6d. on him, which he said he was going to buy fruit with.
Three witnesses gave him a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

1615.
THOMAS LINTOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Edward Warner
, from his person .

EDWARD WARNER. I am a brass-worker . On Sunday, the 10th of September, about one o'clock in the day, a handkerchief was taken from my coat pocket; I did not feel it taken, but was told it was gone - I turned and pursued the prisoner, who was running about fifty paces from me; he was taken but not in my sight.

WILLIAM HOLLIDAY
. I am a writer. I was behind this gentleman, and saw the prisoner approach his pocket; he then left it put something under his coat, and ran away - a person behind the prosecutor stepped up to him, and said, "Sir, that lad has your pocket-handkerchief" - I ran round the new-church to meet the prisoner, and took him; but the handkerchief had been previously dropped; I did not see him drop it.
NOT GUILTY .

1616.
JOHN TILLYARD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of May , 2 saddles, value 10s.; 1 bridle, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of hames and traces, value 2s.; 1 breechin, value 2s.; and 1 crooper, value 2s. , the goods of
Francis Buckingham
.

JOSEPH HARLEMORE
. I am a harness-maker, and live in Edgware-road. The prisoner came to my shop on the 8th of May, about seven o'clock in the morning, with Biddle, who was tried here last Sessions; they brought some harness to my house; I was not at home at the time, and they took it to a neighbour's who detained it - it was then brought to my shop, and the officer told me to detain them when they came; I told them I must detain them, and the prisoner ran away; the other was taken - I am certain of the prisoner.

JOHN PINDER
. I am constable of Paddington. I was sent for on the 8th of May, to take two men on suspicion of stealing some harness; as I was going to Mr. Harlemore's shop, the prisoner passed me; Mr. Harlemore came out and gave me the other, and he said, "That is one gone past you;" I pursued but could not overtake him.

FRANCIS BUCKINGHAM. I live at Hendon, in Middlesex
. I lost some harness between the 7th and 8th of May; we missed it on the Monday morning from my stable, and I had seen it perhaps within two or three days; the prisoner had worked on my premises occasionally; his brother works for me now.

JAMES TOWER
. I am a constable of Hendon. I apprehended the prisoner on the 6th of September - I said, "You know I had a warrant against you for stealing harness from Mr. Buckingham, and why had you not got further out of the way;" I said, "I blame you for taking it of your brother's master, who has employed him so long;" he acknowledged to being a party to the robbery, and said, he was very sorry he should have done such a thing - I had not made him any promise or threat.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. The other went and stole it; he came and called me up between two and three o'clock in the morning, to go to town with him - he said, he had got some harness to sell - I went to Paddington.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .
SIXTH DAY. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 20.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1617.
MICHAEL COLLINS
and
HUGH HASTINGS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 sovereign, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Edward Rhind
, from his person .

EDWARD RHIND. On the evening of the 26th of August, I received one sovereign, three shillings, and a half-crown; I tied it in the corner of a towel and put it into my hat; I went to the Grapes public-house with an old shopmate, and he treated me - I then went towards home in Willow-street, Vauxhall; I was crossing near the Sanctuary
to avoid a coach; the two prisoners were walking near the Sanctuary - I ran against Collins; I turned round and begged his pardon; he muttered something - I said, "Don't be offended, I will stand a glass of gin to make all right;" I took off my hat to get a sixpence; Collins knocked it all out of my hand - I stooped and picked up three shillings and sixpence - Hastings took up a sovereign and a sixpence, and went away - I said to Collins, "Through your knocking that down, I have lost a sovereign and a sixpence" - he said, "D - n your eyes go after the man;" I took him to the watch-house, and they said, I must take him to Queen-square; when I got out, he ran away; I ran and caught him by the sword-belt; I took him to the office, but the Magisstrate discharged him.

DANIEL SULLIVAN
. I was with Rhind on the 26th of August between five and six o'clock - I saw a sovereign and some silver in his possession; he took off his hat, and drew a towel out; he placed the money in the corner of it, and put it on his head.

WILLIAM HALL
. I am a constable. On the 28th of August I was sent by the Magistrate to the Mews, to apprehend Hastings; I found fourpence on him.
HASTING'S Defence. The prosecutor himself searched me before I got from him; he found two shillings and threepence, which I said was mine, and he gave it me again.
RHIND. He ran away directly, I had not time to do it.

HASTINGS -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Two Months .

COLLINS -
NOT GUILTY .

1618.
THOMAS BARNET
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 2 shirts, value 7s., and 1 shift, value 3s. , the goods of
William Griffith
.
MR. QUIN conducted the prosecution.

MARY FOSTER
. I was in the service of William Griffith. On the 17th of July I hung out two lines of linen about two o'clock; at a quarter before three Groves brought two shirts and a shift to me - they are part of what I had hung out.

JOHN GROVES
. I live in Burton-crescent, Islington
, and have a view of Mr. Griffith's premises from my back window. I saw a person get over the railing from the drying-ground, with a parcel - he went under a shed, and then into a brick-field - I followed; I touched him on the arm, and said, "What have you got here?" he dropped the bundle and ran off; I cried, Stop thief! I cannot swear that the prisoner is the man; he took a kind of circuit round the field; I took up the articles, and took them to Mr. Griffith's.

EDWARD SHIRLEY
. I am a brick-maker, and work in Mr.
James Rhodes
' field, at Islington. I saw the prisoner, on the 17th of July, (I believe it was him) in the brickfield - he was running - somebody called Stop thief! but I do not know who it was; I do not know where the prisoner had been employed before that day.

Cross-examined. Q. How far were you from the person you think was the prisoner? A. Fifty or sixty, or a hundred yards; his back was towards me as he ran past me - I had never seen him before that I know of - I had an opportunity of seeing him for about half a minutes; I did not see him drop any thing.
COURT. Q. Do you know the person of the man? A. I believe it was the prisoner.
Q. Have you any doubt about it? A. No.
Q. Upon your oath, was it, or was it not, the prisoner? A. Yes, that is the man who ran by me - no one was running after him - I did not see Groves that day - not to be confident it was him.
Q. Upon your oath, did you see John Groves that day? A. No, Sir, not to be positive it was him; I saw nobody pursuing the prisoner; I do not know who cried Stop thief!

JAMES FOSTER
. On the 18th of July I was at Mr. Griffith's, waiting for my wife, and the groom came in and said, there was a person waiting about the back-ground - I went and took the prisoner; I asked how he came to take these shirts and the shift; he said he did not - but when I got him up to Mr. Griffith's stable, he owned it.
Cross-examined. Q. Was there any thing said before he owned it? A. I said it would go hard with him if he did not tell the truth.
NOT GUILTY .

1619.
CHARLES JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th June , 1 half-sovereign, 3 half-crowns, and 2 shillings, the monies of
James Webb
, from his person .

JAMES WEBB. I keep the Cock and Lion, public-house, in Wigmore-street
. On the 26th of June, the prisoner came to live with me as pot-boy - on the 30th I sent him with beer to Mrs. Robinson's - he came back, and said, "Master, does not Mrs. Robinson owe you for three pints of beer?" I said, "Yes;" he said, "If you will have the kindness to give her change for a sovereign, she will pay you;" I counted him out half-a-sovereign, three half-crowns, and 2s. 6d. in silver; he took it, but did not come back; I never saw him again till he was in the hands of the officer, on the 5th of July.

CATHERINE ROBINSON
. I live in Wigmore-street, and am a customer of Mr. Webb's. I told the prisoner on the 30th of June, that I would pay the bill, but he brought me no money.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am an officer, and apprehended the prisoner.

GUILTY. Aged 15. Of stealing only . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1620.
ELIZABETH DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of June , 2 sheets, value 5s.; 1 blanket, value 4s.; 1 bolster, value 3s., and 2 pillows, value 4s., the goods of
Samuel Mann
, in a lodging-room .

ANN MARIA MANN
. I am the wife of Samuel Mann - we live in Chapel-street, Somer's-town
. The prisoner has lodged with me about one year and a half, in the front-room, on the second-floor, and these articles were part of the furniture let with the room. On the 21st of June I missed these articles; there was an execution against her - and I went up stairs, and found the bed was stripped - before I got down she had run away.

JOSEPH PEWTNER
. I am a pawnbroker, and have a bolster and pillow, which have been in pawn twenty months - I do not know who brought them.

Prisoner's Defence. I did it through complete starvation - and when I had got a little work, I would have got them home; she said she never objected to lodgers pawning, if they made all good before they left.
MRS. MANN. I deny that.
GUILTY . Aged 32.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1621.
RICHARD HARRISON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 pair of shoes, value 5s., the goods of
Henry Bonham
, his master .

HENRY BONHAM. I am a shoemaker and live in Dean-street, Soho-square
- the prisoner was my shopman . On the 12th of July I did not give him authority to take aa pair of shoes, or to pawn them; these shoes are mine, they were kept in the shop where he worked; I had seen them the day before, and missed them when I came home, about six o'clock in the evening.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. I believe he had a shop of his own once? A. I believe he had; he was not in any kind of partnership with me; I never had any cards with his name on the back of them; he came with a condition that he should recommend his former customers, and I allowed him 15 percent.; I did so with all my shopmen - he was allowed to take shoes out and sell them to his own customers with my leave, or with the shopman's permission in my absence, and to book them afterwards - I should have no objection to take him again.

COURT. Q. What was it you permitted him to do on speaking to you, or to any body in your shop? A. If any of his friends had a pair of shoes, I allowed him the profit of them, but I never allowed him to take any, except for sale.

HANNAH ANDREWS. I was in the service of Mr. Bonham. On the 12th of July, I observed a pair of shoes in the prisoner's coat pocket, which hung in the cupboard - he took them out with him; I sent the apprentice to see where he went to - he gave me information, and I found them at the pawnbroker's.
Cross-examined. Q. You were in the shop when he went out? A. Yes; the cupboard was not locked - any one might have gone there - he put the coat on openly before me - he has borne a good character.

WILLIAM DEMPSTER
. I am a pawnbroker. These shoes were pawned with me, on the evening of the 12th of July, by the prisoner, I believe, in the name of John Dunn.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you a great many people come to your shop? A. Yes; I think I can be positive he is the person who brought them.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I did not take them to defraud my master; I cannot see how it is possible the witness can speak so positive to me, my brother is so much like me, we are continually taken for one another.

JOHN PROCTOR
. I am apprentice to Mr. Bonham. On the 12th of July, I was sent to watch the prisoner; I saw him go to the pawnbroker's and pawn the shoes.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you go into the shop? A. No; I did not see him with the shoes - I watched him in, and watched him out; Mr. Bonham went there afterwards.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1622.
JAMES HARGER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of September , 5 lbs. weight of silk, value 7l.; 120 yards of cotton-braid, value 2s., and 1 bobbin of silk, value 1s., the goods of
John Henry Machu
, his master .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN HENRY MACHU. I am a silk-trimming manufacturer , and live in Twister's-alley, Bunhill-row
. The prisoner was my porter ; on the 10th of September I received 58 lbs. weight of silk from the dyer's - it ought to have been kept in the silk-room, a place quite detached from the warehouse - on the 11th of September, early in the morning, I was in the warehouse, and my attention was drawn to an iron safe; I saw behind it a quantity of sewing-silk; it was afterwards weighed; when I first saw it it was loose, and was the very same sort as that I received from the dyer's; I had not any more in the warehouse - it was among a lot of waste paper; I took it up to convince myself what it was, and let it fall again; I had been looking there for a cord; about this time the prisoner was coming to the warehouse; I sent him away with some goods, and he returned in about an hour; he had not time to go behind the safe before he went away; there was a boy left in the warehouse - when he returned the boy had left, and I went to the place, and saw the silk still there; no one else had gone into the warehouse; the boy was never in the warehouse afterwards - about half an hour after the prisoner returned, I saw the silk in the cotton-room, which is a building quite detached from the warehouse - I am not aware that the prisoner had any occasion to go into that room, and did not see him there - I found the silk in a handkerchief, which I believe to be his; I have seen him with one of the same pattern; he was with me when I found it; I asked him how to account for it; he said he did not know, the silk was not his - I asked if it was his handkerchief; he said he did not know - I sent for the officer, and when he came I told him how wrong it was for him to do so, and I had been served so by some of his predecessors; he made no reply - he said when he was going out that he was a lost man, and did not care what became of him; I afterwards went to his lodging with the officer.

Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. You say, when the boy went away the prisoner had returned? A. Yes; and in about half an hour I found the silk in the cotton-room. I had been some few moments in my house, once or twice; a person might have gone into the warehouse without my seeing them, but not without my hearing the door go; my house is about six feet off; I went up stairs into the bed-room which looks into the warehouse; I was there five or ten minutes, I might be a quarter of an hour altogether in the house - I employ forty or fifty other workmen; I believe they were not on the premises; I did not see any one go from the warehouse to the cotton-room; they might have done so, but it is very improbable.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Could any person have gone out of the warehouse without your hearing them? A. I think not, because the door makes a noise; it was not the business of any person to have been employed there but the prisoner.

COURT. Q. When you came back the prisoner was in the room where the silk was? A. Yes, and I suppose he took it from the warehouse to the cotton-room during the half hour; he must have opened the door that I speak of; it was his usual custom, after he has done his work in the warehouse, to lock the door and bring in the key; I went out with the key, and he was coming out of the cotton-room; at that moment my dog got loose in the cellar, and I desired him to go down and fasten him; I then went into the warehouse, and the silk was gone - I found it in the cotton-room, behind a box of rubbish - I sent for the officer, and told him what I conceived the prisoner to have done, and it was when he was going out of the door that he used this expression - I had desired him to look for it, but he would not; he stoodbefore the hole where the silk was, within a yard of it, and I desired him to move; I put my hand in and took hold of it.

ROBERT LOCK
. I am the officer. I have the silk which Mr. Machu desired me to take away - it laid on the box - the prisoner was there; he said he was a lost man, and he did not care what become of him; it was tied up in this handkerchief.

JAMES BAMFORD
. I am a foreman to Mr. Machu. I know the prisoner - on the 10th of September some silk of this description came from the dyer's; I weighed it, and there was 58lbs.; it was then put into the silk-room, which is detached from the warehouse; I have seen this parcel of silk weighed; it weighs 5lbs., and I have weighed the silk that came from the dyer's since; we had parted with about 9lbs. 11 oz. of it, but allowing for that there is 5lbs. deficient - I have seen the prisoner with a handkerchief of this pattern, about five or six days before; it was dirty on a shelf, and he said "This is mine, I will take it home, and have it washed;" it struck me immediately that it was the same handkerchief; I have often seen a handkerchief of this kind in the warehouse.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I went out with a paper, and the boy was left in the warehouse; when I returned I was occupied full an hour in putting things in order; the prosecutor was in his house, and I did not see him till I went out to my breakfast; he then came and asked, if I had seen the silk; I said I had not; he then told me to search, which I did, and it was found in the cotton-room; but I told him I knew nothing of it.
COURT to PROSECUTOR. Q. Did he say he knew nothing of it? A. He said it was not his - I said it was not, it was mine.
Six witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 33.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Twelve Months .

1623.
JACOB MEE
was indicted for
embezzlement .

GEORGE OWEN
. I am a boot and shoe-maker , and live in Cross-court, Carnaby-street
. The prisoner was my apprentice , and was employed to receive money for me; when money was paid him, he was to account for it immediately on his return; he gave me no money on the 1st of June , as received from
Ann Smith
; and to the best of my knowledge he gave me no money on that day - Mr. Smith owed me for the repair of a pair of boots for one of his children - on the 26th of August I told the prisoner to go for the money, and he said he recollected that Mr. Smith had called in my absence, and paid it, and he had given it to his mistress - my wife denied receiving the money; he did not say any thing else, and I sent for Mrs. Smith, who came and said she had paid him when he took them home; when I sent him with them I was in the shop, and on his return he said he gave them to Mrs. Smith, who did not ask him the price; he has been with me four years.

ANN SMITH. I am the wife of
Thomas Smith
. The prisoner brought home a pair of boots for my child, and I paid him 1s. 4d. when he brought them home.

THOMAS GOOK
. I was sent for to take the prisoner; his master gave him in charge for receiving 1s. 4d. of Mrs. Smith, which he had not given him; he said he was very sorry, and hoped his master would forgive him.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Months .

1624.
JOHN MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing 3 axes, value 5s., and 1 hammer, value 4d. , the goods of
John Hinxman
.

MARY BUVINI
. I am in the service of John Hinxman, who lives in Tottenham-court-road
- his house was repairing on the 11th of August - the prisoner was a labourer there; I saw him go to dinner with a sack, which appeared heavier than it ought to be; I called him back, and asked him what he had got; he said, "Tools of my master's, which I am going to carry home;" I found these three axes - I claimed them as being Mr. Hinxman's property - he has a quantity of iron and lead, and other things at the back of his premises, of which I had the charge.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Was this man working on the premises? A. Yes; with his master; he offered no resistance - he said he had been desired to take them by his master - he emptied the bag without any hesitation.

JOHN TECTOR
. The prisoner was working for me at Mr. Hinxman's - I did not desire him to take any axes or any thing else from there.
Cross-examined. Q. How long did he work for you? A. Ten days; I never saw the tools.

JOHN LEWIS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found this hammer in his breeches pocket - he said at the office that his master gave it him to put a handle to it.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. He put all these things in the bag, and told me to take them home before I went to dinner.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Confined One Month .

1625.
GEORGE PALMER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
Edwin John Grafton
, from his person .

EDWIN JOHN GRAFTON. On the evening of the 30th of July I was walking with my brother and a friend, near Northumberland-street, Strand
- we passed five or six persons at the corner of St. Martin's-lane; I felt something behind me, and missed my handkerchief; I saw the prisoner walking from me; I took hold of him, and was about to take the handkerchief from his hand - he had not met me, but was walking as if he had - he ran across the street, I pursued, and he dropped it; I am quite certain I saw it in his hand - the gentleman who was with me took it up.

WILLIAM NETTLETON
. I am the officer. I took the prisoner at the watch-house.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. (written.) I was proceeding home, and heard an alarm - I went to ascertain the cause, but finding it was of no consequence I returned, when I was stopped by a watchman at the end of a court - he took me back to the prosecutor, who was completely intoxicated - the handkerchief produced is the property of my sister.
Mr. GRAFTON. I was not at all in liquor.

ANN PALMER
. I am the prisoner's sister - this yellow handkerchief is mine - there is a man on horse-back on it.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined Three Months .

1626.
THOMAS TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 1 pair of boots, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Croft
.

THOMAS CROFT. I am stable-boy to Mr. Gale, of Phoenix-yard, Oxford-street
. I lost a pair of boots from the stable; I went the same evening to Bow-street - I saw the prisoner there about half-past four o'clock - he had a horse to look after in the same yard.

WILLIAM GUY
. I am a patrol. Philpott, (who is not here,) gave the prisoner into my custody, with these boots, which he said he had stopped him with, and he had stolen them from Mr. Gale's yard; the prisoner said he could not swear that.
NOT GUILTY .

1627.
FREDERICK WILKINSON
and
ELIZABETH ADAMS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 2 pictures, framed, value 12s. , the goods of
Thomas Smart
.

THOMAS SMART. I am a carver and gilder , and live in Greek-street, Soho
. I lost two pictures on the 12th of September; I went out on business at seven o'clock that evening, and when I returned, in an hour and a half, they were missing - they were safe when I went out.

SIMON SOLOMAN ZILVER
. I was opposite Mr. Smart's shop on the evening of the 12th of September; I saw Adams walking about, and I noticed her; I then saw Wilkinson at the corner of Mr. Smart's door - he took the pictures, and ran with them into Bateman's-buildings, with Adams; they went together. I heard in about two minutes that they were stolen, and ran with others through Greek-street, to Soho-square, and then to Dean-street; I then saw the prisoners opposite, and we went and took hold of them - I said, "Where are the pictures?" Wilkinson said, "I do not know any thing about them;" Adams said, "I did not take them." We then took them to the watch-house; I had not seen them together before; she was standing in the street when he went to the shop - she did not see him take them, but she joined him the moment he had got them; they only walked to the corner of Bateman's-buildings, and then I saw them in Dean-street.

JOHN PRATER
. The prisoners were brought to me at the watch-house.

WILKINSON'S Defence. I was coming down Dean-street, that gentleman came and took hold of me, and said I had stolen pictures; I said I had not, and would go with him any where. As to this girl I know nothing of her.
ADAMS' Defence. I never saw this young man before- I am innocent.

WILKINSON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

ADAMS -
NOT GUILTY .

1628.
ABRAHAM FOWLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , 1 watch, value 20s., the goods of
John George Emett
, from his person .

JOHN GEORGE EMETT. On the 3d of July, while I was walking in the Strand
, in company with two friends, we met a procession of some Society; we got partly through the crowd when I found myself stopped, and the pressure appeared to me to be more than usual; I gave the person a push with my hand, and he made off; Richardson, who was with me, asked if I had lost any thing; I then felt, and my watch was gone.
Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. You have the misfortune to be blind, I believe? A. Yes, very nearly so.

JONATHAN RICHARDSON
. I was with Mr. Emett, near Somerset House, and saw the prisoner very near us, actively engaged at the head of a mob, which I evidently saw was created for the purpose of making depredations. I cannot say I saw him make an attack on my friend, but he was very near him; I did not see the watch taken, but some time afterwards I asked Mr. Emett, and he said, "I have lost my watch" - I went to the head of the mob, and saw the officer - I told him of it. I did not see the prisoner till he was at Bow-street.

JONATHAN RICHARDSON, JUN.
I was with Mr. Emett, and saw the prisoner in the Strand, in a mob - I saw him look at Mr. Emett, and make a stop, and appear as if he was picking his pocket.

JOHN VIRGO BUCKLAND
. I took up the prisoner in the Strand.

WILLIAM BEAZLEY
. I live at Vauxhall. I was in the Strand, and saw the prisoner near Mr. Emett, but did not see him do any thing.
NOT GUILTY .

1629.
CHARLES WALKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 2 candlesticks, value 3s. , the goods of
William Wood
.

MATILDA WOOD
. My brother, William Wood, keeps the Grapes public-house, in Portpool-lane
. On the 14th of August I saw the prisoner in our skittle-ground, with this pair of candlesticks in a handkerchief under his arm; I asked what he had got - he said nothing - he then threw them down, and said, "If they are your's you are welcome to them" - my brother sent for an officer, who took him. I saw him come out of the wash-house, where they were kept.

WILLIAM WAINWRIGHT
. I am an officer, and took him.(Property produced and sworn to).
Prisoner's Defence. I went to the skittle-ground, and saw my handkerchief on the ground - I took it up, and the candlesticks were in it.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Confined Three Months .

1630.
JOHN WEALE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 4 hair-brooms, value 5s. , the goods of
Mary Ife
, widow .

MARY IFE. I am a widow, and live at Chelsea
. I lost these four hair-brooms from the door of my shop - the prisoner was brought back with them.

JOHN ABRAHAM
. On the 30th of June I saw the prisoner take four brooms from Mrs. Ife's shop, and walk away - he had not gone above a hundred yards, when I told a person, who went and took him; I was at a window on a ladder; I had a full view of him.

THOMAS SYMONS
. Abraham pointed out the prisoner to me on the 30th of June - I found these four brooms on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I was in great distress, but I did not take them.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1631.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 2 pewter pots, value 2s. , the goods of
Henry Herbert
.

MARY JACOBS
. My brother, Henry Herbert, keeps a public-house in Bunhill-row
. On the 31st of August I was in the passage, and saw the prisoner with something under his apron; he asked for some water, and I told him to go into the wash-house, and he would find some; he took the tea-kettle, and walked, stooping, to the water cock, and stooped to fill the kettle; I saw him lay a pint pot on the dung-hill, and put a quart-pot into his hat; I left him in care of my brother, while I fetched an officer.
HENRY HERBERT. I went into the yard on the 31st of August, and saw the prisoner, who, my sister said, had put the pot on the dung-bill - he said nothing.

ROBERT LOCK
. I took the prisoner; he said, "I was going to get a kettle of water," but afterwards, just as he got to the watch-house, he said it was through distress.
