Prisoner's Defence. I never said a word of the sort; I went to get a kettle of water, and there was none in the butt; I saw a pail of water there, and I took the quart-pot, and filled the kettle; as to the pint-pot on the dunghill, I know nothing of it.
MARY JACOBS re-examined. He drew the water from the cock into the kettle.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined One Month .

1632.
JOSEPH WINSALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , 1 basket, value 2s., and 1 bushel of pears, value 5s. , the goods of
Thomas Tittman
.

THOMAS TITTMAN. I live in the Strand, and keep a stall in Covent-garden-market
. On the 4th of August I missed a bushel of pears, and a basket, which I had seen safe the day before - I saw them again the day afterwards; the basket has my name on it.

WILLIAM THOMAS PARSONS
. On the 4th of August I saw the prisoner running up Durham-street, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, with a basket of pears; I followed him - he threw it off his shoulder, and ran down William-street; I took him to the watch-house, and took the basket of pears.(Basket produced and identified.)
Prisoner's Defence. I have been out of employ for four months.
GUILTY . Aged 47.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1633.
ANN WEBBER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 2 shillings, the monies of
Edward Evans
, from his person .

EDWARD EVANS. I was at the Adam and Eve, public-house, Westminster, on the 5th of September - I went from home about twelve o'clock, and remained at the public-house the rest of the day; I was not very much in liquor, and I left my friend who I had been with, at half-past seven o'clock in the evening; I had some money on my person - I had never seen the prisoner before I was at Queen-square-office; I do not know how I got into her company.
Prisoner. You had 2s. 6d. in the office the next morning, and you told the gentleman you had lost no money.
Q. Then you do not know that you had more money then than you had the next morning at the office? A. Yes; my landlord brought me half-a-crown that morning.

FRANCIS NEWSTEAD
. On the 5th of September, I saw the prisoner and the prosecutor; he appeared to be in liquor, but appeared to have been extremely ill-used; he was quite stupified from the effects of the usage; the prisoner was accompanied by three young men and a boy about ten years of age - she placed the prosecutor against a door, and supported his head with her left hand, while she put her right hand into his breeches pocket, and passed something to the boy, who made off; she then put her hand again into his left hand pocket; I watched her; she changed her position, and put her right hand before his eyes, and put her left hand into his breeches pocket; I saw her put something in her bosom; I went and asked her if she was his wife; she said No - I went and told a grocer, who came out, and said it was a pity there was not a street-keeper about - I went on to Shetton-ground, and when I returned I saw three youths ill-treating the prosecutor in a most barbarous manner; the prisoner had his hat in her hand, partly concealed by her apron; I went up and remonstrated with them - I was afterwards desired to give my address, which I did; the prisoner ran off as soon as she knew there were officers coming.

WILLIAM RAYNER
. I am the officer. I came up and took the prisoner, who was running away; I found 2s. in her bosom; she said she had some money which she brought out to buy something.

Prisoner's Defence. I went into the house where the prosecutor was drinking, and my friend sat down by him; he gave us some beer to drink; he had half-a-crown, and said he had pawned his coat for 6s., and had no more left- he then got up to go and he fell into the sink; I raised him up and set him against the wall, and told her to mind him while I went to get him some water; when I got back his hat was off, and I put it on his head.

COURT to EVANS. Q. Did you pawn your coat that morning? A. Yes, for 6s.; I had but 1s. 11d. in the morning, and thought that not enough; I was sober then, and I went to the Adam and Eve with my friend, and we drank several pints of beer together; I then left him to go home; I was not so tipsy till I was knocked down and ill-treated.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1633.
ANN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 necklace, value 2s., the goods of
Elias Bendon
, from the person of
Rachael Bendon
.

JULIA CARTHY
. I am servant to Elias Bendon; I had the care of his daughter Rachael. On the 14th of August I took her down Whitechapel
in my arms - the prisoner, whom I knew before, came and asked me to give her the child, which I did; she took it up stairs in a house, and gave it a bit of victuals; it had a necklace on; she then brought it down, and took it to a cook-shop, where there were a number of people - she would not let me go in; she did not stay there above a quarter of an hour, and then brought the child out without the necklace; I asked her for it; she said she had not got it; I said "Will you give me the necklace, and I will say nothing to my master;" she said "I don't know, I have not got it."

Prisoner's Defence. I took the child into a cook-shop and there were a great many girls there, some of whom took the child and kissed it, and took the necklace off its neck; I did not know it for above an hour when the witness came back, and then one of the girls gave me the duplicate - the witness went all down Petticoat-lane, and where the mob was; she never spoke about the beads till she came back with her master.

JAMES LEA
. I took up the prisoner, and she gave me the ticket.

JOHN YOWART
. I am a pawnbroker. I took in this necklace, about two o'clock, of a girl of the name of Maun, not the prisoner.
ELIAS BENDON. This necklace is the one my child had on.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined One Month .

1635.
JAMES RAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of July , 1 cap, value 3s., and 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of
John Lipson
, from his person .

JOHN LIPSON. On the 14th of July I was in Gray's-inn-lane
; the prisoner came up with two females; he took me up in his arms and put me down again - I then missed my cap and handkerchief, which was in it - the prisoner joined the two girls and walked up Gray's-inn-lane; I went and asked him for my property; he made me no answer; I was looking about the street for them, thinking he had not got them; and in half an hour the prisoner came back with the two females again - I asked again for them, but he made me no answer; I then told the watchman; he went after him and took him; he objected to the watchman searching him, and there was some struggling between them; and while that was going on, the cap fell from the prisoner's hat.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did he not appear very drunk? A. No; he returned back to the place where I was; when his hat fell off one of the girls took it up and put it on his head.

WILLIAM BANTING
. I was on duty on the 14th of July - the gentleman came to me and said, he had been robbed; he said there were two men, and one held him while the other took his cap from him - he described him as dressed like a sailor - we went down Gray's-inn-lane-road, where we saw them, and he said, "That is the one in the middle" - I took the prisoner, and he began fighting - his hat fell off, and the cap fell out of it.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he not appear tipsy? A. I should not have supposed so; no doubt he had been drinking with the girls.(Cap produced and sworn to.)
NOT GUILTY .

1636.
FANNY SHEPHERD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , 2 sheets, value 4s.; 2 blankets, value 4s.; 1 counterpane, value 3s.; and 1 bolster, value 4s., the goods of
William Rowe
, in a lodging room .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1637.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of June , 11 tea spoons, value 18s., and 2 table spoons, value 12s., the goods of
William Bashall
, his master .
Mr. BARRY conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM BASHALL. I live in Camden-cottage, Kentish-town
. The prisoner left my service on the 13th of June; I had taken him on the 8th of June; he waited at table at dinner time, and then he went down to the kitchen, and went out at the coach-house door, which it was not necessary to open at all - I have never had the spoons since; he left without his wages.

SARAH PLATT
. I am servant to Mr. Bashall; the prisoner attended the dinner on the 13th, and after dinner the two table spoons were brought down; they laid on the kitchen table, the rest of the plate was in the kitchen cupboard - the prisoner was in the kitchen - I asked him to shake the cloth, he said, he could not till he had put the horse and chaise away; and that would take him the whole afternoon - I went down in about a quarter of an hour, and he was gone and the spoons also; he did not return.
Prisoner's Defence. I left the place, as he was always grumbling about the horse.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Confined Two Months and
Whipped .

1638.
THOMAS WEAVER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 22 yards of lace, value 22s.; and 8 pair of stockings, value 28s., the goods of
Thomas Bates
, his master .
MR. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

THOMAS BATES. I live in Thayer-street, Manchester-square
. The prisoner had been my shopman three months, at sixty guineas a-year - I had given him notice to quit, and he was about leaving on the 10th of August; there was a settlement between us, and he owed me two shillings and ninepence; he requested to stop in the house that night, which I allowed; in the evening an acquaintance called, and she was taken very ill - I went for a surgeon; the prisoner was there; some tape was asked for, he got the key off the dining-room table, and, without being asked, went into the shop to get the tape; it struck me he was gone two or three minutes longer than he needed; he slept in the same room as I did that night; and in the morning I went to get the key of the shop from his pockets, and found a piece of lace there; I came down and sent for an officer, who came, and we went up stairs; the officer taxed him with having the lace, and he said he had; he then requested me to step out on the landing; I made him no promise or threat, but on getting on the landing-place, he said, "Mr. Bates, I did take the lacewhen I went for the tape, I also took the stockings;" I desired the officer to search his box, and we found a paper of eight pairs of silk stockings, which cost me 3s. 6d. a pair; he then came out and said, "You have got your property, what do you want more;" I told him, as he had acted so ungratetully, the law should take its course.

ROBERT WILLIAMS
. I am an officer. I was sent for; I went up stairs, took up the prisoner's coat, and found this card of lace in his pocket; I asked how he came by it, and he mumbled something; he said, he took it; that he was sorry for it, and we might have it again; Mr. Bates then wished to have his trunk searched, and, at that moment, he asked Mr. Bates to step out on the landing with him; the door was open; he said, there were six pairs of stockings in his trunk; Mr. Bates claimed the property.
Prisoner's Defence. I can declare this is a solitary instance, and no man in the world can charge any thing against me.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1639.
MARY BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 watch, value 30s.; 1 watch-chain, value 40s.; 2 seals, value 15s.; 1 watch-key, value 3s.; 1 handkerchief, value 4s., and 5 shillings, the property of
George Hallows
, from his person .

GEORGE HALLOWS. I met the prisoner on the night of the 11th of July, and went with her to a house in the Almonry
- I was not tipsy - I slept with her, and when I awoke in the morning she was gone, with my watch and handkerchief.

SARAH TAYLOR
. The prisoner slept at my house that night - she had slept there twice before; I met her afterwards, and told her she had made a nice job of it - she said, "Well, if I did, you did not know what I was going to do;" I told her the man said, if he had the duplicate of the watch, he would not mind; she said she would give it me next morning; I said, I would have it then, or keep her, which I did, and had her taken up - the watch has not been found.
GUILTY. Aged 21. Of stealing, but not from the person .
Transported for Seven Years .

1640.
JOHN CATLIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of a certain man unknown
, from his person .

DANIEL RIERDON
. I was in the Strand
between nine and ten o'clock at night, on the 17th of July - I saw the prisoner and two lads opposite Exeter-Change, following two gentleman - one of them took a handkerchief from one of the gentleman's pockets, and handed it to the prisoner, who put it into the flap of his breeches; I took him, and got it from him.

WILLIAM McGREGOR
. I was with Rierdon - I saw the prisoner and a companion rather less than him, take the handkerchief and gave it to him - he was about half a yard from him; he put it into the left side of his breeches - I followed the gentleman and said, "You have lost your handkerchief;" he turned round, and said, "My God - it is gone." I do not know who he was.

Prisoner's Defence. When he took me he said "Mac, let us take him to our old shop - we can do as we like there, and have him fully committed in the morning - let us take him to St. Ann's watch-house, they will take in any charge there;" the next morning McGregor said I took the handkerchief, and the other said, "Mind what you say," and then he said one of the others took it.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1641.
JOHN WOOD
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Conrad Meyer
, on the 19th of June , with intent to put him in fear and danger of his life, and his monies, from his person, feloniously to steal .
SECOND COUNT stating it to be with intent to rob the said Conrad Meyer.

CONRAD MEYER. I am a Swiss. On the 19th of June I was sitting on the trunk of a tree in Kensington-gardens
, about one o'clock; I received a heavy blow from behind, which stunned me; I then got a second blow - I did not see any person near me; I thought I was about to be murdered, but I got up, and two men very kindly came to me.

DAVID STEWART
. I am a cork-cutter, and live in William-street, Regent's-park. I was in Kensington-gardens, heard a cry, and ran with another person in that direction - I saw the prisoner running towards us, in an opposite direction to Mr. Meyer, about a furlong from him - he then turned, and went in another direction, at a good pace - I went up to him, and asked what was the matter; I did not distinctly hear his answer then; but afterwards, when I returned from assisting Mr. Meyer. (whom I left bleeding on the box with the porter.) he told me he was in want - the grass was very high, and I could not see whether any one else was near Mr. Meyer.

JOHN LUGARD
. I was with Stewart, in Kensington-gardens. I heard a cry of Murder! and saw Mr. Meyer run without his hat; I looked after him, and at some distance I saw the prisoner walk, and then begin to run; he was the nearest person to Mr. Meyer; he walked up towards us, and I asked him what he did to the gentleman - I think he said, nothing; I took him, and Stewart went to see for Mr. Meyer; there was a labouring man stood with me; the prisoner asked me to let him go; I said I would not; he said he was doing his business, and the gentleman came and took him by the collar, and said the park was no place to do any thing of that kind in; he then wanted to go again, but I said, "If that was all, he had nothing to fear."

Cross-examined by MR. FISH. Q. There was a considerable concourse of people, was there not? A. No; the prisoner was on one side of the river, and we were on the other, which is a considerable distance; he was going in a direction from the gentleman.

WILLIAM WRAGG
. I am keeper of the gardens. Mr. Meyer was brought to me in a state of great ill-usage, and then the prisoner was brought; I took him to Mr. Meyer - he fell on his knees, and said, "Sir, I humbly beg your pardon for what I have done - I have done wrong."
Cross-examined. Q. Were there many people about? A. Not many; I found this veil on the prisoner's person, which is used to put before the face.

THOMAS FORD
. I received the prisoner at Bow-street;I found a phosphorus-box and nine matches on him, a chisel, and nine duplicates; I went to look for the weapon the next morning, and found this stick.

WILLIAM BALE
. I was there and heard the cry; I saw the gentleman staggering about, and bleeding very profusely; I conveyed him up to the gate.
COURT to PROSECUTOR. Q. Did you see any person near you that you spoke to about relieving themselves? A. No.

GEORGE KENFIELD
. I was going to take a boat from the water, and heard the cry of murder; I saw the gentleman, and I thought he had been cutting his own throat; I went and inquired which was the man; I collared the prisoner; he said he begged my pardon, and was sorry for what he had done; he was in great distress; I said, "What did you do it with an instrument?" he said,"No, a stick which I took up in the gardens."

Prisoner's Defence. I merely said, when he came and said the gentleman had his clothes all over blood, and he supposed it was done with a sharp instrument, that I had seen it done with a stick, but I had not done it; when I knelt down and begged the gentleman's pardon, I was treated shamefully.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1642.
WILLIAM HEAGREN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Philip Burgess
, from his person .

PHILIP BURGESS. On the 5th of September I was in Piccadilly
; my handkerchief was in my right-hand surtoutcoat pocket; I felt a pull, and turned round immediately; I found it in the prisoner's hand; I had used it a moment before, and put it safe into my pocket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up, and gave it to the gentleman.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1643.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 shoe, value 3s., the goods of
Francis Lloyd
, from his person .

FRANCIS LLOYD. On the 11th of July I was at the Haymarket Theatre, with my wife - the prisoner, as I believe, came up and requested me to let him get a coach, as is was raining; I would not; he then followed me up the Haymarket
, and there were twenty or thirty persons; some one threw a stone, which staggered me a little; the prisoner then came and stood on my heel; I turned and said, "Is there not room enough on the flag-stones?" - I then put my hand to my pocket, but I had lost nothing - the prisoner then appeared to be inebriated, but I afterwards saw him follow some other persons up the Hay-market, and I said to the watchman, "There is a thief, I believe," and I was going away; but when I had got about thirty doors, Mrs. Lloyd put her hand to my pocket, and found that one shoe was gone from it; I put her into a shop, and went with the watchman; we took the prisoner with the shoe in his hand.

COURT. Q. Why did not you give charge of him at once? A. I did not know that I had lost any thing; when he was taken he was speaking some flash words to a woman, who was very angry with him for not taking both shoes - one expression which I remarked was,"What a d-d fumbler he was not to get the two - one was of no use."

MICHAEL QUIN
. I am a watchman of Coventry-street. I went with Lloyd, and took the prisoner with the shoe; he pretended to be drunk, but when he got to the watch-house he was perfectly sober.
Prisoner to FRANCIS LLOYD. Q. Can you swear I took it out of your pocket at the time I trod on your heel? A. I can swear he got it out of my pocket, but I cannot say when.

GEORGE SMITH
. I was night constable. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house with this shoe.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was going along the Haymarket - a shoe was thrown at me, and I took it up.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1644.
WILLIAM KILBY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 4 sovereigns, 2 half-crowns, 2 shillings, and 2 sixpences, the monies of
Joseph Labovitch
from his person .

JOSEPH LABOVITCH. (Through an interpreter.) I live in Brown's-buildings, and am a licensed-hawker and pedlar . On the 14th of August, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I was in a brick-field, with a box, selling rhubarb; I had a little box, containing four sovereigns, some half-crowns, shillings, and sixpences. The prisoner came out of the field, and cheapened a piece of rhubarb - he told me to wait while he went into the field; I waited on the opposite side of the field, and there was a brook - the prisoner called me, and he laid down some bricks for me to get over, but I went to another place, a little higher, which I could step over; the prisoner then came again, and he pulled the box, which I had across my shoulder - the strap broke, and when the box was on the ground he put his hand in, and took the money out; he ran away: I made a terrible noise, till some persons came to my assistance; I left my box on the ground, and when I came back it was safe, but I have never got my money; I did not see him again till the officer took me to a public-house, where I saw him with many others, and distinguished him - I swear he is the man.

THOMAS COPE
. I am a constable. On the 14th of August, at a quarter before four o'clock, I met the prosecutor in Lower-road, Islington - he appeared much agitated, and put his hand to his pockets; a gentleman said he had been robbed by the brick-makers; I went to the field, and saw the stool where the prisoner had worked was wet, and a boy there called out, "Whahaak," which is a signal for a person who has done wrong to keep away; I then went to the Green Man public-house with the prosecutor, who put his hand on the prisoner's shoulder, and pointed him out as the man.

WILLIAM SLATER
. I work in Mr. Laycock's brickfield
, at the next stool to the prisoner. On the 14th of August, about four o'clock, I saw the prosecutor on the road; the prisoner went over the road, and called to him to come - he seemed afraid, but the prisoner laid down two or three bricks for him to come over, which he did; the prisoner then asked the price of his rhubarb; he said 3s. 6d.,3s. 3d., and 3s., and the prisoner ran off with it; a man ran after him, and bring it back; I saw the box safe round the prosecutor's neck - he put it down himself, and ran a little way after the prisoner.

Prisoner's Defence. I asked the price of the rhubarb, and offered him 2s.; I went to ask a friend if he thought it was worth it, but the prosecutor made such a noise that I was afraid to bring it back, and I sent it back by the moulder.

SARAH BAILEY
. I am a brick-maker. I was at the next stool to the prisoner; I saw the prosecutor take the box off his own neck, and go to get the rbubarb back.
COURT to THOMAS COPE. Q. When the prosecutor pointed out the prisoner, did he say any thing? A. No - but on the road he acknowledged taking the rhubarb, but nothing else.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Whipped and Discharged .

1645.
JAMES LACEY
,
CHARLES NEWMAN
, and
ROBERT WRIGHT
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of July , 1 hat, value 10s.; 1 pencil, value 1s. 6d.; 1 knife, value 2s., and 1 umbrella, value 6s., the goods of
Henry Coles
, from his person .

HENRY COLES. I had a hat, a pencil-case, a knife, and an umbrella with me, at the corner of Cowcross-street
, on the 28th of July - I had a fall there, which stunned me, and scratched my face - I know nothing more; but the hat, pencil-case, and knife are here.

CHARLES CLARKE
. On Friday evening, the 28th of July, about half-past nine o'clock, I saw Lacey, Newman, and another with Coles, who was very drunk, and had had a fall; they were in Turnmill-street - I saw Lacey turn up the skirt of Coles' coat, and take from his pocket a handkerchief, which he delivered to Newman; they went round Clerkenwell-close, and when they got to Corporation-lane I met a watchman, and told him; Lacey was then taken, and locked up; as I returned I saw Newman with a different hat to the one he used to wear, which he was offering for sale.
Cross-examined by MR. FISH. Q. What description of boy was the other? A. He said he was an apprentice - he was discharged by the Magistrate.

SAMUEL SMITH
. On the evening of the 28th of July, about half-past nine o'clock, I saw the three prisoners and Coles in Cowcross-street - he was very tipsy, and had a desperate fall; he dropped the umbrella out of his hand; it rolled into the kennel - I saw Wright pick it up, and walk by the side of Coles, and then go down a court by a public-house. I then saw Lacey, Newman, and another follow Coles, and at the corner of Clerkenwell-close I saw Lacey take the handkerchief, and by the New Prison Newman took Coles' hat off his head, and put his own hat on Coles' head.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. I am an apprentice to Mr. Hey, of Coppice-row. I knew Wright, by seeing him on Clerkenwell-green - he had the same dress he has now - I was not a yard from him - there was light by the public-house; he put the umbrella under his arm. I never stated that he had light-coloured trousers on.

Prisoner WRIGHT. He stated at the office that the boy who ran away took the handkerchief and umbrella? Witness. No, I did not; he took up the umbrella, and put it under his arm; he then turned into a court, as if he was unlocking a door, I thought, and two children followed him. The prosecutor was quite senseless; Lacey took hold of him, and was dragging him along; Newman took his hat off.

JONATHAN BROWN
. I took Lacey, and one who is not here, to the watch-house. I saw the pencil-case and knife taken from Lacey.

JOHN LEADMAN
. I am a constable. I took up Newman on Friday, the 28th, about ten o'clock, on the information of Clarke and others. I found this hat on his head, which he said he got for 2s., and his own in exchange.

JOHN POTTINGER
, I took up Wright on Saturday - he said he knew the prisoners, but knew nothing of the robbery.(Property produced and sworn to.)

LACEY's Defence. I was walking up Turnmill-street, and saw the prosecutor lay on the ground - I got him up, helped him along, and proposed taking him to the watch-house; the other young man took hold of him - I was then taken to the watch-house.
NEWMAN's Defence. I met two or three people selling the hat - one man said, "Look at it?" I said, "What do you want for it?" he said 2s. 6d. and my old hat.

LACEY -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

NEWMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Confined One Month .

WRIGHT -
NOT GUILTY .

1646.
MARGARET BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , 20 yards of cotton, value 14s. , the goods of
Thomas Davies
.

CAROLINE BRADSHAW
. I was in Holborn
on the 11th of September, near Mr. Davies' shop; I saw the prisoner go and take the cotton off the rail, and put it into her lap - she went a little way into the shop, then came out and went down Chancery-lane; I went and told the shopman, who pursued, and stopped her - I saw the cotton fall from her in Holborn.

ROBERT MIERS
. I am shopman to Mr. Davies. I pursued the prisoner and found this cotton in her apron - she said "Be off, you don't want me;" she let it fall out of her apron - it has our shop mark on it.

JONATHAN NICHOLSON
. I am the officer, and took the prisoner. She said at the office, she picked it up, and had a right to it.
Prisoner's Defence. I was very much in liquor.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Transported for Seven Years .

1647.
MARTHA BURGESS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , 1 waistcoat, value 6s. , the goods of
James Payne
and
George Henry Bassington
.

JOHN YOUART
. I am in the employ of James Payne and George Henry Bassington; they live in High-street, Whitechapel
. On the 11th of August this waistcoat was in the shop; I did not see it taken, but in consequence of information I pursued, and found it in the prisoner's apron.

WILLIAM HAWKINS
. I was standing opposite the shop, and a man said "I believe that woman has taken something;" I looked round, and the prisoner was putting something into her apron; I had seen the waistcoat not a quarter of an hour before in the shop,

WILLIAM DICKINSON
. I am the officer. I took her in charge.
(Property produced and sworn to).
Prisoner's Defence. I found it on the pavement.
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Confined Six Months .

1648.
MARY ANN CARROLL
and
MARY CARROLL
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of August , 7 yards of lace, value 3s.; 1 gown, value 3s., and 6 yards of net, value 3s. , the goods of
James Dawson
.

CATHERINE DAWSON
. I live in Church-street, St. Giles
- Mary Carroll lived with me; Fleming lived in the same house. On the 22d of August, about four o'clock, I went out and left Mary Ann Carroll in my room, and this property safe; I went to the adjoining house, but did not go in - while I was there the two prisoners came out together - I saw Mary Ann with her apron up - I went into my house, and missed the articles.

Prisoner MARY CARROLL. The witness asked me to go to lie down at her house, where my sister was; she gave me the gown to pawn, and the lace was in it; she knew I pawned it, and had some of the money. Witness. No, I did not.

ELIZABETH FLEMING
. I went out on this evening for some clothes, and left Dawson in the room - my gown was there, with her net and lace - in about five minutes I missed my gown, and the lace was gone.

JOHN SYMONDS
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a gown, pawned on the 22d of August, by Mary Ann Carroll, to the best of my knowledge, in the name of Mary Carroll.

TIMOTHY RYAN
. I am a watchman. On the 22d of August the prosecutrix took me to her house to take the two prisoners - I found no property or duplicates on them- this nett was sent to Marlborough-street, by a woman - the prosecutrix said if they would send it back she would forgive them.
NOT GUILTY .
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1649.
LOUISA DOVER
and
SUSAN HAMMOND
were indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , 5 silk handkerchiefs, value 16s. , the goods of
John Graham
.

EDWARD BOYLE
. I am shopman to Mr. Graham, linen-draper , of High Holborn
. On the 22d of July the prisoners came together to the shop, and asked to look at some silk handkerchiefs which were in the window - I was in the shop, and they looked at them a long time before they attempted to purchase; a fellow-shopman was serving them; I saw Dover put one piece under her shawl; they continued to look at them a little longer - when I saw them going out I took hold of Dover, and said, "Are you not ashamed of yourself?" she then took it from under her shawl, and said, "If you will let me go, I will buy it of you;" Hammond might not have seen what was going on.

SAMUEL FURZMAN
. I am watch-house keeper - the prisoners were brought to me.(Property produced and sworn to.)

DOVER's Defence. I called on this young woman to go and buy a handkerchief; I took one piece and went to the door to see what pattern they were, and this young man took me by the arm, and sent for the street-keeper.

DOVER -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

HAMMOND -
NOT GUILTY .

1650.
SARAH GRAY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 gown, value 5s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Harvey
, spinster , now the wife of
George Garskin
.

ELIZABETH GARSKIN. I am now the wife of George Garskin. I lost a gown on the 6th of August; at that time my name was Harvey, and I was living with Mr. Richmond, Ray-street
, and lost this gown from there; I know nothing of the prisoner.

MARY RICHMOND
. I keep a cook-shop in Ray-street. I saw Garskin's gown hanging on the bedstead on the 6th of August - it was found at the pawnbrokers on the 7th; my shop door was open - there is a communication to the upper rooms, through the parlour.

JOHN BOWYER
. I am a constable; at a quarter before eight o'clock, on the 17th of August, I took the prisoner - she denied the charge.

THOMAS CARPENTER
. I am servant to Mr. Cross, of Turner-street, pawnbroker. I have a gown pawned by the prisoner, on Saturday, the 5th of August, in the name of Flower.

Prisoner's Defence. I was on Clerkenwell-green, and met a woman who said she was in great distress, and wanted to sell a gown - she said she would let me have it for 4s.; I said she had better pawn it - she said she would rather sell it; I bought it of her, and then, to regain my money, pawned it - in a few days afterwards I went to pawn my shawl, and was stopped.
NOT GUILTY .

1651.
JANE GRAHAM
was indicted for
stealing, on 28th of August , 1 sheet, value 4s., and 2 night-gowns, value 4s. , the goods of
Benjamin Hatchard
.

MARY ANN SADLER
. I am servant to Mr. Benjamin Hatchard; Mrs. Bulmar washes for them. On Monday, the 28th of August, the prisoner, who is the daughter of Mrs. Bulmar, came for the linen as from her mother, and I delivered the sheet and night gowns to her; on the Tuesday her mother came for the things as usual - I told her I had delivered them to her daughter.

ELIZABETH BULMAR
. I have washed for Mr. Hatchard some time - the prisoner is my daughter; I did not send her on the 28th of August for Mr. Hatchard's washing; she had been a few days from home; I never received the articles, nor sent her for them.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker, and live in Chapel-street, Westminster. I received, from the prisoner and another young woman, two night-gowns and a sheet, for half-a-crown; the prisoner told me it was her mother's - she gave the name of the person who was with her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Confined Three Months .

1652.
WILLIAM HAZELL
,
STEPHEN TRINDELL
and
SAMUEL FARIS
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 1 gown, value 12s.; 2 aprons, value 1s., 1 pair of stockings, value 1s.; 1 petticoat, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 4d.; 1 cap, value 6d.; 1 shift, value 2d.; 1 snuff-box, value 6d.; 1 book, value 4d., and 1l shillings, the property of
Margaret Williams
, spinster , and 15 shillings , the monies of
Mary Ann Humphries
, spinster .

MARGARET WILLIAMS. On the 12th of August, I was going to Wales with Mary Ann Humphries - we were togo by Turner and Bailey's waggon; we went to the White Horse-cellar - I had my property in a small deal-trunk, and fifteen shillings of Mary Ann Humphries' were in it; I had put the things in, but my mother packed it up - the waggon was gone, and my mother, I, and Mary Ann Humphries, went in the Southampton waggon to overtake it; I saw my trunk put into the waggon we went by; we went in at half-past ten o'clock at night, and got on to Hounslow at half-past two in the morning - we then went into a public-house, and three men, not the prisoners, followed us out - the waggoner gave a waggoner a shilling to take us to Staines; we waited there to see if Turner's waggon came; we then went to Colnbrook, to the Punch Bowl, public-house
- I had my trunk on the seat; the three prisoners came in, and sat on the seat opposite us; Trindell leaned his arm on my trunk, and asked if I was afaid to trust him - I told him I wanted to get something out of it - he let me have it - I opened it, and took a shilling out, and then fastened it with a bit of rope - I asked Hazell for a knife to cut it with; the waggoner came by at half-past eight o'clock - I went out with Mary Ann Humphries, to see if it was the right waggon - we left the trunk in the house, and when we had been out about five minutes, Hazell came and brought it out, and gave it to Faris, and told him to give it to us to put into the waggon; Trindell then came out and accused Mary Ann Humphries of robbing him of 15s.; he used shocking language, and said she should not go away; while this quarrel was going on Faris had taken the box through the turnpike, and Hazell was in the public-house; the waggon went on, and I went to run after Faris - a gentleman of the name of Cox came up, he said he would go after him; a young man brought me the trunk afterwards - and then Hazell said he would show us where Faris lived - we went there, but he had not come home.

JOSEPH SAWYER
. I am a horse-patrol. At half-past nine o'clock, on the day in question, I was on the Bath-road - Mr. Cox came and informed me of the robbery - I went in pursuit, and overtook Trindell in the road to Staines - I asked him what had happened, and where the girls were who he had been in company with; he said they were gone down the lane with three gipsies; I went down the lane, and found them with the gipsies; I turned back, and brought Trindell back to the place; the landlord said,"Here is a man here who owns to taking the box, and giving it to another man;" Hazell then came out and said he had given it to Faris; one Goodman, who was bound over, but is not here, brought me the box in the morning.

WILLIAM COURTNEY
. I keep the Punch Bowl at Colnbrook. The young women came to my house - the three prisoners came in, and when the waggon was coming they brought out the box - I went and asked them if they had got all right; they said, Yes.

MARY ROBINSON
. I live at the Punch Bowl. I saw Faris come out with the box, and go through the turnpike-gate - it was a small deal trunk.
Cross-examined by Mr. BRODRICK. Q. How far was the turnpike? A. Close by.

MARY ANN HUMPHRIES. I was with Williams, and had 15s. in the box; she has stated the truth. I saw Hazell bring the box to Faris - we went home with the horse-patrol; and the next morning the box was brought there by
William Goodman
.
NOT GUILTY .

1688.
WILLIAM SANDERS
was indicted for
embezzling, on the 27th of July , 5 shillings and a sixpence .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM JOHN HADDON
. I keep the Bell brew-house, at Tottenham
; the prisoner was in my employ in June last; it was his duty to deliver beer and receive money for me. On the 27th of June he was sent out with some beer; there were fourteen firkins, but I cannot tell how many casks - I had no customer of the name of Parker, to my knowledge, he never gave me any account of any money received from a Mrs. Parker.

Cross-examined by Mr. ANDREWS. Q. Did you, with your own hand, measure the fourteen firkins of beer he took out? A. No; it was the duty of my clerk to do it; it is my clerk's business to count the casks, and when he returns, he gives an account of it - I took him before the Justice, about this 5s. 6d., without asking him about the matter; but this 5s. 6d. was not the only ground of complaint I had against him - I had received a letter before I went to the Magistrate.

JAMES SHARP
. I am clerk to Mr. Haddon. I remember the prisoner going out on the 27th of June; I can tell by the book what beer he took out - it is put down every morning, and he signs it, and gives an account when he returns. On that day he took out twenty-five casks of different dimensions, containing beer and ale; there was some of it be-spoke; he brought back an account at night - but there was a deficiency of nine gallons of table ale - he did not account for any thing delivered to Mrs. Parker, her name is not mentioned, she had never been a customer of ours.

Cross-examined. Q. You take an account when he goes out and when he comes in? A. Yes; it was not till a letter came from Mrs. Paker that we found there was some deficiency - he was authorized to sell beer to any body, if he brought the money; but he gave no account of this.

Mr. ADOLPHUS. Q. He accounted for the whole of the casks, but did he account for all the money? A. No, there was a deficiency of 5s. 6d.; it was a nine gallon cask of table-ale; which I afterwards saw at Mrs. Parker's - he accounted for all but that - he had accounted for the casks sent out, so that it was a deficiency, in the value of the beer, of 5s. 6d.; I did not discover this till the letter came a fortnight afterwards.

ELIZABETH ANN PARKER
. I live at Hackney. On the 27th of June I purchased, of the prisoner, a nine gallon cask of beer, for which I paid him 5s. 6d. in silver - I believe it was five shillings and a sixpence; there were some shillings - this is the receipt he gave me (read) - I had never before bought any beer of Mr. Haddon or of the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you certain you did not give him a piece of gold, and receive the change? A. Yes; we were out of beer; my servant saw him, and we bought of him; I heard him tell the Magistrate it must have arisen from mistake my being an accidental customer.
Prisoner's Defence. I had fifty or sixty customers toserve in a day, and this must have been put down to an old customer by mistake.

JURY to
JAMES SHARPE
. Q. Was it customary for him to take down in writing the casks he sold? A. Yes; he had a book for that purpose, and I have it here; this is his writing - this is the money he received, but here is none to Mrs. Parker - it was customary with him to enter it at the time he received it.
NOT GUILTY .

1654.
WILLIAM SANDERS
was again indicted for a
like offence .

WILLIAM JOHN HADDON
. The prisoner was my servant ; I received this letter from Mrs. Parker, and sent my clerk to her house; I had no knowledge of the existence of such a person before I received the letter.
Cross-examined by Mr. ANDREWS. Q. Where was the prisoner when the warrant was executed? A. In the brew-house yard - he had no previous notice of it.

JAMES SHARP
. It was the prisoner's duty to carry out beer, and to account to me in the evening for what he had received; it was the custom to deliver to the draymen these cheques to take out with the beer - this pile of cheques is his hand-writing, down to the 15th of June last, but those since then are not written on - he kept them till the book was full, and then returned it; I sent him out on the 11th of July; he did not account to me on that day for 5s. 6d. received from Parker; here is his book of that day, but no entry of this kind; on the 13th of July we received a letter, complaining of the beer, and desiring it might be changed - in consequence of this, I went there, and found a nine-gallon cask belonging to our brewery.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you go yourself in consequence of this letter? A. Yes; and the beer was changed; it was not my duty to call on the prisoner to account for it, but to report it to Mr. Haddon.

ELIZABETH ANN PARKER
. On the 11th of July I purchased a cask of beer of the prisoner, and paid him in silver; I paid him some shillings; I received this receipt for it. - (read.)

Cross-examined. Q. You trust to your memory, I suppose, when you say you believe it was paid in shillings? A. I am sure of it; I did not ask him for a receipt with his master's name on it; he did not say, "If the beer is bad do not write to me or my master," but he gave me this printed receipt.
Prisoner's Defence. I have so many customers, that I am obliged to put it down going along, and on a wet day it is very troublesome; it must have been booked to some old customer.
JURY to JAMES SHARP. Q. How came you not to complain of his not filling up these books of receipts? A. We do not examine the book till it is quite full; what he collected was more than 1000l. a year.
GUILTY . Aged 39.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Confined Three Months .

1655.
THOMAS SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of May , 1 hammer, value 4s., and 1 pair of pincers, value 3s. , the goods of
William Jones
.

WILLIAM JONES. I am a couch and sofa bedstead-maker , and live in Meed-street
. The prisoner was my journeyman ; these tools were on the bench; I missed the tools on the 24th of May; I had not seen the prisoner for a month before he was taken; I never suffered him to take them.

THOMAS BAYLIS
. I am employed by Mr. Attenborough, a pawnbroker. I have some tools, pawned at our house, in the name of Smart, but I cannot swear to the prisoner.

THOMAS WELLS
. I am a japanner. I was going to Jones' house, to work, on the 24th of May, and saw the prisoner running along; I said, "Where are you going?" he said, to Shoreditch. I saw him drop a pair of pincers, which he picked up; I went to Mr. Jones', and found the things had been stolen; no other man worked there but myself.

SARAH JONES
. I am the wife of
William Jones
. I was standing at the door on the 24th of May - the prisoner was working with the hammer and pincers - I told him to be careful of them, and the moment he was gone I missed them.

Prisoner's Defence. I never intended to steal them. - Mr. Jones and I had a few words in the morning, which induced me to leave; he went to Paddington, and said he would prosecute me to the utmost, and I was afraid to go back.
GUILTY . Aged 21.

Recommended to Mercy -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1656.
SUSAN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of August , 1 sheet, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
John Stott
, in a lodging-room .

JOHN STOTT. I keep a lodging-house , in the New-way, Westminster
. I let a room, furnished, to the prisoner, at 4s. per week; she was there about eight weeks - she paid me the rent sometimes, but the last time I went to her for 5s. 6d., she said, "I have not got it for you, Stott"- I said, "I must have it;" I went out in a passion, and she got up out of bed, and took all her things away - I got a constable, who took her close by; she said she had done it, and the duplicate was in the room.

WILLIAM PATMORE
. I am a constable. The prisoner told me the duplicate was on the table, but it had fallen on the floor.

LEONARD GEORGE NEEDS
. I live with Messrs. Graham and Stock, of Tothill-street, pawnbrokers. I have a sheet, pawned on the 11th of August, by the prisoner, for 2s.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I pawned the sheet - he came for my money; I went out to get some money to redeem the sheet, and when I came back, he had broken into my room.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Confined Twelve Days .
SEVENTH DAY. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 21.
Third Middlesex Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1657.
MARTIN PALFRIN
and
JOHN CARRON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
Joseph Moore
, from his person .

JOSEPH MOORE. On the 25th of July I was in Southampton-row
- a person gave me information, and I missed my handkerchief, which I had used immediately before. I turned round, and found it in the possession of Palfrin; Carron was behind, but I did not see him till he was in custody.

THOMAS BELLINGHAM
. I am a tailor, and live in Southampton-row. I saw Moore pass my door, and Carron was following close at his heels - I saw Palfrin on his left; Carron took the handkerchief from Moore's pocket, and gave it to Palfrin - I am certain of their persons; I went and took them.
Prisoner CARRON. He was looking through the glass door. Witness. No, my door was open.

ROBERT DUKE
. I am the officer, and took the prisoners.(Property produced and sworn to.)

PALFRIN -
GUILTY . Aged 16.

CARRON -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1658.
WILLIAM SEDGWICK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July , 1 coat, value 4s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Stewart
, widow .
SECOND COURT, stating it to belong to a person unknown.

ROBERT CARTER
. I live with Mr. Gulston, at the Feathers public-house, at Milbank
. On the 10th of July I saw some persons in a boat; some of whom fell over and were drowned; the others were brought on shore by the watermen; they were very wet, and were taken to Mr. Gulston's; there was a coat left in the boat; I saw the prisoner step to the boat, and take it out, and walk with it towards our skittle-ground, and then through the half-hatch; I had seen him before, and knew him. The waterman said he could not stop, he must go with his fare - the next night, when I was out with my beer, he met me, and said, if I said any thing about it, he would knock my bl-y thundering head off.

WILLIAM BLUNDLE
. I was in the boat on the 10th of July, with my brother-in-law, named Stewart; he was drowned; his coat was left in the boat; he had pulled it off to row; there was no other coat in the boat; it has not been found.

JOHN WARREN
. I took up the prisoner; he said nothing to me; I could not find the waterman.

Prisoner's Defence. I saw the men fall out of the boat; I handed the coat up to one of the gentlemen who was leading that witness up to the house; I never went away till the man was found who had been drowned.
NOT GUILTY .

1659.
JAMES ROSE
was indicted for
embezzlement . MR. ANDREWS declined offering any evidence.
NOT GUILTY .

1660.
GEORGE SMITH
and
THOMAS DOWSETT
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 2 hams, value 28s. , the goods of
Samuel Brown
.

SAMUEL BROWN. I am a cheesemonger , and live in Whitechapel
. I lost two hams from my shop-window while I was absent.

WILLIAM MACKEY
. I live nearly opposite to Mr. Brown. On the 28th of June I saw Smith and another person, who is not here, go up to the shop; Smith took a ham from the window, - they walked up Angel-alley - Smith then came again with Dowsett, who took another ham; they walked off; I spoke to a person, who went and told Mr. Brown's shopman of it - next morning they passed my house, and crossed over; the officer was there, and took them; I knew both their persons well.

CHARLES READ
. Mackey told me the hams were stolen, and I saw the prisoners again in the road; I ran to the shop and asked if they were the two persons, and I took them.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

DOWSETT -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .

1661.
JOSEPH SHENSTON
and
ROBERT FITZGERALD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 2lbs. and 6ozs. weight of tea, value 3s. , the goods of the United Company of Merchants, trading to the East Indies
.
MESSRS. BOLLAND and LAW conducted the prosecution.

SAMUEL BALL
. I am assistant elder at the East India-house. On the 19th of July, in consequence of information, I directed Gale to watch in a warehouse.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Is it not customary to search every body who goes out? A. Yes; but they might conceal tea, as they are not rubbed down indecently.

GEORGE WARREN GALE
. I am a labourer to the East India Company; the prisoners are also labourer
s. On the 19th of July Ball desired me to watch; I examined the contents of a handkerchief and bag, which were on a pile of chest tops; they both contained black tea - at twenty minutes past ten o'clock I heard two persons in the passage, between the chests, and in an instant I saw Shenston come to this place; he took the handkerchief of tea, and put it into his hat; he went to the top of the alley, and said to Fitzgerald "All right" - Fitzgerald then came and took the bag; I went away, and informed Mr. Ball, and a constable was sent for.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did you mark the bag in which you say the tea was? A. No; three men have been dismissed from the warehouse.

JOHN GIBBS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoners into custody; I found Shenston at work in the third floor, mending a chest - I went down to take Fitzgerald, but he was gone to the privy - I saw frost search Shenston; he put his hat down, and I found this handkerchief in it, with this 2lbs. 6ozs. of tea in it - he said, it was his hat and handkerchief; he wanted the handkerchief back - I then fetched Fitzgerald from the privy, and found in his pocket this bag, with a few grains of tea in it.
Cross-examined by Mr. ALLEY. Q. Was not the part of the warehouse in which you searched him, in the City? A. No.

WILLIAM FROST
. I saw this tea found in Shenston's hat; I took these two small bags out of Shenston's trousers pocket, and I saw another bag taken from him by Gibbs, with a few grains of tea in it.
Prisoner SHENSTON to GIBBS. Q. Was there not ahesitation as to who the hat belonged to? A. No; you said it was yours.
Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Are not these bags used for the men to bring their victuals in? A. No; they are smaller bags; this would hold 5lbs. of tea.

SHENSTON -
GUILTY . Aged 32.

FITZGERALD -
GUILTY . Aged 26.

Recommended to Mercy by the Jury -
Confined One Year .

1662.
JAMES MALONEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 1 shirt, value 2s.; 1 hat, value 3s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; 1 shawl, value 2s.; 1 sheet, value 3s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 2s. , the goods of
Cornelius Gore
.

CORNELIUS GORE. I live in Cato-street
. I missed this property on Monday week last; and on the following morning, at nine o'clock, I met the prisoner in Langham-place, and found it all in his possession - I asked how he came by them; he made no answer; I took him to the watch-house.

ELEANOR GORE
. I am the prosecutor's wife - the prisoner slept at our house on this night; the things hung on a line in his room, at six o'clock that evening - the hat hung in the same room - at seven o'clock in the morning he was gone, and I missed them.

ROBERT WILLIAMS
. I am an officer. I took him into custody at a cook's-shop.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .

1663.
MARY WEST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of June , 1 gown, value 6s., and 2 caps, value 4s. , the goods of
James Carrol
.

ESTHER CARROL
. I am the wife of James Carrol - we live in Vine-street, Westminster
. On the 28th of June I went out at twelve o'clock, and told Webber, who lives opposite, to watch my room - the door was not locked - I fastened the latch with a nail - when I returned, at one o'clock, I saw the prisoner coming out of the street-door with a bundle; I knew her before I found my door ajar, and missed these things.

SARAH WEBBER
. I was left in charge of the room, and went out at half-past twelve o'clock - next morning I met the prisoner in the Broad-way, and followed her to Harris' the pawnbroker; I went in and had her detained.

JOHN JACKSON
. I am shopman to Harris. About four o'clock this gown was pledged by a female, about the prisoner's size.

JAMES PATMORE
. I took her in charge, and found the cap on her head.
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1664.
MATHEW NORMAN
,
PHILIP OLIVER
and
PATRICK BRYAN
, were indicted for
stealing on the 24th of August , 1 wrapper, value 6d., and 2 table-cloths, value 16s., the goods of
John Connor
, from the person of Eleanor, his wife .

ELEANOR CONNOR
. I am the wife of John Connor. On the 24th of August, at night, I was in Buckridge-street
, and had two table-cloths in a wrapper; they were snatched from me - I thought the boys who did it were taller than the prisoners - I have bad eyes - I think the person who snatched them threw them down a cellar - I think there was a man, who received them - I believe they ran away, but I did not see them.
Q. Did you see them thrown down the cellar? A. I think they were, but it was very dark - the persons got away - I have not found the property.

WILLIAM BISHOP
. I heard of the prosecutrix being robbed - and on the 25th of the watchman brought Bryan to me, with the prosecutrix - she said in his presence, "This is one of the boys who robbed me last night of the tablecloths" - I said, "Are you sure of that?" - she said, Yes, and she knew the others, and mentioned their names - I then asked, if he was the boy who took it out of her hand - she said, "No, but he ran away with it." - I did not lock him up, but sent her to get the others; and in the morning, from information Bryan gave me, I went and took Norman and Oliver out of bed - Bryan was with me, and said, in their presence, "It was Norman took the bundle from Mrs. Connor, and threw it down the tinker's cellar" - Oliver and Norman said Bryan took it - Connor said, in their presence, that they were the boys who took it, and they did not deny it, but said the tinker had the property; I did not see the prosecutrix on the night of the robbery - her husband told me, the boys' parents had been and made it up.

CATHERINE McGRATH
. This business was settled in my apartment, and the prosecutrix promised not to come here. I know the prisoners and their parents.

The prisoners put in a joint written Defence, stating, that the prosecutrix had offered Norman 1s. to lay the charge upon the other prisoners, since which she had been paid for the property by their friends.

NORMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 11.

OLIVER -
GUILTY . Aged 13.

BRYAN -
GUILTY . Aged 13.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1667
JOHN BUDD TARRELL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of August , 1 coat, value 10s., and 1 waistcoat, value 5s. , the goods of
John Peters
.

JAMES WADE
. I am a fireman at the London-docks
. On the 16th of August, about ten o'clock, I saw the prisoner go on board the Susannah, where I was at work;(John Peters is the mate ) he came away in ten minutes; I called to Peters, and asked if he knew him - he said, No; we followed him - he saw us, and ran off - we overtook him, and found he had Peters' coat and waistcoat on, under his own; he said he took them from the cabin; Peters claimed them - he went down in the cabin and pulled them off - but not in my presence.

THOMAS BOLTEN
. I am an officer. Peters gave me the clothes.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Confined Three Months .

1666.
JOHN SHERWOOD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of July , 1 hat, value 2s., the goods of
William John Sarson
, from his person .

WILLIAM JOHN SARSON. On the 15th July, about fouro'clock, I was in Hyde-park
- I fell asleep; I pulled off my hat, and put it behind me - a gentleman came and said it was gone; I then saw the prisoner running away with it; I saw it thrown away afterwards, but cannot say that he threw it - I had seen him with it.

JOHN WILKINS
. I belong to Bow-street Office. I saw the prisoner running without a hat - this hat was produced in a few minutes by a person.
NOT GUILTY .

1667.
WILLIAM BARTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 23 yards of calico, value 39s., the goods of
Thomas Bew
, privately in his shop .

CHARLES DAVIS
. I am shopman to Thomas Bew, a linen-draper , of Pimlico-terrace
. The prisoner came to the shop and looked at this calico, among several other articles - he wanted three yards of calico for a shilling - I refused; he was there a quarter of an hour, and went out; we then missed the calico, and went after him; it was found in his basket - he said it must have fallen into his basket.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. He came back quietly; A. Yes - a great many pieces of calico were on the counter, and several persons had passed; the prisoner said where he lived, and how he got his living, which we found correct; my mistress was called down, and said it might be an accident.
NOT GUILTY .

1668.
ANN RANSOM
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 28 yards of cotton, value 30s., the goods of
Joseph Lee
, privately in his shop .

JOSEPH LEE. I keep a linen-draper's shop , in Upper-street, Islington
. On the 15th of August I missed two pieces of cotton, which were safe about a week before; I found them in pawn at Cross'; the prisoner came to the shop on the 21st of August - I asked her what she had taken from me; she said she only took one piece, and pawned it at Cross'; I detained her.

THOMAS LINSCOTT
. I am shopman to Mr. Cross; the prisoner pawned this piece of cotton.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know they were stolen; the girl who was with me gave me them to pawn.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Confined Six Months .

1669.
GEORGE SMITH
and
FRANCIS WILSON
were indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 ring value 15s., the goods of
William Newby
, privately in his shop .

WILLIAM NEWBY. I am a silversmith , and live in Southampton-row, Bloomsbury
. On the 28th of August my shop bell rang - I came down, and my man said he had lost a gold seal - the prisoners were then in the shop a constable was fetched and searched them; the seal was not found, but I saw Smith put this ring on the counter; I took it up - he said, "Here is a ring of yours;" he then said, "It is not yours, it is my wife's."

JOHN SIMMONS
. I am in Mr. Newby's employ. Smith came in and asked to see some wedding-rings, which were shown him; Wilson then came in, and joined him in conversation; they then asked to see some seals and keys - they had selected a ring, but not paid for it; I suspected them, and shut the door; I saw Smith take a seal and put it up his sleeve; I then rang the bell - Mr. Newby came down, and an officer was fetched; I saw Smith put the ring on the counter, saying, "Here is a ring of your's;" it was not the ring they had selected.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Did they see you ring the bell? A. Yes; they attempted to get away - Wilson broke a pane of glass - only 1d. was found on them - a 6d. laid on the counter.

SAMUEL SKELTON
. I am an officer. I found the prisoners in the shop - found 1d. on them and no more; I did not see the ring put down; I heard Smith say it was his wife's; they said, if they had broken the glass, they would pay for it.
SMITH's Defence. I met this man, and asked him to go in there and buy a ring; I said, I thought one would do but I would go and measure my wife's finger, and then he missed the seal.
WILSON's Defence. I went in with him, but was not near the counter.

SMITH -
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Transported for Seven Years .

WILSON -
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined Six Months .

1670.
SAMUEL WOOD
and
JOHN WOOD
were indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , 2 dishes, value 1l.; 2 silver butter-boats, value 1l.; 5 spoons, value 12s., and 1 pair of sugar-tongs, value 2s. , the goods of a person unknown
.

JOSEPH CADBY
. I am street-keeper to the Foundling estate
. On the morning of the 3d of July I saw the prisoners with another person; I followed them, and saw the one who is not here, trying different area gates - each had a basket; I saw Wood go down some areas with one of their baskets, and when he returned he joined them, and returned the basket; they went off the estate; the same afternoon, at two o'clock, I saw them again: Samuel had two baskets, one in the other - they appeared heavy; I went up suddenly, and took Samuel - he scuffled and got from me, and threw the baskets at me; I called Stop thief! and Morley took Samuel - Avery took John; the basket contained the articles stated in the indictment - Samuel said he found them and was going to Hatton-garden.

WILLIAM AVERY
. I heard a cry of Stop thief! the first person who ran up to me was John Wood; I secured him - he tried to get away.

ISAAC MORLEY
. I heard a cry of Stop thief! - I saw Samuel Wood running, and secured him.
SAMUEL WOOD's Defence. I found it in the middle of the road, and was taking it to the office.

SAMUEL WOOD -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

JOHN WOOD -
NOT GUILTY .

1671.
JOHN RYALS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , 1 trowel, value 1s. 3d., and 1 hammer, value 1s. 3d., the goods of
William Chillingworth
, and 1 trowel, value 1s. 3d. , the goods of
Ralph Chillingworth
.

WILLIAM CHILLINGWORTH. I am a journeyman plasterer , and was working at Mr. Wilson's, Barnsbury-park
.On the 21st of August I left these tools in the back parlour; I returned at half-past eight o'clock, and missed them - I found the prisoner behind a door, which leads to the roof of the kitchen with them.
RALPH CHILLINGWORTH. I was working at this house, which was unfinished - we had fastened the doors, and found one open.

ROBERT BROWN
. I took the prisoner - he said necessity drove him to it, and he wished to be transported.
Prisoner's Defence. I was in great distress; I went there to lay down, and saw a man, who gave me the things.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Whipped and Discharged .

1672.
ANN MILLER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 bonnet, value 2s. , the goods of
John Cox
.

SARAH COX
. I am the wife of John Cox, and live at Lisson-grove
; my husband worked for the prisoner. On the 17th of August I locked up my house and took the key; I returned in half an hour, and missed this bonnet out of a box - I found the prisoner selling it, and asked how she came to do so, when I had been so good to her child.

HENRY RICHARD BUCKERIDGE
. I took her in charge. The person, who was buying the hat, has run away.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the hat till I saw it in her hands.
NOT GUILTY .

1673.
CORNELIUS McCOY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of July , 1 handkerchief value 4s. , the goods of
John Humphries
.
JOHN HUMPHRIES. My son had been bathing in the canal, on the 30th of July - he had a handkerchief when he went out, and returned without it.

WILLIAM HUMPHRIES
. I went to bathe. I left my father's handkerchief in my hat, by the side of the Regent's-canal, near Primrose-hill
- my cousin called me out, and said the prisoner had robbed me.

JOHN ADDERLEY
. I was by the side of the canal, and saw the prisoner take the handkerchief out of the hat, and ran away - some other boys were about - I saw him fold it up and give it to some one - he stood still, and I gave an alarm.

JOHN HURWORTH
. I was on the opposite bank, and saw the prisoner get out of the canal naked, and take the handkerchief; I did not see what he did with it; he ran among about a dozen others, some of whom were naked - I secured him; he was then dressed - he said he had taken it, and given it to some person, whose name I do not remember - he afterwards refused to tell the name - I am certain he is the boy.

JOSEPH KINGSTON
. I am an officer, and received him in charge; he said he had given the handkerchief to another person, but would not tell me who; he said, at the watch-house, that he would rather be lagged for seven years, than he would split.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1674.
SAMUEL MESFIELD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , 1 coat, value 5s. , the goods of
George Pritchard
.

GEORGE PRITCHARD. On the 31st of July I was bathing near Maiden-lane-bridge
, and lost my coat from the bank - I saw the prisoner put it on and walk away - I got out, and called Stop thief! he pulled it off and ran away - I saw him in custody.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. What time was this? A. About eight o'clock; he had no other coat on.

SAMUEL STEVENS
. I apprehended him.
Prisoner's Defence. I had been bathing in the morning, and lost my coat; and in the evening I went and took this.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1675.
WILLIAM LILLYWHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of September
, 2 rings, value 8s.; 6 tea spoons, value 10s., and 1 pair of sugar tongs, value 2s. , the goods of
Thomas Burchall
; and
ANN LILLYWHITE
was indicted for
feloniously receiving the same .

ALICE BURCHALL
. I am the wife of Thomas Burchall, a plasterer ; we were in possession of a house, No. 42, York-terrace
. On the 9th of September the prisoner, William, was working there as a painter
; and on that day I missed this plate, which I had seen safe on the 4th, in a chest in the kitchen; the key was left in it.
Prisoner WILLIAM LILLYWHITE. Q. Was nobody else in the house? A. There were two plumbers, but they were in my presence all the time - I went out for five minutes and left the prisoner there.

JOHN LIMBRIC
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner on the 9th of September; he denied the charge; Burchall said there had been nobody else in the house, and that when she went out he shut the door and kept her out; I went to No. 13, Crown-street, where he lived, and found his wife, who afterwards produced some duplicates - I asked if she had nothing else - she said No - I saw something in her hand, and found a purse, containing the duplicate of two rings - she said her husband gave them to her.

THOMAS BLACKMAN
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 7th of September the female prisoner pawned the rings.(Property produced and sworn to.)
WILLIAM LILLYWHITE's Defence. There were various workmen in the place; one was there an hour and a half; I can prove we have had the rings two years.

WILLIAM LILLYWHITE -
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

ANN LILLYWHITE -
NOT GUILTY .

1676.
SARAH MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of August , 2 sheets, value 5s., the goods of
William Williams
, in a lodging-room .

MARY ANN WILLIAMS
. I am the wife of William Williams. I let a room to the prisoner and her husband the beginning of July last; her husband absconded a a week before she left the room - I went in and found the sheets were gone, which I had let with the lodging.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned these sheets with me.

THOMAS DAGNALL
. I am an officer. I took up the prisoner - she said she had pawned the sheets, but wished her husband to know nothing about them.
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 36.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1677. MARGARET DREW
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , 1 shirt, value 3s., and 1 sheet, value 12s., the goods of
Godfrey Lazarus
, his master .

GODFREY LAZARUS. I am a jeweller ; the prisoner was my servant . On the 5th of August there was a fire, and the prisoner was taken on suspicion of setting the house on fire; but her innocence has been clearly proved - I afterwards searched her box, and found duplicates of this property.

WILLIAM WESTON
. I am a pawnbroker. These articles were pawned by a woman, in the name of Drew.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that she could not obtain her wages, and that Mrs. Lazarus had sent her to pawn the goods.
GODFREY LAZARUS re-examined. I never sent her to pawn things. I owed her five months wages - she said she did it because her father was in distress.

FRANCES MARY LYONS
. I am the prisoner's sister. - I heard Mrs. Lazarus tell her, on the 1st of May, to pawn a coat and trousers, or to sell them, in part of her wages.
NOT GUILTY .

1678.
JOSEPH WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 2 quires of paper, value 2s., the goods of
John Lewis Cox
, his master .

JOHN HAYES
. I am foreman to John Lewis Cox, of Turnstile, Holborn
. I have the care of the paper-room; the prisoner asked me to let him go there for paper which he wanted for his work; when he came out I missed two quires, and told him he had got them - he said he had not, but afterwards produced them from the legs of his trousers; he bore a good character, and, I believe, was in distress, as he had lately got married.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Two Months .

1679.
SAMUEL MARTIN
was indicted for
embezzlement .

WILLIAM NORMAN
. I am a baker . The prisoner was in my employ, and received money on my account, which he should pay me every night. On the 19th of June he settled with me, but did not pay me 10s. on account of King.

ELIZABETH KING
. I paid the prisoner, on the 19th of June, in the morning, 10s., for Norman - there were two half-crowns, and five shillings - he wrote a receipt.

BENJAMIN SCHOFIELD
. I apprehended him on the 10th of August - he acknowledged the charge.
Prisoner's Defence. It must have been an error.
GUILTY . Aged 37.

1680.
THOMAS JOHN KINGSTON
was indicted for
embezzlement .

CHARLES WILLIAM GOLDING
. I am the son of
Elizabeth Golding
, a cheesemonger , who lives in Whitechapel-road
. The prisoner was our errand-boy , and received money - he should account for it directly. On the 22d of July I sent him to Mrs. Riddle, with goods, and gave him a bill, which amounted to 3l. 19s. 11d. - on his return he paid me 1l. short, and said he was certain it was all that she gave him; I entered it on account. On the Wednesday Mrs. Riddle was at our house; he persisted that it was all she gave him.
Cross-examined by MR. BRODRICK. Q. I believe the matter rested two or three days? A. Yes - I think it was a mistake.

SARAH RIDDLE
. I paid the prisoner three sovereigns and 19s.; he wrote a receipt, and put the money into his right-hand pocket; he went for change for sixpence, and when he returned he said I had only given him two sovereigns; I had told him to count it when I paid it him.
Cross-examined. Q. Was not the money left on the counter while he went for change? A. The silver was - I do not know about the sovereigns; two people were in my shop.

LUCY RICKETT
. I stood at the counter, and saw Riddle put down three sovereigns; I was called away, and did not see the silver.
Cross-examined. Q. Was it not one sovereign and two half-sovereigns? A. No.
CHARLES WILLIAM GOLDING. He brought me one sovereign and two half-sovereigns.
NOT GUILTY .

1681.
JOHN FLETCHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 2 tubs, value 2s., and 190lbs. weight of butter, value 9l. , the goods of
Ralph Mould
and others, his partners.
TWO OTHER COUNTS, stating it to belong to other persons.

THOMAS IVEMY
. I am a carrier. On the evening of the 14th of September Mr. Mould's man delivered me three tubs of butter; I tied two behind my cart, and put the other inside; I stopped in Lisle-street
, and saw it all safe, but before I got to the end of the street my cart seemed lighter - I got down, and the two tubs were gone; the rope had been cut; I ran, and met a man, who gave me information - and in Leicester-square I saw the prisoner running, with a tub on his shoulder; I stopped him; he said he got it from a gentleman's door, in Lisle-street; this was within two minutes of my missing it.

HAMMOND WEBB
. I received him in charge, and found a knife on him, with a direction, which had been on the tub. The knife had a piece of the rope on it.

ROBERT QUADBURY
. I received him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up at the step of a door.
THOMAS IVEMY. It was a very wet night, the tub was quite dry.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1682.
WILLIAM CROWTHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 coat, value 5s. , the goods of
Edward Lidyard
.

EDWARD LIDYARD. I am a butcher , and live at Portland-town
. The prisoner was at my house, with his mother, on the morning of the 19th of August - I missed a great coat from a room up stairs; he and his mother came home at night; he had this great coat and some other things; I asked why he took it - he gave no answer.

HUMPHRIES ROBERTS
. I took him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Transported for Seven Years .

1683.
SARAH CHAMBERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
Edward Healy
.

HARRIET BOWSER
. I live with my brother, Edward Healy, a shoe-maker , in Holborn
. On the 19th of August I saw the prisoner in the shop, about twelve o'clock - she said she was a servant , and her mistress had sent her to buy a pair of shoes; she brought a pair, as a pattern; I missed a pair from a parcel of eight, and accused her of it - she said she was surprised at me - I called my brother, who sent for an officer - they were found under her dress.

JOHN WOODWARD
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner take the shoes from under her dress.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1684.
JOHN CONNORY
and
STEPHEN KEEFE
were indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
William Lobb
, from his person .

WILLIAM LOBB. I am a surgeon . I was in Lincoln's Inn-fields
on the 27th of June, and was informed I had lost a handkerchief; I turned round, and it was produced to me, but I did not see the prisoners.

JESSEE PHILLIPS
. I am a glassman, and live in Queen-street, Lincoln's Inn-fields. I saw the prisoners following Mr. Lobb, who was with a lady, by my door - I followed them about twenty yards and saw Keefe take the handkerchief from his pocket, and give it to Connory, who put it into his pocket. I secured them both, and gave them to my father, who took it from Connory, while I went to Mr. Lobb.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do not you very often come here as a witness? A. I was here six months ago; I have been here six or seven times, about robberies which I saw committed; I had seen Keefe before. My father was a constable of St. Giles'; it was done under the arch-way, between three and four o'clock - I was about twenty yards from them; nobody was between me and them.
CONNORY'S Defence. I was under the arch-way, and picked it up.
KEEFE's Defence. I was passing along, when he took me.

CONNORY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

KEEFE -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1685.
DANIEL HOLDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 1 hat, value 9s., and 1 pair of gloves, value 1s. , the goods of
Robert Blick
.
ROBERT BLICK. I am a surgeon . On the 14th of September, about six o'clock at night, I missed this hat off a nail in the surgery, where I hung it at five o'clock; it was produced two days afterwards.

WILLIAM LEE
. I am an officer. I saw the prisoner in the Old Bailey-yard, on the 14th of September, about half-past five o'clock - he had nothing then - I saw him a few minutes after six o'clock with this hat and gloves, covered with an apron.

JAMES ISAACS
. I was with Lee - his account is correct.
Prisoner's Defence. A man offered me 2d. to sell it for him in Sharp's-alley.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged .

1686.
JOHN COOK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 8 napkins, value 2s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 1s.; 1 apron, value 1s., and 4 live tame fowls, price 10s. , the property of
Low Fysh
.

LOW FYSH. I keep a chandler's shop in Edward-street, Islington
. About one o'clock on the morning of the 15th of September, I was called up, and was told somebody was climbing my wall; two officers got over; I went down, and found the prisoner in charge; I saw the linen taken from him; the fowls were dead, in the wash-house.

EDWARD PALMER
. I received information, and got over Fysh's wall, and found the prisoner concealed there, with the linen.

JOHN REYNARD
. I am an officer. I was with Palmer, and took the prisoner.

JANE CLARK
. I had washed this linen, and hung it up in the yard.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 64.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1687.
DAVID BRACEWELL
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
William McKenzie
, on the 1st of August , with intent, 1 watch, value 20s., from his person, violently and feloniously to steal .
SECOND COUNT, stating his intent to be to rob him.

WILLIAM McKENZIE. I am a seaman , and live in Peartree-court, Ratcliff-highway
. On the 31st of July I was going home, about twelve o'clock at night: I found the gate shut, and could not get in; I went and stood in the middle of the street for the gate to be opened; the prisoner came and asked me twice if I did not want a lodging; I said No; he asked me a third time, and I told him to go along - he then ran with his full force against me, and pushed me down, struck me on the chest, and got hold of the ribbon of my watch; he very nearly got it, but I prevented it - I then felt his hand in my pocket; I heard the watchman coming - he then took to his heels, and ran off - the watchman followed, and took him; I lost sight of him, but I am sure he is the person.

WILLIAM PHILLIPS
. I am the watchman. On the 1st of August I took the prisoner, between twelve and one o'clock - McKenzie was in the road, and nobody near him - he was so alarmed and hurt he could hardly speak - he said he should know the man, and pointed which way he ran; I could not see him, but in a short time another watchman was driving the prisoner along, and desired me to see him out of the parish, as he was a bad character; I took him to the watch-house, and fetched McKenzie to the watch-house - he immediately said he was the man; there was nobody else near - McKenzie had been drinking, but was not intoxicated.
Prisoner's Defence. There were two watchman drivingme about; I was taken to the watch-house; he said to the prosecutor, "That is the man, is it not?"
GUILTY . Aged 21.
