Transported for Fourteen Years .

1688.
JOHN CULLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , 1 coverlid, value 2s.; 1 bed, value 15s.; 1 sheet, value 3s., and 1 blanket, value 2s., the goods of
Isaac Elly
, in a lodging-room .

ISAAC ELLY. I live in Surry-buildings, Vauxhall
. I let the prisoner a back room furnished; on the 2d of September I missed this property; and gave him in charge.
Prisoner. Q. Did I not say the woman I lived with took them? A. No.

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am a pawnbroker. A woman pawned this sheet.

LEONARD NEEDS
. I have a quilt pawned by a woman.

RICHARD BIRCH
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a bed and bolster pawned by a woman.

WILLIAM SMITHERS
. I searched the prisoner's room, and found these duplicates in a tea-pot.
Prisoner's Defence. I sent them 13s. to make it up, but the officer wanted 7s. for himself.

WILLIAM SMITHERS
. The Magistrate recommended him to make it up; I told the Magistrate my expenses, but did not tell the prisoner; I had a good deal of trouble.
NOT GUILTY .

1682.
JAMES FLEMING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of August , 1 candlestick, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
Edward Richardson
.

SARAH WISEMAN
. I am servant to Edward Richardson, at the Northumberland Arms, public-house, Clerkenwell
. On the 17th of August the prisoner came from the skittle-ground, took a candlestick off the copper, and put it into his pocket.
EDWARD RICHARDSON. I took this candlestick from the prisoner's pocket - it is mine.
Prisoner's Defence. I wanted a piece of candle, and took it out of the candlestick, but it was not in my pocket.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined One Month .

1690.
THOMAS BRAMWELL
was indicted for
bigamy .
The prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1691.
CATHERINE MOORHEAD
was indicted for
stealing, 1 purse, value 2d.; 1 shilling, and 2 half-crowns, the property of
Thomas Lamerton
, from his person .

THOMAS LAMERTON. On the 10th of August I was at the Cooper's Arms, public-house, Stretton-ground, Westminster
, about eleven o'clock; I had a purse with this money in it; when I got a few yards from the house it was gone; I returned and said to the prisoner, who was there, "Kitt, you have done me;" she drew her hand from her bosom, with the purse in it, threw it at me, and threw a farthing at me, and said, that was all that was in it, and struck me.

WILLIAM WOODBERY
. I am an officer. Lamerton said he had been robbed by Irish Kitt; I found her at the Cooper's Arms - she said she had picked the purse up.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that she had found the purse.
NOT GUILTY .

1692.
ELIZABETH LAWSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 2 shirts, value 10s.; 2 sheets, value 7s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 tablecloth, value 2s.; 1 waistcoat, value 1s., and 1 bolster-case, value 5s. , the goods of
John Hone
.

JOHN HONE. I live at Somer's-town
- my wife is a laundress - the prisoner worked for her. On the 14th of September my wife had these things to wash.

WILLIAM ROWLAND SEARES
. I am a pawnbroker. I have two sheets, two handkerchiefs, a table-cloth, and a waistcoat, which were pawned - I do not know who by.

DAVID HENDERSON
. The prisoner pawned a sheet with me on the 14th of September.

THOMAS BLACKBURN
. I have a sheet, pawned by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

ROBERT TEASDALE
. I apprehended her, and found the duplicates at her lodgings.
GUILTY . Aged 42.
Confined Three Months .

1693.
HENRY LONGLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 1 watch, value 18s. , the goods of
John Berman
.

CAROLINE BERMAN
. I am the wife of John Berman, a watch-maker , of Park-terrace, Lambeth
. On the 10th of August I saw the prisoner come to the shop, reach his hand in, and take a watch from the window - he went out with it; I went out and overtook him, when a man had stopped him; I had not lost sight of him; he had thrown it away.

MARIA WEBB
. On the 10th of August I saw the prisoner throw this watch over the rails; I saw a man pick it up.

WILLIAM SELLERS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner and the watch.(Property produced and sworn to).
GUILTY . Aged 12.
Transported for Seven Years .

1694.
THOMAS JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 7 live tame pigeons, price 5s. , the property of
John Simmons Winterflood
and
John Brown
.

ROBERT DUKE
. I am an officer. On the 19th of July I searched the prisoner's room in Steward's-rents, Drury-lane, and found seven live pigeons; the prosecutor claimed them.

JOHN SIMMONS WINTERFLOOD. I know the pigeons - they were the joint property of myself and John Brown; I had seen them the day before on our coal-wharf, at Waterloo-bridge
- the prisoner was in our employ - I would take him back again.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Fined One Shilling and Discharged .

1695.
WILLIAM ORVILL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of August , 1 watch, value 18s.; 1 chain, value 6d., and 2 seals, value 1s., the goods of
Benjamin Harris
, from his person .

BENJAMIN HARRIS. I live in Houndsditch. On the 8th of August, at a quarter-past six o'clock, I was passing the Session's-house at Westminster
, the prisoner run against me, touched me on the shoulder, and said, "Harris!" thenpulled my watch out, and ran away - he knew me before; he let the watch fall as he ran, for the ring broke; Fox stopped him - nothing was found on him - the seal and key are lost - I did not lose sight of him.

ROBERT FULLER
. I am a private in the Guards. I was coming towards Storey's-gate - Harris said a soldier had stolen his watch; I followed the prisoner down King-street - called to him to stop - he would not; I took him in Cannon-row.

CHARLES DIGGLE
. I live in Little Chapel-street. Harris described the man to me - I assisted in securing him - he knocked me down.
Prisoner's Defence. He knocked me down - I was a little in liquor - I know nothing of the property.
NOT GUILTY .
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1696.
THOMAS McNAMARA
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 1 curtain, value 2d. , the goods of
Robert Tims
.

JOHN WEATHERLEY
. I am an officer. I met the prisoner on the 8th of July, in Regent's Park, with a bundle - I asked what it was; he said he had bought a coat that evening; that it was his own, and he would not shew it to anybody; he tripped me up and ran away; I followed and secured him; he still had the parcel - he tore the string, and threw the papers about - we found the curtain and handkerchief in his cap.

ROBERT TIMS. I am a carpenter , and live in Edward-street, Regent's Park
. These things are mine - I cannot say when I had seen them last - I had been removing from No. 1 to No. 2, and am not certain where these things were - they were usually kept in a chest in my bed-room; the prisoner was working for me as a bricklayer's labourer - I paid him on the evening of the 8th of July - and in the morning, when I awoke, I found the chest wrenched open by a chisel - I had gone to bed without a light - there was more valuable property and some money left in the chest - the prisoner had access to the house - these papers were in the trunk - he bore a good character.
Prisoner's Defence. I found the things a few yards from the public-house, where I was paid.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Six Weeks .

1697.
THOMAS PHILLIPS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 5 sixpences, the monies of
David Brinn
, from his person .

DAVID BRINN. I am a stone-sawyer , and live in Fitzroy-place. On the 5th of September, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was returning from Covent Garden, where I had been to see my uncle; I met the prisoner by the Seven Dials - I was a little in liquor, and asked him to shew me the way to Tottenham-court-road
, and I would give him 6d. to drink with; we went into a house and had something - when we came out, he asked if I knew the way; I said Yes; but asked him to go further - when we got beyond Tottenham-court chapel, we went into a house, and had a quartern of rum - when I came out I wished him good night - I felt his hand in my pocket - I put my hand to it; he pulled his hand out, and slapped my face, and said, "You are no use, and I am off;" I swear his hand was in my pocket - I missed a half-crown, a shilling, and five sixpences - I ran after him, calling Watch! I lost sight of him once in turning the corner; but I heard the watchman say "We have got him;" I went up and found him in charge - the money I lost was found on him.

JOHN THOMPSON
. About half-past eleven o'clock I heard Watch! called - I saw the prisoner running; I stopped him, and took him to the watch-house - I saw a half-crown, a shilling, and five sixpences found on him.

JOHN JONES
. I found this money on the prisoner.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Life .

1698.
RICHARD REEVES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of April , 1 warrant, for payment of and value 52l. 10s. , the property of
Daniel Magniac
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1699.
THOMAS ROBERTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of August , 1 silver cream-jug, value 30s. , the goods of
Andrew Luriottis
.

FRANCIS TITE
. I am servant to Andrew Luriottis, he lives in Sackville-street
. On the 26th of August, at a quarter before eleven o'clock, I saw the prisoner in the area - the gate was shut, but the people in the kitchen opened it for him - he said he came to know if there were any orders for fish - but he was quite a stranger - the bell rang, and I went away for about three minutes - on my return he was still there; but as he was going out, I saw some milk on his coal-sleeve - I then looked on the tray, and the silver cream ewer was gone - I ran out at the front-door, and overtook him running about the middle of the street - I found this milk ewer in his hat.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am the officer. I took charge of the prisoner, and have the property.
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Transported for Seven Years .

1700.
WILLIAM JOHN RICE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of June , 4 pieces of glass, value 20s. , the goods of
Henry Bingham
.

JOHN CULLIFORD
. I am a watchman. I met the prisoner in Lisle-street, Leicester-square, on the 1st of June, at half-past two o'clock in the morning, with a bag under his arm - he looked at me, and went on into Little Newport-street - I went up to him and said, "I think you have got something that is not all right;" he threw it at me - I caught it in my arms - it contained this glass; he ran off; but was not a quarter of an hour out of my sight - I gave the alarm, and he was taken.

JOHN MASON
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! I took the prisoner.

ROBERT HOWARD
. I am a constable. I was at the watch-house, and received him in charge.

HENRY BINGHAM. I live in Ryder's-court
. These pieces of glass are mine, and worth about 1l.; they were in a cupboard, in a lumber-room.

Prisoner's Defence. They were given to me by a man to carry - Mr. Bingham told my mother that if I wanted to get released, I had better say who he was - I did so; it was Phillips, who I went to to sell my coat - he sent a boy with me, who brought the property out.
HENRY BINGHAM. He said Phillips, a Jew, instigatedhim to carry them - I said I knew several persons of that name, and he had better produce the man.
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Confined Three Months .

1701.
JOSEPH SCOTT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 7 yards of silk, value 1l., the goods of
George Benjamin Ford
, privately in his shop .

JAMES ROBERT FIGG
. I am shopman to George Benjamin Ford, a mans mercer , of Southampton-street, Covent-garden
. On the 19th of July, at half-past seven o'clock in the morning, the prisoner came to the shop for some patterns of blue cloth - he then asked for some silk - I shewed him the pattern-book; he went away without buying any thing - I missed seven yards of silk which I had shewn him.

JOHN KNOWLES
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker in Drury-lane. The prisoner came to pawn the silk, about eight o'clock in the morning, of the 19th of July, for 26s.; I had received information, and detained him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A friend sent me to pawn this, to make up his rent.
GUILTY . Aged 23.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined One Year .

1702.
JOHN SULLIVAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 1 watch-chain, value 6d., and 1 key, value 4s., the goods of
Robert Coleberd
, from his person .

ROBERT COLEBERD. I am a wine-merchant . On the 15th of September I was in Soho-square
, at a quarter to one o'clock, a man ran up and took my watch-chain and two keys; I had a bottle of gin on my back - he snatched it under my arm; I cannot tell who he was; I called Stop thief! the officer pursued, and brought the prisoner back in two minutes; the person was about his size.

JOHN WILLIAM BEAN
. I am a silver chaser. I was in Swallow-street, going towards Soho-square, and heard a cry of Stop thief! I met the prisoner running, and stopped him; he used a violent oath, and put himself in a fighting attitude, and made a blow at me; I struck him again; he ran off; I pursued with others, and caught him in a court - he got from me again; I still pursued, and secured him.

JOHN MASON
. I am an officer. I was in Soho-square, and saw the prisoner and two others coming from Charles-street - the prisoner left the other two, and went into the road; I followed him till we met the prosecutor; the prisoner went up to him on the side on which the bottle was on his shoulder; he snatched at his watch, and ran off immediately; Coleberd called Stop thief! I pursued, and lost sight of him, as he turned into Sutton-street; I came up, and took him from Bean; I knew him before.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1703.
JOHN TURNER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 1 pair of shoes, value 3s. , the goods of
George Owen
.

ROBERT EVANS
. Owen's shop is in Cross-street
, opposite my father's. On the 15th of September I saw the prisoner pass the shop several times, about eleven o'clock in the morning - he at last went in; I saw him take a pair of shoes from the window; I ran out and took him - he gave them to me; he said he was in distress.
GEORGE OWEN. I am a shoe-maker . I was out at this time; the shoes are mine.

WILLIAM WESTCOAT
. I took him in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, being in distress.
Confined Six Weeks .

1704.
GEORGE TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 10 sovereigns; 1 half-crown; 1 shilling; 1 sixpence, and 2d., the monies of
Thomas Robinson
, his master .

THOMAS ROBINSON. I am a tallow-chandler , and live in Drury-lane
- the prisoner was my servant . On the 12th of August, about a quarter-past eleven o'clock, I sent him to the Excise-office to pay some duty, with ten sovereigns, four shillings, and two penny-pieces; he had the charge-paper with him; he never returned; I found him on board a ship in the river, and had him secured; I could not get a word out of him; the Captain said, in his presence, he had paid his passage with one sovereign and a shilling, for Yorkshire; he had eight sovereigns and 17s. 6d. in his pocket, which he gave up.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I am an officer, and took him in charge; he said he had paid the Captain 1l. 1s. of the money; I was obliged to handcuff him - he said he had changed one sovereign.
Prisoner. I beg for mercy.
GUILTY . Aged 17.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Three Months .

1705.
THOMAS TAPP
and
HENRY DAVIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of September , 7 live tame fowls, price 14s.; 1 basket, value 6d.; 1 cage, value 6d.; 1 pair of shoes, value 2d., and 1 pair of boots, value 2d. , the property of
Thomas Nash
.

THOMAS NASH. I am a labourer , and live in Copenhagen-fields
. I kept my fowls in a shed; I lost them on the morning of the 16th of September - they were safe when I went to bed - in the morning, about a quarter to six o'clock, I found the shed open, and the fowls gone; I missed the other property from two different sheds in my yard; the feathers lay about - we traced them across the fields for a mile, to the New Kentish-town road - we there saw the prisoners who I had seen loitering about the premises the night before; they were walking about the hedges - this was a quarter-past six o'clock; Harmon, who was with me, secured them; I have received seven fowls, the boots, shoes, cage, and basket, back.

EDWARD HARMON
. I live near Nash, and went with him on this morning. I had seen the prisoners loitering about the place, the evening before, we found them, by the road; I secured them - they tried to escape; I said,"Where are the fowls?" Davis took the basket off his back, and said, "Here!" Tapp made no answer; there were five fowls in the basket, dead; Tapp had the boots; I delivered them to Nash.

WILLIAM REYNOLDS
. I am an officer, and took them in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
DAVIS's Defence. I met this man in the fields; he asked me to buy the basket.

TAPP -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

DAVIS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

1706.
THOMAS WALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of September , 1 tea-kettle, value 2s. 6d. , the goods of
George Hoffman
.

SAMUEL RODWAY
. On the 15th of September I saw the prisoner lurking about Hoffman's shop, at the corner of Wilmington-place, Spa-fields
; he went in, and came out, in five minutes, with this tea-kettle in his hand; I I pursued, and took him near the toll-gate.

ANTHONY LAWRENCE
. I heard the cry of Stop thief! and caught him in my arms.
GEORGE HOFFMAN. This kettle is mine - it stood about three yards within my shop.
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Whipped and Discharged .

1707.
WILLIAM BATES
was indicted for
stealing, on 15th of September , 1 piece of linen, containing 5 yards in length, value 2s. , the goods of
Samuel Cowley
and
Henry Hewetson
.

SAMUEL BEAMAN
. I am carter to Samuel Cowley and Henry Hewetson. On the 15th of September I was bringing five bales of sheeting from Hoare's wharf to our warehouse, in Cateaton-street; I met the prisoner on the wharf, whom I had known some years - he had been a carter to Mr. Evans - he is now patrol of St. Botolph, Aldgate ; we went to the Coopers' Arms, public-house
, to have some beer and my dinner - it was then between one and two o'clock; while I was at the house he went out and got my dinner - and as he went out, I saw through the window, that he put his hand on the rail of the waggon, and his foot on the wheel - but I did not see that he got into it, though he raised himself up; he returned in about five minutes, and after I had done my dinner, I drove away; when I got on to the Minories I missed a piece of sheeting-wrapper from my waggon; I think it might be five yards, or more; I had put it in, and the lock-chain over it. I had never said that previous to my going to the Cooper's Arms, he had seen me double it up, and put the lock-chain over it; he must have seen it when he raised himself up - he was near the cloth, and could get it; I went to his house that night - I found his wife at the gin-shop; I went with the officer and found the prisoner on his beat - he denied it to the officer - but when I went up to him, he said, if I went home with him, he would give it to me; I found it there.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did not the officer tell him he had stolen it? A. No; he said, "There has been a waggon robbed - do you know any thing about it?" I did not say. I would give him something to make an apron; I did not think any thing about his putting his hand and foot on the waggon. We drank the beer, and came up as far as Butcher-row, and had some rum; I did not ask the prisoner to hold the whip while I went up Morgan's-rents; I left the whip inside, and he brought it out, but I did not desire him.

JAMES WITNEY
. I am a headborough. I received information from the witness, at a quarter before ten o'clock, and went to the prisoner on his beat, in Nightingale-lane, with Beaman - I went up to the prisoner, and said, "Bates - you are charged with stealing a piece of linen out of a waggon to day;" he said he had not; I then stepped five or six yards back, and Beaman went up, and said."Bates"- I did not hear more, but when they had been in conversation about a minute Bates said, in a louder voice, "Yes, I did take it out of the waggon - if you come home with me you shall have it;" we all three went to his house, and, after searching a few minutes, we found this linen on the floor, at the foot of the stairs, in the lower room - the prisoner took it up. I took him to the watch-house.
Cross-examined. Q. When you went up did not you charge him with stealing it? A. Yes - the carman knew what he was about - I think he was sober.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Confined One Month .

1708.
MARY MAHONEY
and
MARY MANNING
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of August , 1 watch, value 50s.; 1 hat, value 10s.; 1 handkerchief, value 1s., and 1 crown piece, the property of
James Henderson
, from his person .

JAMES HENDERSON. I am a sailor , and belong to the Nicholas, a collier, which laid off the Tower. On Saturday night, the 5th of August, I left the vessel at half-past eight o'clock, and met the prisoners at a public-house in Ratcliff-highway; they were there when I went in; they came to me - Manning asked me to give her a glass of gin; I gave her 1s. to get half-a-pint for the prisoners and two old women, who were there - they had a glass a piece - I had nothing but a single pint of porter; I left the house with the prisoner about eleven o'clock; I went with them to a house I never was in before, in Blue Anchor-court
; I then went up stairs with Mahoney; I undressed myself, and laid my clothes on the table; I went to bed, and she laid on the bed with me - she then said she wanted to go down stairs for a minute, and she left me in bed - she did not come up again to my knowledge; I fell asleep, and slept till two o'clock as near as I can guess - there was no light in the room; I then went to my clothes, and missed my watch, hat, and handkerchief; I am quite certain I had put my watch on the table when I went to bed, and the crown-piece was in my pocket; I listened for awhile, and then an old woman came up, and said, "There are no girls here belonging to you;" Manning then came up, and said she knew nothing about it, but she would fetch the other to give me my things; I came down, and found Mahoney outside the door, who said she would give me a glass of something, and give me my things; I said I should like to know the number of the house, but I could not find it; we then went to a public-house to get something - there were a great many people - the prisoners got through them, and got out of the back door; I told the landlord, who said he would search the house, but they were not to be found - he then told me to go out, and see for the watchman, which I did, and the prisoners were taken; I have never seen any of the property since.
Cross-examined by Mr. CRESWELL. Q. Are you quite certain you met the prisoners at the public-house? A. Yes; I am certain I was sober.

JOHN TOLKER
. I am the watchman. I was on my beat near Blue Anchor-court; I saw this sailor come out of the house with two girls, about two o'clock in the morning; I was not near enough to hear what they said - he came outof the public-house afterwards, and then complained to me; I asked if he should know the girls again - he said Yes; I had seen the two prisoners go down a yard; and I went and called them - they came, and I asked him if these were the girls - he said Yes; I took them to the watchhouse; I then searched them and their room, but found nothing; the sailor appeared a little in liquor, but he knew what he was about - he pointed out the house to me, and I knew they lived there.
MANNING's Defence. I know no more of the man than by seeing him at the Paviors' Arms public-house.

MAHONEY -
GUILTY . Aged 18.

MANNING -
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1709.
ELIZA SUTTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 4 pairs of shoes, value 14s., and 1 pair of boots, value 4s. , the goods of
William Moore
.

WILLIAM MOORE. I am a boot and shoe-maker , and live at No. 15, Upper King-street, Bloomsbury-square
. The prisoner was servant to a lodger of mine for one week, and her mistress was about to discharge her - some shoes of mine were brought down stairs; I sent for an officer, who searched her box in my presence, and found in it a pair of boots, and a pair of shoes; I took one pair of shoes off her feet - two pairs of shoes were found under her bed - I asked her about them - she denied all knowledge of them; a few days before this I went out and double locked my shop door, and the passage door - on my return I found the shop door on the single lock only; I then missed some property.

WILLIAM JAMES
. I am headborough. I searched a box, which the prisoner acknowledged to be her's; I found a pair of boots and a pair of shoes in it; these two pairs were under the bed, and one pair on her feet.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner. I leave myself to the mercy of the Court.
One witness gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, believing it to be her first offence.
Judgment Respited .
EIGHTH DAY. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 22.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1710.
CAROLINE HOPPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of August , at St. James, Clerkenwell
, 1 watch, value 7l.; 1 watch-chain, value 3l.; 1 watch-key, value 4s., and 3 seals, value 3l., the goods of
Thomas Haywood Lamb
, in his dwelling-house .

MARY ANN LAMB
. I am the wife of Thomas Haywood Lamb; we live in Sidney-street, Goswell-road
, in the parish of St. James, Clerkenwell. I know the prisoner, she lived in the neighbourhood. On Friday, the 4th of August, between 3 and 4 o'clock in the afternoon she called at my house, and seemed to have some pressing call upon her; I showed her to the water-closet, on the first floor; she then went away and said she would return in an hour, and then, she supposed, her kettle would boil, and I should take tea with her, or she with me; I went to the room on the first floor soon after she was gone, and missed, from a drawer, a gold watch, a gold chain, three gold seals, and a key, which had been in that drawer on the Monday before; I had not seen them after Monday; they were my husband's; the prisoner had been in that room a fortnight before, and I had shewn them to her in the drawer; these are the articles.

CHARLES SANDERS
. I am a pawnbroker. I produce all these articles, except one seal; they were pawned with me on Friday, the 4th of August, by the prisoner.

COURT. Q. How came you to be so sure of her: you only said you believed so before the Magistrate? A. Yes, but I spoke to her after she left the bar, and her voice convinced me that she was the person; I am certain of her.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. I am a constable. I took up the prisoner on Thursday, the 10th of August, in Blackfriars-road. The prosecutor had given me the information on the Sunday, and I went to look for her, but she had left her own house; when I took her I told her I was a constable, and I had come respecting a watch; she said she had never been happy since she took it, and she had written a letter to the prosecutrix or her husband, I do not know which; and meant to give herself up that night.
COURT to Mrs. LAMB. Q. How long had you known her as a neighbour? A. About seven or eight weeks - she first came to inquire about a room in my house; she lived with a man who was a carpenter.

SAMUEL SHARWOOD
. I live in St. John's-street-road, and am a pawnbroker. I produce the other seal pawned by the prisoner on the 4th of August.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 30.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, supposing it her first offence, believing her to have had a good character before, and appearing sorry for what she had done.

1711.
THOMAS POWELL
and
WILLIAM PERCIVAL
were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Warren
, about six o'clock in the forenoon of the 28th of June , at St. Leonard, Shoreditch
(
Henry Warren
being therein,) and stealing 5 cages, and 5 singing birds, value 27s., the goods of the said John Warren .

JOHN WARREN. I live at Old Haggerstone, near King's-land-road
, in the parish of St. Leonard, Shoreditch. On the 28th of June I saw my birds and cages safe at four o'clock in the morning, when I and my wife went out to work - I had then given them water - there was an outcry in the field about half-past six o'clock, and I missed my birds and cages; the back door was open - I saw them again in about ten minutes; but I did not see either of the prisoners till they were in custody about seven o'clock.
Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. Was it light when you went out? A. Yes; I found my baby, Henry Warren, safe in his bed - he was not awake.

WILLIAM WILSON
. I am a servant to the Gas-light company. On the morning of the 28th of June, I saw the two prisoners at Warren's house, trying the padlock of the door - they could not get in at the front door, and they went to the back - I saw them come out with some property tied in two handkerchiefs - I followed them to Hackney-road, and gave an alarm; I saw them stopped with the property on them.

Cross-examined. Q. Was there not a third personthere? A. Yes; but he was not at the door at all; I was not twenty yards from them - I did not know either of them before; the other person was rather taller than them.

JOHN THURLEY
. I am a servant to the Gas-light-company; I saw the two prisoners on the 28th of June, trying the padlock in front of the house, and then they went to the back - I saw them go into the house, and I went for an officer, and when I returned, I saw them coming out with the cages.
Cross-examined. Q. Where were those persons as you went by? A. I passed them to look at them, and then I saw them go in, when I came back over Black-horse-fields - they were coming out of the house.

GEORGE M'DONNELL
. I am a constable. I saw the two prisoners running out of Haggerstone-lane, and another person with them, who got away - I found four birds and cages on Powell; Percival was taken near the Methodist-chapel; these are the cages.

WILLIAM BULL
. I am a constable. I took custody of the prisoners - the property was delivered to me.

JAMES TAYLOR
. I took Percival; he was in custody of some brick-makers, who were going to duck him; I found these skeleton keys on Powell.

JOHN WARREN. All these are my property; and they were all necessary to make up my stock, with one which they threw over a wall; that bird is dead - they were all in my room - the back-door was bolted, and the front door locked with a padlock; I looked it myself; they are worth five shillings a bird - I could sell them for that.

POWELL -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 21.

PERCIVAL -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 21.

1712.
CHARLES CURREY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of August , at St. James, Westminster
, 18 yards of woollen cloth, value 18l., the goods of
George Noah
, in his dwelling-house .

JOHN DEEKER
. I am porter to Mr. George Noah, a tailor and breeches maker , who lives in Pall Mall
, in the parish of St. James, Westminster. On the 21st of August I was coming up from the kitchen to the shop, to speak to my master, and saw the prisoner in the shop, in the act of taking a piece of cloth; I asked the foreman if he had given a piece of cloth to any body - he said No; I pursued the prisoner, who had the cloth in his possession; I saw him stopped, without losing sight of him, and saw him throw it away - I took it up, and the foreman took him, in my presence.
Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. What time was this? A. A quarter past eight o'clock; our shop door was shut, but not locked.

PHILIP HARROW
. On the 21st of August I was foreman to George Noah. I heard a man had run away with a piece of cloth; I followed, and saw the prisoner was carrying it in a way to conceal it. I saw him throw it away; the porter took it up; I took the prisoner at the corner - the cloth is worth 18l.

Cross-examined. Q. Where were you? A. I was gone up to the workshop - when I came down the porter gave me information. I did not see the prisoner in the shop - when I first saw him he was turning the corner of Crown-court, about forty yards off, walking briskly.
COURT. Q. Had you seen the cloth that day? A. Yes - I had been cutting it a quarter of an hour before. The shop is a part of the dwelling-house - it is under the first floor.

JAMES SMITH
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner. and bring the cloth here.(Property produced and sworn to).

Prisoner's Defence. The witness said he saw me take the cloth off the counter, and go up the court; I had got to the top of the court when the foreman came out, and he lost sight of me; Mr. Noah wished to let me go, and several persons wished to liberate me, and the foreman would not let me go.
PHILIP HARROW re-examined. Q. Were there any other persons about who wished you to let him go? A. There was a Jew, who came up, and said Mr. Noah wished me to let him go, but I took him back.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 19.

1713.
JOHN WILLIAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of July , at St. Luke
, 1 purse, value 6d., and 4 sovereigns, the property of
John Davis
, in his dwelling-house .

CATHERINE SARAH DAVIS
. I am the wife of John Davis; we live in Lamb's-passage, Chiswell-street
, in the parish of St. Luke's. My mother asked me to give the prisoner a few night's lodging - I had four sovereigns in a purse, locked up in a drawer, in my front parlour; they were safe about nine o'clock in the morning of the 31st of July, and I missed them about ten o'clock on the morning of the 1st of August; I had not been out, but I had gone into the yard on the 31st of July, and left the prisoner in the room; a key was in another drawer, which would open the one the money was in; he knew the money was there, because he saw me take some out; I was not out more than two or three minutes, and when I came back he bade me good bye twice, and went away - he was taken on the 3d of August.

JAMES NOTT
. On the 31st of July I saw the prisoner at Brook's-wharf, Upper Thames-street - I went with him to buy some clothes, which he asked me to do - he bought some, and paid for them, but I cannot tell to what amount - there were more than one sovereign; I saw him take it from a little brass-linked purse; he said his grand-mother had left them all 2l. a piece.

JOHN WILLIAM HARRISON
. I took up the prisoner, dressed in sailor's clothes, which I understood he had changed his new clothes for. I found this purse in his pocket.
CATHERINE SARAH DAVIS. This is my purse, and contained the money.

Prisoner's Defence. The day before I took the money I told James Nott of it, and he persuaded me to get it - I gave him half of it, and he said when that was gone he would go and get 6l. of his father's master; he spent the money about with me, and then took 1s. from his father - he then left me.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 14.

1714.
GEORGE THOMPSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 20lbs. weight of coffee, value 20s., the goods of
James Turnley
, and others, in a certain barge, on the navigable River Thames
.

JOSEPH TURNLEY. I am a lighterman , and am in partnership with other persons. On the 31st of August the prisoner was a watchman on board a lighter of ours in the river, with six casks on board, which were to be shipped on board the Argo; I sent him at five o'clock in the afternoon, and his especial charge was to take care of those casks; he was to remain there that night, and come to me in the morning.

THOMAS THOMPSON
. I am a Custom-house officer. I was stationed on board the brig Allies, lying in the river; between eleven and twelve o'clock, on the night of the 31st of August, the barge Jane, which had this coffee on board, struck the Allies, and remained athwart the bows till morning; I saw the prisoner and another person in that barge, while I was walking the deck; they had some conversation about some beer - the other one said he should like some, but he was close hawled and they had better finish - the other said, "I think it is as well;" they then walked the gunwale of the barge - the other person opened the cabin door - the prisoner then got to the bottom of the barge; I am not sure whether he went through the cabin - I went to the other side of the vessel to observe their motions more particularly; there was a hole of six or eight inches square through which I could look at them; the prisoner then produced some bags from under his jacket, which he adjusted over his knee - he then went under the tarpauling, and I heard the running of something which appeared to be coffee or pepper; it was then about a quarter to twelve o'clock - at twelve o'clock I called up
Pierce Powen
, my partner, to release me - and we continued watching together; I then saw a cask rolled from under the tarpauling without any person with it; and I then discovered the coffee running from a hole in that cask; in a short time I saw the prisoner before the cask - he took a plug from his mouth and put it into the hole of the cask, from which the coffee had been running, and drove it in with a piece of wood - during all this time, the other man was shuffling on the deck and whistling - a smack then passed by, and the coffee was stopped, while it passed, the others then said "It is all right;" and the coffee began to run again, while the man on the top kept moving the hatchway - the prisoner then drew the tarpauling, which had been spread for the coffee to run on, towards the cabin-door - I got into a boat, and went into the harge, and my partner came over the bow of the vessel; I told the prisoner I came for the coffee which he had drawn from the cask - "Lord bless you," says he, "I know nothing about it; I am the watchman;" I told him he might as well confess it, for I had been so near, I could have lent him a hand; I went into the cabin and found his companion; I moved a tar barrel, and found five bags of coffee, which weighed 22lbs. - I applied my light to the prisoner's face, and am quite positive of his person - I told them it was a fortunate job there was not a Police-boat coming by, for if it had, they would have been locked up; I left them on board the barge, and wrote to the Eonourable Board the next morning, stating what I had done; I am certain it was the prisoner, who put the plug into the cask - it was a star light night, and high water - I could see him very distinctly.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. This man tells me he was asleep when you went on board? A. No; he was standing on the vessel.

HENRY FENNEY
. I am foreman of the West India Docks; I delivered six casks of coffee, on board the barge Jane, No. 222; one of the casks was No. 65; I had weighed it, and it was 13cwt. 1qr. 9lbs.

GEORGE RICH
. I am a searcher. I saw the cask, No. 65, weighed on board the Jane on the 5th of September, it weighed 12cwt. 2qrs. 4lbs.

JOSEPH FARNLEY
. I believe this to be the same sort of coffee as was in the casks - it is worth 9d. per lb. without the duty; the prisoner had been eight years with us, and we had a good opinion of him.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been sent on board the barge the night before, and the next morning I left, and she was sent adrift in the course of the day; at night I was sent on board again, and I found these bags under the tarpauling in the cabin.

JURY to
THOMAS THOMPSON
. Q. Did you leave the deck to go to call your companion? A. No; I called him down the forecastle; I do not know whether the prisoner heard me - he slept about six feet from me.
GUILTY . Aged 45.
Recommended to Mercy by Jury, on account of his former character.
Confined One Year .

1715.
ANN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 gown, value 4s.; 4 caps, value 1s. 6d.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 1 pair of shoes, value 1s., and 1 printed book, value 1s. , the goods of
Elizabeth Lay
, spinster .
The prosecutrix did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1716.
SAMUEL STROUD
and MARGARET, HIS WIFE
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 2 sovereigns, 1 half-crown, 4 shillings, and 4 sixpences, the goods of
Joseph Batchelor
, from his person .

JOSEPH BATCHELOR. On the 14th of September, in the night, I went into a field with the female prisoner; I felt her hand in my pocket; I laid hold of her, and she cried out Murder! the man came down, and said, "What are you going to do with my wife;" I had not seen him before; I said, "She has robbed me" - he said, "Then take her to a constable, but you shan't ill-use her." I took her to a watchman, but he would not take charge of her; a man showed me where a constable lived, who at first refused, but afterwards took her into custody.

JOSEPH ADDERLEY
. I am a constable at Ealing. I was not at home when the watchman brought the female prisoner to my house - I received her in custody; I searched her the next morning, and found half-a-crown, and two-pence upon her.
NOT GUILTY .

1717.
JAMES HUNT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July , 19 napkins, value 28s., and 3 tablecloths, value 11s. , the goods of
Hannah Rees
, widow .

CHARLOTTE REES
. My mother,
Hannah Rees, is in partnership with my brother. NOT GUILTY .

1718.
ROBERT KELLY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
John Spriggs Morss Churchill
, from his person .

JOHN SPRIGGS MORSS CHURCHILL. I am a bookseller , and live in Leicester-square. On the night of the 8th ofJuly I was in Bedford-street, Covent-garden
, and felt a hand at my pocket - I turned round, and saw the prisoner take my handkerchief from his coat, and throw it away; he ran off - I pursued him to the corner of Bedford-court, and took him in Henrietta-street; I never got my handkerchief again; I think it was my handkerchief I saw in his hands, but I am not certain - it was a red one, and so was mine; when I came up to him, I said, "You have robbed me!" I was taking him to the watch-house, when the beadle came up and took him; I saw him take it out of his bosom, and throw it on the pavement; there was some person said, "Let him go;" I said he was not the first person I had prosecuted.

JAMES BETHELL
. I am the beadle. I was in the street at half-past nine o'clock, and heard the cry of Stop thief! I took the prisoner to the watch-house, and found nothing on him; the prosecutor charged him with this robbery, and he did not deny it.

Prisoner's Defence. I was walking with a friend, and got joking him - when we got to Probert's hotel, he was offended; I ran down Bedford-street, this gentleman was coming after me, and I thought it was him, as he had said he would put me into the watch-house.
Mr. CHURCHILL. He said at Bow-street, that there was a row, and he ran, and I followed him, crying Stop thief! he said he heard the rattles sprung, but the watchmen do not come till ten o'clock.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1719.
JAMES FAYES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 1 pewter pot, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
Samuel Cordeux
.

SAMUEL CORDEUX. I keep the Masons' Arms, public-house. Devon-shire-street, Mary-le-bone
. This pot is mine; I never gave the prisoner leave to do any thing with it.

WILLIAM MITCHAM
. I was in Margaret-street, Cavendish-square, on the 14th of September, and saw the prisoner; I watched him down Castle-street, where I touched him on the arm, and saw this pot concealed under his coat, which was buttoned; I took it from him; he wished me to let him go, and said he was out of work, and he had been three weeks in London,

ROBERT WILLIAMS
. I am an officer, and took the prisoner.
Prisoner. I was in distress, and found it in the street.
GUILTY . Aged 55.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Fourteen Days .

1720.
ROBERT ROPER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of July , 1 fork, value 10s. , the goods of
John Jackson Cuff
.

JOHN CUFF
. I am the son of John Jackson Cuff - he keeps the Freemasons' Tavern
. We had missed a fork about a week before the 13th of July. The prisoner had frequently been employed as an occasional waiter , and had access to it.(Property produced and sworn to).

THOMAS WEBB
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner brought this fork to pawn, but we saw the name of Cuff partly erased on it, and detained him.

SAMUEL LACK
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found a number of duplicates at his lodgings.
Prisoner. I leave myself to your mercy.
GUILTY . Aged 37.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Months .

1721.
RICHARD TRUELOVE
and
WILLIAM EDWARDS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of September , 1 boys' dress, value 7s. , the goods of
James Corss
.

JOHN HUBE
. I am shopman to James Corss, a tailor , who has a shop in Chiswell-street
. On the 12th of September I saw the two prisoners walk to and fro; I then saw one of them take the dress; they went up Whitecross-street; I followed, and they dropped it between them.

JOHN FELLS
. I am an officer, and took the prisoners.(Property produced and sworn to.)
TRUELOVE'S Defence. I am innocent. I was going home to dinner.
EDWARDS' Defence. I had been to Maiden-lane, and as I turned the corner the gentleman laid hold of me.

TRUELOVE -
GUILTY . Aged 15.

EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 14.
Whipped and Discharged .

1722.
ELLEN SINGLETON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of May , 6 decanters, value 3l. 17s., the goods of
Barnaby Dunn
, her master, in his dwelling-house .

BARNABY DUNN. I am a glass and china-man , and live in the Haymarket
. The prisoner was my servant - she left me on the 1st or 2d of May, and after she was gone I missed these six decanters from a glass case in my shop, where they had been with many others; she had access to the shop in a morning, and when she went out; the cases are kept locked, but the key is always in the door - these are the decanters - two of them are odd ones, and I have the fellows; the others have the mark at the bottom, which is always taken off when they are sold; I am quite sure I had six decanters like these in my shop, shortly before she left.

HANNAH LEWIS
. I live in Princes-street - my husband is a boot-maker. On Saturday, the 6th of May, the prisoner, whom I had not seen before, came to my house with a woman whom I knew; the prisoner said she had let that old lady have a pair of decanters to get some fruit for her stall, and on the 4th of May she had let her have another pair to get some clothes for herself; she wanted me to lend her the money, and go with her to get them out before her mistress knew it; she said she lived with a lady in Regent-street, who performed at the Opera; I went to Mr. Cameron's, the pawnbroker, in the Strand, with the woman, but I did not get the decanters out; Mr. Cameron had stopped them - I did not own them as mine; I had known the old woman by seeing her stand every day with fruit at the corner of my kitchen window; I found there were six decanters at Cameron's - she said there were but four.

HENRY POWELL
. I am shopman to Mr. Cameron, a pawnbroker. On the 1st of May a woman pawned a pair of decanters for 10s. in the name of Mack; on the 5th of May she brought two pairs more; the same woman came on Saturday the 6th of May, with the prisoner.

SUSAN BOWLES
. The prisoner came to me, and asked me to go and own these decanters, as she had lent them to the woman to get fruit for her stall.

ROBERT TITHERDY
. I am servant to Mr. Dunn, of the Haymarket; the prisoner lived servant there. I recollect the old woman who sold fruit - but I do not know that it was the same woman the witness saw - I never saw any decanters handed to her.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I never went into the shop, but to get wood to light the fire.
GUILTY. Aged 20. Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1723.
ANN HATCHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 2 table-cloths, value 48s.; 1 shirt, value 10s.; 1 shift, value 2s., and 1 shirt, value 3s., the goods of
Daniel Holland
, in his dwelling-house .

AMELIA MULL HOLLAND
. I am the wife of Daniel Holland, and am a laundress; I live in St. John's-street, Cambridge-heath
. I employed the prisoner to iron for me at 3s. a day; I missed this table cloth on the 29th of August - I sent her home with some linen to Mr.
George Brown
- I went there on the Monday following, and the lady charged me with altering the figures of the book - I then charged the prisoner with it, and after a long time she confessed she had taken the table-cloth out and pawned it at Mr. Hales' - she gave the duplicate up.

EDWARD HALES
. I am a pawnbroker. The prisoner pawned a table-cloth with me for 4s. 6d., another for 5s., a shirt for 4s., and a shift for 1s. 6d. - this cloth has the initials of G. B. on it - it was pawned on the 16th of August - it is worth about 10s.

JAMES GARROW
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet pawned by the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN WILLIAMS
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found these five duplicates on her - one of them answers to this table-cloth.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating that the prosecutrix had desired her to pledge the property.
ANN HOLLAND re-examined. I never employed her to pawn any thing in my life - I never authorized her to alter the book - Mrs. Brown took the work from me, and said I was not worthy to have it.
GUILTY. Aged 47. Of stealing to the value of 10s. only .
Confined Six Months .

1724.
JAMES CONNOLLY
,
WILLIAM REYNOLDS
, and
JOHN SMITH
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of June , 1 watch, value 3l., the goods of
Thomas Connolly
, in his dwelling-house .

THOMAS CONNOLLY. I am a green-grocer , and live in Church-lane, Strand
- Connolly is my nephew. This watch hung in my room on the 10th of July, and I missed it on the 11th - my brother lived in St. James' parish, but used to come sometimes.

THOMAS CUP
. I am a constable. On the 11th of July Thomas Connelly applied to me - I took Smith on the 14th of July, in St. Giles, and found a duplicate of this watch in his right-hand waistcoat pocket.

THOMAS LUCAS
. I am shopman to Mr. Harrison, pawnbroker, of Tottenham-court-road. On the 11th of July this watch was pawned by a woman, in the name of Elizabeth Cooper.

JEREMIAH HARLING
. I am ten years of age. I do not know the nature of an oath - I do not know what will become of me, if I do not speak the truth.
NOT GUILTY .

1725.
WILLIAM WARD
was indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
James Samwell
and
Catherine Watkins
, about twelve o'clock in the night of the 27th of August , with intent to steal .

JAMES SAMWELL. I live in High Holborn
- Catherine Watkins and myself occupy the house jointly. On the morning of 27th of August we were alarmed, by a knocking at the street door; I looked out at the window, and saw the watchman with the prisoner; he asked if I knew the man - I said No; he said he found him coming out of my house; I said, "Secure him" - he ran, and secured him, and brought him to the side door; I afterwards went into the kitchen, and found a bag, a cloth, a centre-bit, a phosphorus-box, and a bit of wax-candle; some of them in the kitchen, and some in the area; there was a square of glass broken, and part of it removed - a hand could have been put in at that part of the window - the window itself does not open. I do not know that any part of the premises were broken open.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Is not this window in a door? A. No, it is over the sink, and does not open; no one could have got in there without taking the frame out, and that was not moved; there was no part broken.

PATRICK McCARTHY
. I am a watchman. I received information on the night of the 27th of August, between half-past twelve and one o'clock, and went to Mr. Samwell's house - I found the area gate open, pulled it to, and knocked at the door; I returned again to the area, and saw the prisoner half in and half out of the gate; I seized him - there are no steps to the area - it is a small place, where they put the shutters down; the private door is in Little Turnstile, and the area in Holborn; he said"Watchman, it is all right - make no alarm;" I asked him if he lodged in the house, or was he the master of it, and, to the best of my knowledge, he said Yes, slowly - I said,"You must see the master of the house;" I went to the private door, and knocked twice - and Mr. Samwell looked out - he said "Secure him;" and I went to take hold of the prisoner, but he flew from me, and went up Holborn; I sprang my rattle, and ran - I took him myself, and brought him back - he was not out of my sight half a second - I then went down into the kitchen, and saw these implements in the sink, which is about an arm's length from the window, in which a square of glass was broken; the articles might have been deposited there, without a person getting into the house - there was no part broken; the articles might have been thrown there from the broken window.
NOT GUILTY .

1726.
WILLIAM WESTWOOD
was indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
Esther Coates
, on the night of the 24th of July , and stealing 1 pair of sheets,value 4s.; 2 table-cloths, value 4s.; 1 gown, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 1s.; 4 pinafores, value 2s.; 2 night-caps, value 6d., and 3 spoons, value 1s., her property .

ESTHER COATES. I live in Castle-court, Castle-lane, Westminster
. I am landlady of the whole house; these articles are all mine - they were safe on the night of the 24th of July - they were taken from my wash-house, which joins my dwelling-house - but it does not open into the dwelling-house, it opens into the yard.
Q. In what state did you find your place the next morning? A. It was not broken - the wash-house door was only on the latch - they had got the articles over the wall.

JOHN WILLIS
. I am a watchman. On the morning of the 25th of July, the prisoner came on my beat with this bundle under his coat-skirts - he passed me nine or ten yards - I then seized him, and took him to the watch-house - these are the articles I took from him - he said they belonged to his mother.(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY. Aged 17. Of stealing only . -
Transported for Seven Years .

1727.
JOSHUA HILL
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Bellamy
(
Susannah Hollinshead
and others being therein) and stealing 2 sheets, value 6s.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s. and 1 piece of tick, value 2s., his property .

SARAH BELLAMY
. I am the wife of John Bellamy; we live in Gibralter-walk, Bethnal-green
. On Sunday, the 6th of August, at three o'clock, I went to the hospital to my husband, who had a broken leg - I left the prisoner, who is my lodger, in the yard; I left Susannah Hollinshead and some other persons in the house; there was no one in my apartments, which are the two lower rooms - the prisoner took his meals in our kitchen - the front window was fastened by two falling drops - and when I went out I fastened the door of my apartment - I returned about nine o'clock in the evening, and found the prisoner on the stairs, very much in liquor; he said he had lost the key of his door, and could not get into his room - I put him to a bed, in another room, where he slept all night - he went out the next morning - I received information, and went in search of him, and found him at a public-house, at the corner, pretty much in liquor - I asked where my two shillings were, which he had taken out of the drawer in my room - he said "Here it is, take it and bed d - d;" I had missed the two shillings from a screw-box in the drawer, and the rest of the property - we usually fasten my backwindow with a gimblet.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am headborough. I went with Bellamy to her house, on the 7th of August; I found the prisoner there drunk - I took him to the watch-house - I said I must search him - and he gave me two duplicates of a sheet and a piece of cotton.

GEORGE JOHN BOLTON
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a sheet and a remnant, pawned by the prisoner, early in the morning of the 7th of July; I gave the duplicates the witness has just produced.

COURT to Mrs. BELLAMY. Q. Is this your sheet? A. Yes; it was safe during the absence of my husband; but I cannot say it was safe on the 6th of August - I had seen the money locked into the drawer that day - the drawer, where the sheet was, was not locked - he had lived with us fourteen or fifteen years - he had access to all our property - we had a good opinion of him.
GUILTY. Aged 77. Of stealing only .

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1728.
SUSAN MELSOM
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Gibbons
, about eleven o'clock in the morning of the 11th of July (
William Gibbons
and
Robert Gibbons
being therein), and stealing 1 apron, value 6d., and 1 shirt, value 4d., his property .

ANN GIBBONS
. I am the wife of John Gibbons - we live in Type-court, St. Luke's
. On the 11th of July I left the house at five o'clock in the morning, and left William and Robert Gibbons, my two children, in bed and asleep; the house is let out in tenements; I have only the lower part. I went to Spitalfields-market - I left the room door on the latch; my husband had gone out some time before; I returned at six o'clock, and was told I had been robbed; I went to the watch-house, and saw my apron and a shirt, which I had seen safe at five o'clock - the shirt was on the bed, and I think the apron was over the head of the bed; the prisoner was a stranger.

ELIZABETH PEARES
. I am the wife of Thomas Peares - we lodge in this house. On the morning of the 11th of July I was coming up from the cellar, and heard the room door shut; I said, "Is that Mrs. Gibbons," but no person answered; I went out at the street door, and saw the prisoner, who had a basket, with an apron or something in it I went and told her she did not belong to that place - she said she did; I brought her back, and said to her, "These things are not your's, for I saw the woman tying up onions in this apron, and this is the shirt the little sailor boy wore"- she then threw them down.

WILLIAM RICE
. I am a watchman. I took the prisoner; she said she was drunk, but she was not - she gave no account of the property.

GEORGE GARROD
. I am a watchman. I assisted in taking the prisoner - what Rice has said is true.

JOHN BROWN
. I am watch-house-keeper. I searched the prisoner, and found 3d. in her pocket.
GUILTY. Aged 22. Of stealing only .

Recommended to Mercy -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1729.
GEORGE SMITH
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Carter
, about six o'clock in the forenoon of the 14th of July (no person being therein), and stealing 1 gun, value 12s., and 1 gown, value 7s., his property .

HENRY CARTER. I live in Maiden-lane, Islington
. - On the 14th of July I had my gun and this gown safe when I went out, at half-past four o'clock in the morning - my wife came and told me they were gone; I came and missed them; I saw them four days afterward, at Bow-street - I had left my wife in the house, and my child in bed.

DOROTHY CARTER
. I am the prosecutor's wife. On the morning of the 14th of July I came down stairs and saw my window open, and missed the gown; I applied to my husband to know if he had opened the window; my child and I had been in bed till I came down.

RICHARD DAKIN
. I am an officer, and live in Grenville-street. Somer's-town. On the morning of the 14th of July I saw five persons together, about twenty minutes before six o'clock, perhaps about one mile and a quarter from the prosecutor's house; two on them attacked me with the butt-end of this gun; I searched the prisoner, who was one of them - the others got away; I found this gown in his hat, and this gun was thrown at my feet.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I was going to bathe - I met four young men in Maiden-lane - one of them had some birds; they said it was too cold to go into the water, and they asked me to go and catch birds; we went on to Camden-town, and one of them asked me to put the gown in my hat, and said it belonged to his sister; I did so, and when we got on further, the officer took me - the gun was thrown down.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY. Aged 19. Of stealing only . -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1730.
ISAAC WILLIS
was indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Robert Smith
, about three o'clock in the morning of the 18th of August , (no person being therein) and stealing 5 handkerchiefs, value 5s.; 1 coat, value 20s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 18s.; 1 cloak, value 15s.; 2 table clothes, value 3s.; 2 shifs, value 5s., and 1 sheet, value 1s., his property .

JANE SMITH
. I am the wife of Robert Smith, and live in the parish of St. Dunstan, Stepney
. On the 18th of August I came home and found two men in my house; when they heard me open the door, they came down stairs and I struggled with them both, but they got from me - I am certain the prisoner was one - he had a crow-bar; nothing had been taken from the house; as they came across the parlour, these handkerchiefs were thrown on the floor; they had been removed from where they were before; I shut the door too, but they got from me one at a time, and got out; I gave an alarm.

WILLIAM WELCH
. I live next door to the witness. On the 18th of August I heard the alarm, and saw two men running from her house; I pursued, and took the prisoner - the other got away.

WILLIAM DICKINSON
. I am an officer. About four o'clock on the 18th of August, I was at the corner of Heath-street, and heard a noise - I saw the prisoner running, and Welch following him - we took him; I found this crow-bar in his right-hand pocket; I had passed the house just before, and heard a noise, but I thought it was a family affair; I asked how he came to break into any person's house; he said he was sorry for it - that he was in distress; there was no marks of violence whatever on the door.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going across Stepney, and as I ran by the prosecutrix's house, she came and cried, Stop thief! I had not been in the house.

GUILTY. Aged 36. Of Stealing only -
Transported for Seven Years .

1731.
PHOEBE ALLEN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of July , 1 cap, value 4d.; 1 collar, value 2s.; 1 veil, value 18d.; 1 gown, value 15s., and two 10l. Bank notes, the property of
Susannah Hollis
, her mistress, in her dwelling-house .

SUSANNAH HOLLIS. I am a widow , and keep a coffee-shop and eating-house , in Crown-court, Westminster
, in the parish of St. James'. The prisoner was in my employ three weeks and five days; she left me on the 2d of July, without giving me notice; she asked me for 5s. on the Saturday night, and had 9s. before; it was about eight o'clock in the morning when she went, and at five that afternoon I missed my property from the second-floor; her bed-room was on the first-floor; I missed a silk gown, a lace-cap, a lace veil, a tippet, and two bank notes of 10l. each; I have not seen the notes, but the other articles are here.

Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. Is not that room open to any one who comes to the house? A. No; only to two young men who have slept in that room the last two years; they slept there the night before these things were lost - they are gentlemen's servants, and go out at seven o'clock in the morning - they are not here now - one is gone to Portsmouth with a family; the room was not locked, but the drawers were - a great many people come to the house; but they do not go to the second floor, they go to the first floor.

CHARLES SAMUEL SMITH
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a cap and tippet pawned for 6s., and a veil for 1s. 6d., on Monday, the 3d of July, by a woman (in the name of Phoebe Allen) like the prisoner, but I cannot swear to her.

WILLIAM ALDER
. I am a pawnbroker, and live at Lambeth. I have a gown pawned, on the 3d of July, by the prisoner, in the name of Phoebe Allen, No. 10, John-street; I have known her for years.
Cross-examined. Q. Is that address correct? A. No; not where she lived last; I could have directed any person to have found her; I knew her name when she first came to the shop.

DANIEL DORKINS
. I am a Bow-street patrol. I found the prisoner in the Strand on the 11th of July - the prosecutrix pointed her out to me - she, at first, denied the charge, but afterwards admitted it, and told me where she had pawned them.

SUSANNAH HOLLIS re-examined. Q. Did you know what time the two servants went out? A. Yes; at seven o'clock - the drawer was kept locked - I had seen the articles safe at half-past eleven o'clock the night before - I had seen the money safe on the 26th of June, when I took it to pay my rent at the Bank, but the person was not there, and I brought it back - the servants came to breakfast at eight o'clock that morning; they were out all day, and came home at ten o'clock at night; I think it was in August they went into the country - it was the prisoner's duty to to make the bed in that upper room - when I discharged her she went directly out of the house.

Prisoner's Defence. On the Saturday night there was a little boy there, and when I left the prosecutrix she came for me to come back; I said I could not, but I would come the next day; she cannot say she saw the things safe on the night before - she was very much in liquor - I never had the money.
PROSECUTRIX. I never was in liquor in my life.

GUILTY. Aged 43. Of stealing only . -
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1732.
GEORGE HENRY CLEMENT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of July , 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 hat, value 5s.; 1 pair of breeches, value 10s.; 1 waistcoat,5s.; 1 gold pin, value 1s.; 3, handkerchiefs, value 5s.; and 2 towels, value 6d., the goods of
John Evison
, in the dwelling-house of
Thomas Young
.

JOHN EVEION. I lodge at Thomas Young's, in Duke-court, St. Martin's-lane
. I lost this property on Saturday morning, the 22d of July they were locked up in my box at nine o'clock that morning, and I had the key - the coat cost me four guineas a month or two before; I had not worn it six times.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Is your landlord here? A. No - his name is Thomas Young; he never told me so - I only know that is the name he goes by; I will swear he mentioned Thomas Young as his name - I know the prisoner, and frequently drank with him.

JAMES HAYWARD
. I am a boot-closer. On Saturday night, the 22d of July, I called on Mrs. Young - I do not know her husband's Christian name - I went up stairs, by her desire, and found the prisoner in the second floor room, where Evison slept; he was walking from the cupboard, with the hat in one hand, and the bundle in the other - I asked him what brought him there - he said Evison let him in to sleep with him, as it was a wet night - I was rather rash with him, and Mrs. Young desired me not to be so violent - I went with him to the public-house where Evison was - I found Evison was gone - the prisoner then went away with the property.

WILLIAM WILCOX
. I am shopman to Messrs. Gray, pawnbrokers, Fleet-street. The prisoner pawned this suit of clothes with me, on the 24th of July, in the name of Jones, for 25s. - I am certain of his person.
Cross-examined. Q. How long was he in the shop? A. Ten minutes - I think 25s. a fair price to advance.

SAMUEL LACK
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner at a public-house; I found this handkerchief on his neck; this towel in his pocket, and a key which opens the street-door of the house, a piece of wax-candle, four duplicates, a hat, a towel, handkerchief, and gold pin, were brought to him by a young woman while I was there - I have had them ever since; I found a sovereign and 5s. on him.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Six witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY. Aged 22. Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Confined Twelve Months .

1734.
JOSEPH HARDING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 21st of June , 4 shirts, value 2l., and 2 shirt collars, value 2s., the goods of
James Lovell
, in his dwelling-house .

MARY LOVELL
. I am the wife of James Lovell - we live at Islington
- I am a laundress. On the 21st of June I lost four shirts and two collars - they were quite new - they were valued to me to pay 2l. for them - I had brought them in a bundle from town to wash, and put them down in the middle of my room: between nine and ten o'clock I took one parcel out to wash, and when I had washed them, I returned back for this parcel about twelve - they were then gone.

JOHN OAKLY
. I am a brush-maker, and live at Hoxton. I was at Winkworth-place on the 21st of June, and saw the prisoner with two other persons - he had some linen in his apron; I got a constable - he said it was his own linen, and he was going to take it to wash; he struggled, and got away - his hat fell off, and there was one shirt in his hat, and two in his apron - I gave them to the officer; one of the others threw away a sheet.

GEORGE WILMOT
. I am a headborough - the prisoner was given into my custody with these shirts; I asked where he got them - he said they were his own, and he was going to get them washed; as we were going to the watch-house, he said he had found them; I found two collars in his pocket.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that he had found the articles in a brick-field.
One Witness gave him a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1734.
THOMAS LEATHER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , 1 watch, value 50s., the goods of
William Singleton
, in the dwelling-house of
James Blake
.

WILLIAM SINGLETON. I keep a shop , at Mr. James Blakes, in Grafton-street
. On the night of the 3d of August I went into the yard about seven o'clock, and on my return I missed a watch from hook, which I had seen not five minutes before - it cost me between 2l. 10s. and 3l. about a month before; I had made an exchange with a person, who is not here, and it was never valued at that - I have not seen it since.

JAMES BLAKE. On the 3d of August, at ten minutes past seven o'clock, I passed by Singleton's shop door, and saw the prisoner run out, about a yard before me - a boy called Stop thief! - finding a watch was missing, I followed calling Stop thief! - I lost sight of him while he turned the corner - he was secured.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Will you swear he was above a minute in your sight? A. I cannot say.

JOSEPH BULLOCK
. I saw some people running, and crying Stop thief! - I saw the prisoner, and ran up Bateman's-buildings, and into Rose-street; he turned into a watch-maker's shop, where I secured him.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see him searched? A. I searched him, but found nothing - I saw nothing thrown away.

ALFRED SINGLETON
. I serve in my brother's shop. On this evening the prisoner and another person came in, and asked for some tobacco - the prisoner said, "Dick, we shall want two pipes;" he immediately reached over the counter, took the watch, and ran out; Blake asked me what he had taken - I told him - the prisoner was secured afterwards; I had seen him before, walking about the street; the watch has not been found.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you never said that the other person came in first? A. Yes - he did; I was serving him with tobacco when the prisoner came in - he was about a minute in the shop.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1735.
JAMES HAMMOND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of September , 1 coat, value 1l.; 1 waistcoat,value 10s.; 1 hat, value 14s.; 1 handkerchief, value 3s. 6d.; 1 pair of gloves, value 1s., and 1 chain, value 1s., the goods of
Edward Harvey
, in the dwelling-house of
David Skivens
.

EDWARD HARVEY. I am a journeyman-baker , and lodge with Mr. Skivens, at the Three Lords', public-house, in the Minories
. On Sunday, the 3d of September, I put the articles stated in the indictment, into my box, and on the 5th I missed them, and have not found them; Land slept in the same room; I saw the officer try a key to Land's box - it opened.

DANIEL SKIVENS
. I keep this house. Harvey lodged with me for five nights; the prisoner slept at the house at the time the things were missed, and left on the Sunday following; the bed rooms are kept locked, and the keys in the bar.

WILLIAM TITSWELL
. I heard of this robbery, and searched the prisoner; I found some keys upon, also a duplicate of a pair of trousers belonging to Land, and the duplicate of a brooch claimed by Harvey.

CHARLES READ
. I am an officer. I found three keys on the prisoner - one of them unlocks Land's box.
EDWARD HARVEY. This duplicate of a brooch was in my waistcoat pocket.
GUILTY. Aged 42. Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Confined Three Months .

1736.
SAMUEL MEAD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 watch, value 3l., the goods of
William Tennant
, in his dwelling-house .

ELIZABETH TENNANT
. I am the wife of William Tennant, a carpenter - we live at Fulham
- I keep a shop. On the 28th of August, about two o'clock, I left the back room for five minutes, and on returning I saw the prisoner taking the watch, which hung over the mantel-piece; he went out on his tip-toes; I followed, calling Stop thief! he was taken, without my losing sight of him; I saw him take the watch from his pocket, and throw it into a yard, where it was found. It is worth 3l. with the chain and seals, as they are gold.

HARRY OVENS
. I heard an alarm, and ran after the prisoner; I saw him throw the watch into a yard, and picked it up.

WILLIAM COOK
. I secured the prisoner, who was running.

DAVID DAVEY
. I am a constable. Ovens delivered the watch to me.
GUILTY. Aged 19.Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Transported for Seven Years .

1737.
FRANCIS WHITE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 4th of April , 1 pair of pistols, value 6l., the goods of
Durs Egg
, in his dwelling-house .

HENRY ROBERTS
. I am shopman to Durs Egg. One Friday morning in April I missed these pistols from our shop window, in the Haymarket
. I have often seen the prisoner pass the window and look in.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. When were they found? A. Within a month or two.

WILLIAM STILES
. I am a silversmith. The prisoner came to my shop, and I bought two duplicates for pistols of him - in May, I think; the pawnbroker is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

1738.
FRANCIS WHITE
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of July , 1 watch, value 3l. , the goods of
William Perry
.
WILLIAM PERRY. The prisoner lodged in the next room to me. In July I lost a watch from my box, and found it in pawn.

Cross-examined. Q. Does Jacobs, your son-in-law, live in the house? A. Yes; I never knew him deal in duplicates - he is a dyer - I never heard of his offering to bail the prisoner - there were several lodgers in the house.

THOMAS SAMUEL RAVENSCROFT
. I am shopman to Mr. Barker. This watch was pawned on the 10th of July, in the name of Simpson - I do not know who by.

THOMAS GOOK
. I found the duplicate of this watch on the prisoner.
NOT GUILTY .

1739.
WILLIAM SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 coat, value 10s.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; 1 pair of trousers, value 4s., and 1 handkerchief, value 4s., the goods of
William Bowden
; and 1 coat, value 10s.; 2 pairs of trousers, value 18s., and 1 sheet, value 2s., the goods of
John Lloyd
, in the dwelling-house of
Thomas Davis
.

WILLIAM BOWDEN. I am a shoemaker , and lodge in Rose-alley, Eagle-street, Holborn
, at Thomas Davis' house. On the 5th of July I was awoke early in the morning by a man crossing my room - I laid still, and saw it was the prisoner - I saw him go to the box and take two pairs of trousers and a coat of Lloyd's - he took my coat, waistcoat, and trousers from the foot of the bed, and went out - I followed - he dropped them on the stairs - I gave an alarm, and a lamplighter took him.

Cross-examined by Mr. PRENDERGAST. Q. What time was this? A. A few minutes before five o'clock - the front door is usually open - I thought, at first, it was my shopmate, and said "Halloo, you are come early;" I never lost sight of him - my things are worth 20s.
JOHN LLOYD. I sleep in Bowden's room. I was not there that night - I left my things in the box - they are worth 30s.

FRANCIS CLARRIDGE
. I am a watchman of Eagle-street. I heard the alarm, and took the prisoner from the hands of the lamplighter - he said that the man was gone down another street - Bowden was following him - I saw nobody else.

JOHN LLOYD
. I found the property at the foot of the stairs.

Prisoner's Defence. I had been at the fair, and returning home intoxicated, I heard a cry of Stop thief! I ran up and saw a man on the other side of the way - I asked him what was the matter; he said "You did it;" and took me; the watchman can prove he said he had lost sight of the person twice.
FRANCIS CLARRIDGE. He did not say so.
JOHN LLOYD. He did not say so.
GUILTY. Aged 20. Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Transported for Seven Years .

1740.
THOMAS SLARK
,
JOSEPH CANE
, and
DANIEL LYNCH
, were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Benjamin Busby
, on the 27th of June , at St. Mary-le-bone
, (
Edwin Busby
and others therein being), and stealing 12 pairs of stockings, value 3l., the goods of the said Benjamin Busby .

EDWIN BUSBY. I am shopman to Benjamin Busby - he is a hosier and glover , and lives in Oxford-street
, at the corner of John-street. On the 27th of June there were twelve pairs of silk stockings missing, which I had seen safe about half an hour before the officers came, and told me of the robbery; I had placed them near the window. They are worth 3l. I found the window had been cut.

ANGELIOUS BERTRAUN
. I saw the prisoners Slark and Cane in Oxford-street on the 27th of June; they were joined by another, who, I believe, was Lynch; they went up to the prosecutor's shop, and stood there two or three minutes; I then saw Slark run away, as fast as he could - I told Roberts to follow him; Cane came into the middle of the road, and I took him back to the shop, and kept him till Roberts brought back Slark. I saw the window was cut, and something taken out.

THOMAS ROBERTS
. I was with Bertraun, and saw the three prisoners at the prosecutor's window; I followed Slark into Cavendish-square; he there threw down these stockings, and struck me a blow - I then secured him. I had known Lynch before, and had passed them twice.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Was Lynch doing any thing? A. No - I did not see him do any thing.

DANIEL RIERDON
. I took Lynch on the 30th of July, from the information I received from Bertraun.(Property produced and sworn to.)

CANE's Defence (written.) I was returning home through Oxford-street, a person laid hold of me, and asked what I had been doing; I did not know what he meant; he then took me to a haberdasher's shop, and accused me of cutting this window. He went out, and brought in another boy, whom I had never seen in my life time. I solemnly declare I knew nothing, either of the boys, or the robbery, and cutting the window - I was peaceably going along on my father's errand.

SLARK -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 18.

CANE -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 14.

LYNCH -
GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 18.
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1741.
EDWARD ELLIOTT
was indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Bricks
, about seven o'clock in the forenoon of the 14th of September , at St. Pancras
, (the said John Bricks and other persons therein being) and stealing 1 box, value 1s.; 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 seal, value 10s.; 2 coats, value 3l. 10s., and 1 pair of trousers, value 1l., the goods of
John Walker
.
