JOHN BRICKS. I am a journeyman tailor ; I live at No. 14, Steven's-street, Tottenham-court-road
, in the parish of St. Pancras. On the 14th of September, about half-past six o'clock in the morning, I was getting up to go to work; there were other persons in the house; the first thing that attracted my attention was the screaming of women, upon which I opened the parlour door where I slept; I looked up the stairs and saw the prisoner, who was a stranger, coming down; I looked at him with astonishment, and held up my hand to strike at him; I was not near enough to hit him, and he darted on me - I caught him by the collar; he was quite a stranger, and had no business in my house; I had fastened my house up, and I do not know at all how he got in; I found no part of it broken; he was not there when I went to bed; he tried to get away, but I held him fast - John Walker's property had been removed.

JOHN WALKER. I have lodged in Mr. Brick's house five months. On the night of the 13th of September I fastened up the house and went to bed about ten o'clock: on the 14th I got up and went to work, about twenty-five minutes past six o'clock - I am sure I locked my room door; (it is the back-room on the second floor,) and hung the key up above John Brick's room-door where he sleeps; I had left my box in my room - I was fetched from work by Bricks; and when I got home my key was gone from the place where I had left it, and was in my room-door, and my box moved to the middle of the room - I had left the box securely locked, and in it a watch worth 2l. 10s.; a seal, and two coats not finished, worth 3l. 10s.; and a pair of of trousers, worth 1l.; they were my property - when I went out, I fastened the street-door with the latch - I put my shoulder to see if it was fast; I know nothing of the prisoner.

ANN SULLIVAN
. I live in this house, and have the front room, second floor - Mr. Walker lives in the back-room. On the morning of the 14th of September I heard the bolt of his door slip back very softly; I was in bed at the time, but I got up immediately just as I was, and threw open my door - I saw the prisoner with the chest on his back, ready to carry it away - I said nothing but Oh; and then I shut my door - I heard him throw down the box and go down stairs - I opened my door again, and screamed out Thieves! my landlord caught him at the bottom of the stairs; I know it was Mr. Walker's box.

MARIAH NEALE
. I live in this house; about half-past six o'clock I heard a scream at the top of the stairs; I got up and ran from the kitchen up stairs; I saw a stout tall man, not the prisoner, in his shirt sleeves going out; I ran and caught hold of him; he stamped upon my toes, and got away - I followed him into the street, and the door was shut against me; when I got in again I found my landlord scuffling with this prisoner.

WILLIAM SHEPPARD
. I am the street-keeper; the prisoner was brought to the watch-house.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. These are two persons who, I believe, are tailors, whom I have not been long acquainted with; one is a cutter-out, and lives in this house up stairs; he came to me on the 13th, and asked if I could carry a box for him? I said, I did not mind, and he sent for some liquor to my house - I did not go with him for five or six hours; when we got to the door of that house, he said,"Oh! I forgot myself, it does not matter to-night; if you come to-morrow morning it will do" - his brother-in-law Andrew, came the next morning; I went with him to the house, and he was standing at the door in his stockings; I went up stairs with him to bring the box away; he lifted up the box and put it on the bed, and said to me,"Do you think you can carry it?" I found it was too heavy,and said, "I don't think I can;" he went down stairs, and I missed him all at once; and the lady put her head out of the next room, and said, Thieves! I said directly,"I see how it is; I am trepauned;" when I got to the bottom of the stairs, this man put himself in a position to knock me down - I said, "I have done nothing wrong, the man has gone out at the door."
JOHN BRICKS re-examined. Q. Was he running down stairs? A. Yes; as fast as he could, ready to make his escape.

ANN SULLIVAN. The moment I heard the bolt of the door turn I got up; so that there was no time for another person to go down; there was another person up stairs in the house in bed; we called him, and he came and assisted in taking the prisoner; his name is James Gainer.

Prisoner. That person has run away since. Witness, No; he has left to go into a good situation; he did all he could to apprehend the prisoner; it was my screams that brought him out of bed; there was no conversation between them whatever.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY -
DEATH . Aged 32.

1742.
WILLIAM JAMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of September , at St. George, Hanover-square
, 58 yards of bombazeen, value 10l., the goods of
Joseph Cork
, in his dwelling-house .

THOMAS TAYLOR. I am a silk-mercer in the employ of Mr. Joseph Cork, who lives in New Bond-street
, in the parish of St. George, Hanover-square - it is his dwelling-house - he and his family sleep there. On the 11th of September, about half-past eight o'clock in the morning, I was in the shop - I saw the prisoner enter and take three pieces of bombazeen from a shelf behind the counter, about eight yards within the door - he went round the counter - there was only myself in the shop, and I was in the second division; the shop is divided into three divisions; the prisoner could not see me, but I could see him very well - he said nothing, nor made any observation, when he took it down - I followed him fifteen or twenty yards from the shop, when I seized him, and brought him back; he said he was employed by a person who gave him a shilling to take it to the bottom of Old Bond-street; I sent for an officer, who took it from him, and here it is; there are fifty-eight yards - the lowest value is 10l., it cost my employer that money.

WILLIAM WESTCOATT
. I am the officer. I took him in charge - he had only two keys and 1d. in his pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. He said, at Marlborough-street, there were fifty yards, and he valued them at 14l.; I heard him say he would not take the trouble to measure it.
THOMAS TAYLOR. I have measured it since, and find fifty-eight yards of it.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY . -
DEATH . Aged 17.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury, on account of his former good character.

1743.
JOHN PLEYDELL
was indicted for
feloniously assaulting
John Sears
, in a certain field, near the King's-highway, on the 12th of September , at St. Matthew, Bethnal-green
, putting him in fear and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 sixpence and 3 penny-pieces, his property .

JOHN SEARS. I am fourteen years of age; I know the necessity of speaking the truth - I live with my father, who is in the wine and beer trade, in Crooked-lane, in the City. On the 12th of September I was in Hare-street-fields, Bethnal Green
, between three and four o'clock; I had just parted with a school-fellow going to school, but he is not here - I was then going home - the prisoner, who was a stranger, came up - he did not speak to me, nor I to him, but he tripped me up - I had a sixpence and three penny-pieces in my hand, which my school-fellow had just given me, which he owed me at school, where we used to go partners - I do not know that the prisoner saw him give it me, but the prisoner forced it out of my hand - I kept my hand as close as I could, but he got it out and skulked away - he got it out of my hand while I was on the ground - there were some boys in the field, who seemed to have been playing with him - I got up and went to some boys, whom I knew, to get them to assist me, but they were afraid; because the boys, who were with the prisoner, began to throw stones - the prisoner then went and sat down in the field - the others came and took my hoop from me, which my uncle had just given me - McWilliams came up on hearing the noise - I told him what had happened - he took the prisoner, who attempted to run away; I do not know whether he found any thing on his person; I have not got my money since - I was alarmed, which made me go to the other boys for assistance.

JOHN McWILLIAMS
. I am an officer of Bow-street. I heard some persons discoursing outside my door, and I went out - I heard a boy in the field had robbed this lad of 9d. - I took my staff, and went to the field, and he pointed to the prisoner - there were eight or ten boys round the prisoner, who ran off in different ways, and the prisoner in another - I followed and came up with him - I secured him - he asked what it was for - I said "I will tell you that by and by;" he said he would not go; but I made him - I took him to a public-house, where I searched him, but found nothing on him - the house was surrounded with a desperate set, and I was forced to send to Worship-street to get further assistance, before I could get him away.
Prisoner. I was going into my own house, and he took me. Witness. No; he was going in quite a different direction.

COURT. Q. The little boy pointed him out immediately? A. Yes; this was a little past three o'clock on Tuesday, the 12th of September, it was in Hare-street-fields; but to distinguish that field from the others, it is called the High-field.
The prisoner called -

JOHN MINNOT
. I am a weaver, and live at No. 15, Mapes-street, Bethnal-green. I had been for my work, and was coming home between two and three o'clock - I passed this lad and two more, who were sitting down close by where I live in Mapes-street - when I got to my own door, having nothing to do, I took my young one in my arms, and saw the prosecutor playing with his hoop; I neither saw the prisoner advance towards him, nor did I hear any alarm till the officer came - I then asked the prosecutor if he was sure it was him; and he said, "Yes,it was the boy with the red night cap;" there might be two or three who had red night caps on.

Q. And so you kept watching him, that he might not do any thing? A. I did not see him do any thing; he was in the field, as he frequently is - a neighbour of mine flies pigeons, and he frequently comes and looks at them; I am quite sure it was between two and three o'clock - it was past three when the officer came.

JOHN McWILLIAM
. There was no other boy there with a red night cap; I wish to ask this witness, if he was not sitting in the public-house, with a newspaper and a pint of beer, when I took the prisoner? Witness. No; I went into the house after he was there; I will swear that I was not in the house till after the prisoner was there.

HENRY FITT
. I am a swivel-weaver. The prisoner was not near the boy at the time - he was at a good distance; I was playing in the field, and saw the prisoner with a red night-cap on, but no one else; the prosecutor was not long on the ground - he had a hoop which he was rolling about the field - no one took it from him; I did not see him on the ground at all - nor see any body throw stones, nor see the officer - but I saw some man go across the field and take the prisoner; I have known the prisoner before, and played with him often, but not on that day - I was playing with some other little boys - I was not throwing stones.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.

GUILTY . -
DEATH . Aged 15.

1744.
MARGARET SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of August , 10 yards of cambric, value 5l., the goods of
John Limbert
and others, his partners, in their dwelling-house .

THOMAS MARKS
. I live in Manchester-street. On the 15th of August, about four o'clock, I was in Mr. Limbert's shop, in Oxford-street
; the prisoner came in and asked to see some French cambric, which was shewn her - the shopman was called away and, in the meantime, I saw her take two parcels of cambric and put them up her clothes; she was going out - I said "Have you been served?" she said Yes - in half a minute a piece fell from her clothes on the floor; she wished to go, but I took her into the parlour, and told her to give up the other piece, and she dropped it.

WILLIAM BALLARD
. I am an officer. I was fetched, and took the prisoner with the property - she said she had not taken it; but afterwards said she was tipsy, and did not know what she had done, and begged for mercy.

HENRY CHANEY
. I am shopman to John Limbert and others - it is his dwelling-house only - this is their property and worth 5l.

JOSEPH PAGE
. I am cashier at Mr. Limbert's, and had been serving the prisoner.
GUILTY. Aged 63. Of stealing, but not in the dwelling-house .
Confined Six Months .

1745.
ELEANOR FINN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of June , 1 watch, value 3l.; 1 key, value 2s.; 1 spoon, value 8s., and 4 cruets, value 20s., the goods of
John Smith
, in his dwelling-house .

JOHN SMITH. I am an ironmonger , and live in High-street, Bloomsbury
; the prisoner was in my service, but had left me. On the 18th of June I went to church, leaving Harris, my servant, in the house - this watch was on the kitchen-dresser as usual; on returning it was gone; it was worth 3l. - I have not found it.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. What kind of watch was it? A. Silver; I had had it sixteen years; she was taken in about a week.

ANN HARRIS
. I am Mr. Smith's servant. I was left at home alone; the prisoner came to the door; she asked for Mr. or Mrs. Smith; she was a stranger to me; I said they were not at home; she said "I know that, I am Mrs. Smith's sister; I will walk in and wait in the dining-room;" she went in, and I went into the kitchen; in about ten minutes she rang the bell; I went up; she asked me to go to Mr. Smith's, in Brownlow-street, and get her half a pint of home-brewed ale; I did not know it - but she directed me and I went; it was church-time, they would not serve me; I returned in ten minutes, and found the door a-jar, and the prisoner gone; in about five minutes I missed the watch, which was in the kitchen when I went out.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you never seen her before? A. No; she was talking to me a few minutes; she wore a black veil, but drew it aside to speak; I noticed her dress and features; I was five minutes in the room with her; she wore a white bonnet, black spencer, and white gown.

MARIA SMITH
. I live opposite the prosecutor. On this morning I saw the prisoner pass our window twice, and look over at Smith's house; I then saw her cross to Smith's door and pull her veil down; she went in; I afterwards saw the servant come out with a jug, and shut the door; before she returned I saw the prisoner come out and walk fast up the street; she had a white bonnet, black spencer, and white gown.

SAMUEL FURZMAN
. I am an officer. I found the prisoner a week after the robbery, in Nottingham-court, playing at cards with her husband; I said "You know what I want, and if you are honest you will let Mr. Smith examine your boxes;" she said "Indeed, I shall not, unless you have a warrant;" I took her, and the servant identified her; I found in her box a white bonnet, black veil and white gown.
Prisoner's Defence, The young woman has sworn false.
GUILTY. Aged 30. Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Transported for Seven Years .

1745.
GEORGE KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 12 pieces of printed cotton, containing 70 yards, value 2l. 2s., the goods of
John King
, in his dwelling-house .

JOHN SURRIDGE
. I am a painter, and live in Chapel-row, Clerkenwell. I heard a cry of Stop thief! on the 14th of September, about one hundred yards from King's house; the prisoner passed me, with a bundle under his arm; I pursued, and saw him throw it away - I took it up and Abbinett stopped him, without my losing sight of him.

RICHARD ABBINETT
. I am a labourer. I heard the alarm - the prisoner was the first person running, and I took him.

JOHN SHEPPARD
. I am shopman to Mr. King, a linendraper , of Exmouth-street
. About half-past eight o'clock in the evening I saw a man come into the shop, and take these prints, which hung about two yards from the door; he ran out - I followed, giving the alarm, and he was taken - this is the property - it is worth about two guineas.

JOHN JORDAN
. I am an officer, and received him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I heard an alarm, ran down Chapel-row, and was taken.
GUILTY. Aged 25. Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Transported for Seven Years .

1747.
WILLIAM HENRY THOMPSON
was indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
John McDonald
, on the night of the 17th of March , and stealing 1 hat, value 1s. 6d.; 1 pair of stockings, value 6d., and 1 pair of shoes, value 6d., his property; 1 pelisse, value 18s.; 1 gown, value 5s.; 1 petticoat, value 1s. 6d., and 2 half-crowns, the property of
Eleanor McDonald
, spinster
.

JOHN McDONALD. I live in Berners-street, Commercial-road
. On the 17th of March I went to bed about ten o'clock at night - I awoke at four in the morning, and missed a pair of stockings and shoes from my bed side; the stockings and shoes were left outside the room door - my hat was gone.

ELEANOR McDONALD. I live with my father. My sister was the last person up. I came down in the morning, and found a drawer open in the parlour; I missed a pelisse, a gown, my father's hat, his shoes, and stockings were outside the door, on the leads. I found the prisoner in custody in July.

MARY BADHAM
. I lodged at McDonald's, in the first floor front room. On the 17th of March, about half-past nine o'clock in the evening, I saw the door on the leads fastened; it was open in the morning about eight - somebody had got in there.

JOHN SAVAGE
. I am shopman to Mr. Aaron, a pawn-of Houndsditch. I have a pelisse, pawned on the 18th of March, in the name of Smith; I believe the prisoner to be the person - a person called that day, and gave me information, which impressed the recollection of his features on me.

JOSEPH HARRIS
. I saw the prisoner on the 18th of March, at the Star public-house, offering this pelisse for sale to several persons - I met him that afternoon, and bought the duplicate of him; I went for it on Monday - the pawnbroker said I was not the person, and sent for an officer.

JAMES LEE
. On the 18th of March McDonald informed me of this robbery. I found the pelisse at Aaron's, and desired him to stop whoever came for it; I was fetched on the Monday, and took Harris, who described the prisoner to me - Savage did the same. I was looking for him nearly three weeks, and found him in Horsemonger-lane.(Pelisse produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I met a young man in Rosemary-lane, and bought the pelisse of him, for 7s. - I took it to the Star to sell for 10s., but could not, and pawned it.
GUILTY. Aged 2 Of stealing to the value of 39s. only .
Transported for Seven Years .

1748.
CHARLES FLASHMAN
and
JOSEPH CHARLES HALL
were indicted for
feloniously assaulting
Joseph Shaw
, on the King's highway, on the 31st of August, putting him in fear, and taking from his person, and against his will, 1 seal, value 10s.; 2 keys, value 8s., and 1 ring, value 2s., his property .

JOSEPH SHAW. I am servant to
Ashley Cooper
, Esq. On the 31st of August I was out of place, and about eight o'clock in the evening I was at the end of St. Martin's-court, in St. Martin's-lane
, going home to Crown-street, Westminster; I looked up to read the name of the court, and Flashman snatched at my watch - the ribbon broke; he got the seals, key, and ring, and ran up the court; I followed, calling Stop thief! (he came right in front of me) I never lost sight of him till the officer took him; a crowd collected: as we were going to the watch-house Hall came up, took hold of my arm, and said, "That is not the man who robbed you - I know where he is gone"- we then went to the watch-house - my property has not been found.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. At the time the man snatched your watch did you hear any thing? A. No. The place was very quiet. I had not seen Hall till he spoke to me.

JOHN GROOM
. I am an officer. I was on duty at the end of St. Martin's-court, looking up New-street, and saw the two prisoners station themselves at the bottom of the court; Flashman stood at the corner, and Hall about a yard from him, so as to let one person pass between them - I heard Hall say "Now;" they drew close together: the prosecutor came up - Flashman snatched at his watch and ran away; I pursued, and took him; Hall came up, and said, "Let that young man go - he is not the person"- I said, "If you know any thing about the robbery come to the watch-house;" I saw Hall go close to Flashman's side - my brother officer came up - I got him to hold Flashman's other arm; we went to the watch-house, and secured him there - then came out, and took Hall; I knew them before.

Cross-examined. Q. They must have been close together? A. Yes - I was not two yards off; the snatch was made within a second of his saying "Now." I was paying more attention to them than Shaw - whether he heard it I do not know; Hall might have escaped if he chose. The watchmen were not on duty.
JOSEPH SHAW. I do not recollect hearing the word"Now."

FLASHMAN -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

HALL -
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Of stealing from the person only.
Transported for Fourteen Years .
NINTH DAY. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 23.
First London Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1749.
WILLIAM ABRAHAMS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 umbrella, value 9s. 6d. , the goods of
William Spriggins
.

WILLIAM SPRIGGINS. I live in Skinner-street, and have an umbrella-shop in Fleet-street
. My son came to me about half-past nine o'clock on the morning of the 14th of August, and told me that an umbrella had been taken.

WILLIAM STAPLETON
. I am a journeyman carpenter. On the 14th of August I was in Fleet-street, and heard the cry of Stop thief! - I saw the prisoner running as fast as he could; I pursued, and took him in Poppin's-court, with the umbrella.

WILLIAM SPRIGGENS
. I am the prosecutor's son. I saw the prisoner come in and take the umbrella off the rail, and run off with - he was brought back by the witness.

DANIEL TURNER
. I am the officer, and took the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I had been two days without food, and the officer, seeing my distressed situation, gave me something to eat.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Recommended to Mercy by the Jury.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1750.
EDWARD ROBINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
James Barlow
, from his person .

JAMES BARLOW. I live in Fore-street. On the 20th of August I was walking with my wife, about half-past eleven o'clock at night - she told me I had lost my handkerchief; I felt, and it was gone; I turned round and seized the prisoner close at my elbow - I did not see the handkerchief.

HARRIET IMMYNS BARLOW
. I was walking with my husband, and saw the prisoner take up his coat-pocket, and draw the handkerchief from it; I saw it in his hand - he threw it on the ground - one of his companions took it up and ran off with it; I told my husband, who turned round and seized him.

Prisoner's Defence. At the corner of Long-lane
the gentleman turned round and seized me - the lady said I had taken the handkerchief.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Whipped and Discharged .

1751.
JAMES JENNINGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , 1 basket value 8s.; and 18 loaves of bread, value 9s. 6d. , the goods of
Josiah Kinsey
.

WILLIAM WITTY
. I am a baker, and live in the Borough. On the 3d of July I was in Holland-street, Blackfriar's-road, and saw the prisoner with a basket of bread on his shoulder - I followed him to the top of Holland-street, and on to Blackfriar's-bridge; the master of the bread came up, and asked me if I had seen a man with a basket of bread - I said, Yes; and we went on to the bridge - he came up to the prisoner first, and took the basket from him - the prisoner struggled to get away - he said he did it for want.

JOHN HARPER
. I am the officer, and took charge of the prisoner on the 3d of July - I took the bread and the basket - here is the basket.

COURT to Mr. WITTY. Q. Did you see the officer receive the same basket that Kinsey took from the prisoner? A. Yes; I lived with Josiah Kinsey's master, and had carried this basket, which I had made for myself - it holds just twenty four loaves; I left four months ago - I know the basket.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Why is not Kinsey here? A. I do not know why; I do not know whether he has any other name.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1752.
JAMES READ
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of August, 1 handkerchief, value 3s., the goods of
John Shedden Scrimgeour
, from his person .

JOHN SHEDDEN SCRimgEOUR. On the 25th of August I felt something at my pocket, I turned round and collared a man, but I cannot say it was the prisoner - the officer came and took him - the officer took up my handkerchief, which was safe an hour before.

HENRY HUGHES
. I am the watchman; I saw the prisoner and two others following the prosecutor about fifteen yards; I saw the prisoner put his hand into the pocket, and then the other two went away - I crossed over, and saw the handkerchief on the ground - I seized the prisoner, and took up the handkerchief.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Were there not a great many people about? A. Yes; there was a dreadful storm at the time - the lightning did not frighten me.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1753.
JAMES BAKER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 28th of August , 1 silver snuff-box, value 11s.; 1 marlin-spike, value 3s., and 1 pepper-castor, value 1s., the goods of
Moses Joseph Cashmore
, his master .

MOSES JOSEPH CASHMORE. I am a jeweller, silversmith, and merchant , and live in Bevis-marks
. The prisoner was in my service upwards of a year and a half - on the 30th of August I missed a coat and pair of trousers, and afterwards a marlin-spike was gone; I had missed the snuff-box six days before, and had sent him to different coffee-houses to inquire if I had not left it there; I told him and the servant girl that it would be prudent for me to go to their houses to see if any thing was there; I pretended to go, but went to Worship-street; I then went home with the officer, and told the prisoner he might sleep in the house that night, and go before the Lord Mayor in the morning, but after two o'clock he got up, and went out, pulling the door after him; I got up, and spoke to the officer, who was on duty at my door.

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. What had the prisoner a week in your service? A. Six shillings, and sometimes breakfast and tea, besides presents from friends, who come to my house - he was very honest - I have entrusted him with thousands.

JAMES HARDEN
. I am an officer. On the morning of the 31st of August the prosecutor desired me to go with him after the prisoner, whom we found in Jamaica-street, Commercial-road, at his sister's house - he was coming out with the marlin-spike in his hand - I found the pepper-castor in his hat, and a duplicate for a silver box - he said he was going to destroy them, and return to his master.

JAMES MOODY
. I am shopman to a pawnbroker. I took in the snuff-box of the prisoner on the 28th of August, in the name of Dorby.(Property produced and sworn to).
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character, whom engaged to take him abroad.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1754.
HANNAH MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of August , 4 silk handkerchiefs, value 12s. ; the goods of
William Palmer
.

WILLIAM WRIGHT
. I am shopman to Mr. Wm. Palmer, hosier , Ludgate-hill
. At three o'clock in the afternoon of the 24th of August, I saw the prisoner lurking about the shop; I watched her for an hour and a half, saw her unpin the handkerchiefs, and take them away; I followed, brought her back, and took them from under her apron, between her and a child, which was in her arms.

JOHN BROWN
. I am an officer. I took her in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 40.
Transported for Seven Years .

1755.
GEORGE KING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of August , 2 reams of paper, value 30s. , the goods of
Thomas Curtis
.

Mr. THOMAS CURTIS. I am a stationer , and live in Budge-row
. On the 10th of August, about nine o'clock in the morning, my clerk called me - he had the prisoner in custody with this paper - he said it was his first offence.

WILLIAM DONALD
. I am in Curtis' employ. I was going into the warehouse, and stopped the prisoner on the threshold of the door with this paper.
The prisoner received a very good character.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Fourteen Days .

1756.
JOSEPH FROST
was indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of August , at St. Sepulchre
, one mare, price 8l. , the property of
David Elliott
.

DAVID ELLIOTT. I live at Lewisham, in Kent
, and am a butcher . On the 10th of August I had a mare, which was turned out on the evening of that day by Wade, my servant - she had been at work all that day - I was in London when she was missed; but I saw her the next day at the Greyhound, in possession of Matthews and Williams the officers.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Who put her up in your field? A. Wade; he is not here - there is no person to tell whether she was fastened in the field, or had strayed through the country.

WILLIAM CUMBER
. I was in the employ of Mr. Elliott. On the 11th of August, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, I was in Smithfield, and saw the prisoner with this mare; he was running her up and down for sale - I knew the mare perfectly well, and asked the prisoner how he got her; he said a man with a rough great coat, and yellow handkerchief, gave her to him to sell for 6l. 6s.

JOSEPH MATTHEWS
. I am the officer to whom Cumber applied - I took the mare from the prisoner.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
. I apprehended the prisoner - he had hold of the halter of the mare - I asked him how he came by it - he said a man had given it him to sell about an hour and a half before.

WILLIAM GABLE
. I am in the employ of Mr. Colgate, of Lewisham - he lives about one mile from Mr. Elliott's house - I know his premises, and I knew his mare. On the 11th of August I saw the prisoner riding the mare towards Brockly; he had no saddle or bridle, and was gallopping.
Cross-examined. Q. What distance is that from London? A. About six miles.

GUILTY . -
DEATH . Aged 19.
Recommended to Mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury, on account of his youth, and believing him to have borne a good character before.

1757.
THOMAS CLARK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 30th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
Henry Munn, the younger
, from his person .

HENRY MUNN, JUN. On the 30th of June, between ten and eleven o'clock in the morning, I was in Fleet-street
, and felt my handkerchief taken from my pocket; I turned on my right, and saw two lads - the prisoner and Ash passed me on the left; I afterwards saw my handkerchief in the officer's possession.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. I saw the prisoner near the Boltin-Tun, and followed him an another to St. Dunstan's church, where they turned round and followed Mr. Munn for some distance - as soon as they passed him I saw a handkerchief in the prisoner's left hand; I ran and tapped Mr. Munn on the shoulder - he said he had lost a handkerchief - I ran and took the prisoner with it, and then took the other, after some resistance.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner put in a written Defence, stating, that he had found the handkerchief on the pavement, and that the prosecutor had stated at Guildhall that he might possibly have dropped it.
Mr. MUNN. I did not say so - I felt it taken from my pocket, turned round, and saw the prisoner pass me, but did not see it in his hand.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1758.
JOHN GATLING
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of August , 20lbs. of veal, value 12s. , the goods of
Isaac Deeley
.

ISAAC DEELEY. I am a butcher , and live at Vauxhall, On the 12th of August I was in Newgate-street
, and lost this veal from my cart.

THOMAS ROBINSON
. I was at Newgate-market, between seven and eight o'clock, and saw the prisoner at Deeley's cart, with the tail-board down - he looked at me, and trembled - he had a cloth in his hand - as I returned I saw him go down Fleet-lane, with a piece of veal hanging out of his basket; Deeley's partner came up to me, but we could not find the prisoner; I knew him before.

WILLIAM KNAPP
. I am porter to Mr. Deeley; I had put this veal into the cart, and fastened the tail-board, and afterwards missed it.

WILLIAM WILLIAMS
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 19th of August.
Prisoner's Defence. I had a salmon in my basket, but no veal.
NOT GUILTY .

1759.
PHILIP HARTLEY
was indicted for
embezzlement .

THOMAS PEARCE
. I am a lamp-manufacturer , and live in Ludgate-street
. The prisoner was my shopman , and collected money - he never paid me 25s. 6d. on account of Mr. Vansalles; on the 10th of August I asked if he had received it - he denied it, but said next morning, that he recollected having received it; he then put 25s. 6d. on the desk, but I would not touch it.
Cross-examined by Mr. ANDREWS. Q. Does he keep a book? A. Yes - I have not got it here.

HENRY SHARP
. I am in the employ of Mr. Vansalles; I do not know the prisoner, but cannot say I paid him any money.
NOT GUILTY .

1760.
PHILIP HARTLEY
was again indicted for the
like offence .

THOMAS PEARCE
. On the morning of the 11th of August , when the prisoner was leaving my counting-house, I found a piece of paper in his hand-writing - I have not brought it; in consequence of that, I went to Stevens and Co., about 2l. 17s. 6d., and had the prisoner apprehended; he had never accounted to me for that sum; his duty was to give it me immediately he came home.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had he been with you? A. Ten months; on the Monday after he was apprehended, Cape, who is in my employ, said he had a sum of Stevens and Wood's to offer me; he is the prisoner's brother-in-law; I have looked into his book; this sum is not entered; he has several small sums to collect - perhaps 2000l. a year.

GEORGE TOBB
. I am clerk to Messrs. Stevens and Co. On the 22d of July I paid 2l. 17s. 6d., and took a receipt from the person - he wrote it in my presence; I gave him two sovereigns and 17s. 6d. - it was about the middle of the day.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you a recollection of the person? A. No.

CHRISTIAN ACOLT
. I am a patrol. On the night of the 11th of August, Mr. Pearce gave the prisoner in charge.
Mr. PEARCE. This receipt is the prisoner's writing. I swear he never paid me the money; I cannot say whether he paid me any money on the 22d of July.

Prisoner's Defence. (Written.) The truth is, that having accidentally omitted to enter this sum, I did not like to acknowledge my inattention, and as Cape was going out to collect, I got him to pay the amount, as if he had received it.

- CAPE . I am in Mr. Pearce's employ. On the evening the prisoner was taken, he gave me 2l. 17s. 6d. to take care of; he afterwards told me he had received it for Stevens - he gave it me after he was in custody; he never told me why he gave it me - I gave it to his sister; I told Mr. Pearce I had some money of Hartley's, and asked what I was to do with it - he had not told me not to give it him - I was in the room, he put it into my hands, and said, "Take care of it."
Mr. PEARCE. I gave the prisoner 30s. a week; I find, by my cash-book that he paid me no money on the 22d; I never made an error in my entries; Cape occasionally collected for me.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Confined One Year .

1761.
GEORGE FULLERTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of July 6lbs. weight of cock-metal, value 3s., and 16ozs. of bell-metal, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
Edmund Pontifex
, and others his partners, his masters .

FRANCIS YEOWELL
. I am in the employ of Pontifex and Co. On the 29th of July I saw some cock-metal separated from the mass, and laid in a place, as I supposed, to be taken away - the prisoner was in their employ; when he was gone to dinner, a constable was sent for - he went after him, and he was taken - this parcel was found on him.

JAMES WOOD
. I am in partnership with Edmund Pontifex and another - we live in Shoe-lane
; we have above a hundred men in our employ, and a great quantity of metal; the prisoner had 1l. a week.

THOMAS GREEN
. I am a constable. On the 29th of July I took the prisoner, just as he left the premises, and found on him this 7lbs of metal concealed in his trousers pockets, his frock-pockets, and about him; he did not account for how he got; he said it was through distress.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1762.
FREDERICK SNELLING
was indicted for
embezzlement .
MR. ANDREWS conducted the prosecution.

ROBERT GRAY
. I am a coach-proprietor at the Boltin-Tun, Fleet-street
. The prisoner was a clerk in my office, and received money from passengers, and from Eastland particularly; he did not account to me on, or after, the 19th of June , for fifty sovereigns received from Eastland.

Cross-examined by ADOLPHUS. Q. He had settled with you for other monies? A. Yes; he was about leaving me - I had given him notice about a fortnight before; he enters in a book all the money he receives; there is none entered to Eastland after the 16th; Eastland is joint proprietor of the coach, and part of the loss would be his.
Cross-examined by Mr. ANDREWS. Q. Was the prisoner your servant exclusively? A. Yes; the payments are made to me, and I divide the profits afterwards.

WILLIAM EASTLAND
. I am one of the proprietor's of the Tunbridge Wells coach. On the 19th of June I paid the prisoner 50l. in sovereigns and half-sovereigns; the proprietors settle at the end of the month.
Cross-examined. Q. You drive and collect the money? A. Yes, and pay to Gray; I told the prisoner to make a memorandum of it, but he has not.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1763.
WILLIAM HITCHCOCK
was indicted for
stealing, on the 1st of July , 6 pairs of leather soles, value 12s., the goods of
John Alger
, his master .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN ALGER. I am a shoemaker , and live in Ludgate-street
. The prisoner was in my employ for five years - Ilet out most of my house; I keep my leather locked in the cellar - there are wooden bars connecting one cellar with another; on the 12th of July I took my family to Vauxhall, and left the prisoner in the house - he left me on Saturday, and was taken on the Wednesday; I never knew of his doing business on his own account till afterwards; he had no business in the cellar,

Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Before he was apprehended, did you not search his lodgings? A. Not till after he had left my employ - he said he had mended a pair of boots on his own account the day before he left; I frequently found the lock of the cellar slipped aside.
Mr. ADOLPHUS. Q. What made him tell you so? A. I missed some boot-trees - he said he had lent them to one White.

BENJAMIN HAYDON
. I am servant to Mr. Alger's lodgers; I was in the cellar between eight and nine o'clock, sitting on a tub as it was warm weather; I went there to cool myself; I could see into Mr. Alger's cellar; I saw the prisoner come down a trap hole, drop on a bench, and take at lest six pairs of soles; he then cut a piece of leather off a large piece - he then threw them up the hole, and got up himself.

Cross-examined. Q. Is the cellar under ground? A. Yes - it was dusk; I mentioned this about three weeks afterwards, when he was leaving, as he was suspected; I quarrelled with him once; I never said he only took two pairs - I said he put two pairs down his trousers at another time.
Mr. ADOLPHUS. Q. Why did you not mention it before? A. I did not like - I had only been there three weeks.

MARY ANN THOMPSON
. I am related to Mr. Alger. I went to Vauxhall, and told the prisoner to be sure and not send the boy out for any thing, and particularly for pump water.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever send the prisoner into the cellar? A. Once - when my brother was out with the key - the prisoner said he could get down the hole, and did so.

SAMUEL CLARK
. When Mr. Alger went to Vauxhall, I was left in the shop - the prisoner, at half-past eight o'clock, sent me out for pump water; I returned in ten minutes, and he was at the cupboard where his coat was kept - he walked to the end of the room in a hurry; Miss Thompson had desired me not to leave the shop - the prisoner then sent me home.

JAMES WHITE
. I am a boot-closer, and live in Water-lane. I got a pair of boots, from Holton, by Alger's desire - I have them here.

WILLIAM HENRY HOLTON
. I am a poulterer, of Leadenhall-market. The prisoner made these boots for me two years ago.

WILLIAM DRINKWATER
. I am an officer. I apprehended the prisoner by Guy's Hospital; I got into his lodgings a few days before he was taken, but found nothing.
Mr. ALGER. I had left a quantity of soles in the collar; I could not tell how many by fifty pairs.
NOT GUILTY .

1764.
CHARLES KNIGHT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of
John Todhunter
, from his person .

JOHN TODHUNTER. On the 5th of July, about half-past ten o'clock in the evening, I was walking with a friend in Fleet-street
, and felt a handkerchief drawn from my pocket- I turned round, and collared the prisoner with it in his hand.

EDWARD KING
. I was with the prosecutor, and saw the prisoner drop the handkerchief.

JOHN CARVILL
. I am an officer. I took him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to)
The prisoner pleaded distress, and received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy. -
Confined Six Months .

1765.
JOHN ROACH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of August , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
John Denny Clunn
, from his person .

JOHN DENNY CLUNN. I was in Duke-street, Smithfield
, on the 14th of August, and was informed I had lost a handkerchief - the prisoner was pointed out; I secured him, but have not found the handkerchief; several persons were about.

WILLIAM GROMET
. I was in Duke-street on the 14th of August, and saw the prisoner and two others; the prisoner took up the tail of Mr. Clunn's coat, took out his handkerchief, and gave it to one who appeared like a sailor; he came through a public-house into Bartholomew-close; I pursued, but could not catch him; I was on the other side of the way.

THOMAS BARKER
. I am an officer. I was passing, and heard a scuffle - I turned, and saw a sailor going through the public-house - he got away; I returned, and took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going to see my mother at the Hospital, and was stopped.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1766.
JOSEPH TAYLOR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of December , 26 yards of linen, value 3l. 7s., the goods of
Richard Fawcett
, his master, in his dwelling-house .

RICHARD FAWCETT. On the 7th of December I missed some linen from my shop in Cheapside
- it was safe three days before.
Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. Was not the prisoner in your service till the 21st of August? A. Yes - he was then apprehended.

EDWARD BEACHAM
. I am a pawnbroker. I have a piece of linen, pawned on the 7th of December; I do not know who by.
Cross-examined. Q. Is it not common for people to buy duplicates? A. Yes.
The officer being absent, through indisposition, the case could not proceed.
NOT GUILTY .

1767.
JAMES DUNN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of June , 2 reams of paper, value 2l. 8s. , the goods of
John Golding
.

JOHN GOLDING. On the 23d of June Mr. Croft, of Wickham, delivered me two reams of paper; I stopped in Fleet-market
, at half-past five o'clock in the morning - itwas then safe in my waggon; I went for some corn, and on returning some other paper had been moved, and this was gone; I have occasionally employed the prisoner.

BENJAMIN TUCKER
. I was in Fleet-market, and saw the prisoner and another man go up to Golding's waggon - they were distrubed, and went up again; the prisoner got in, and put out a parcel, which had a stamp on it; he gave it to the other man, who went down Fleet-market, into Shoe-lane; the prisoner got down, and was stopped in my presence.

EDMUND CROSS
. I belong to the Warminster waggon. I saw the prisoner get out of Golding's waggon; he was secured - I had seen the other man go away with a parcel.

THOMAS GREEN
. I took him in charge.
GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Three Months .

1768.
JACOB WIGMORE
and
HENRY WELCH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of July , 1 piece of silk, containing 7 handkerchiefs, value 30s. , the goods of
Frederick Teanby
.

GEORGE TEANBY
. I am the brother of Frederick Teanby, a draper , of the Minories
. On the 7th of July, about six o'clock in the evening, I saw the prisoners come up to the window, and suspected them; I jumped over the counter, and went out; they ran off, and dropped a piece of handkerchiefs. I secured them, and picked it up.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOSEPH STONE
. I took the prisoners - they denied the charge.

WIGMORE -
GUILTY . Aged 10.

WELCH -
GUILTY . Aged 9.
Whipped and Discharged .

1769.
JOHN WILLIAMS
and
THOMAS JONES
were indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of July , 1 teaspoon, value 1s. , the goods of
John Collender
.

JOHN COLLENDER. I keep a sale-shop . On the 12th of July the prisoners came into my shop, to look at clothes, but bought none; they were there half an hour - this spoon was on the counter, by the window, as we had drank tea there; I missed it immediately they went out; I pursued, and found it on Jones.

JOSEPH STONE
. I took them in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JONES -
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

WILLIAMS -
NOT GUILTY .

1770.
HENRY CARPENTER
was indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 1 saw, value 2s.; 1 smoothing plane, value 1s. 6d.; 1 mallet, value 1s., and 1 basket, value 10d. , the goods of
Hugh Fletcher
.

HUGH FLETCHER. I am a carpenter . On the 9th of September I was at work at Mr. Lee's, in Bread-street
, and left a basket, containing these tools, there, while I was gone to breakfast opposite; I saw the prisoner open the street door; I ran out, and secured him with the property.

JOHN WILLIS
. I received him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 38.
Transported for Seven Years .

1771.
THOMAS GALL
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of June , 1 handkerchief, value 5s. , the goods of
Henry Case
.

HENRY CASE. On the 25th of June, about nine o'clock in the evening, I was in Holborn
- I missed my handkerchief, turned round, and saw the prisoner handing it to another man, who received it; I seized them both - they shook me off, but I secured the prisoner.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Did two gentlemen say the prisoner was not the person? A. No; I do not recollect saying I would send him over the herring pond.

THOMAS GREEN
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going home when he seized me and another - I know nothing of it; a gentleman said I was not the man.
NOT GUILTY .

1772.
ELIZABETH THURLAND
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of August , 1 table-spoon, value 7s.; 1 tea-spoon, value 1s. 6d., and 1 table-cloth, value 2s., the goods of
Lyon Michael
, her master .
LYON MICHAEL. The prisoner was my servant . On the 29th of August we missed this property.

WILLIAM TYE
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 24th 26th, and 28th of August, the prisoner pawned this property with me.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN FORRESTER
. I took the prisoner in charge, and she gave me the duplicates.
Prisoner. I meant to redeem them.
GUILTY . Aged 41.
Confined Three Months .

1773.
RICHARD FERRIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of September , 1 coat, value 2l., and 1 pair of breeches, value 1l. , the goods of
John Cragg
.

MARY CRAGG
. I am the wife of John Cragg - we live in Tilburn-street, Thomas-street
; our bed-room is on the first floor, over the stable. On the 8th of September I saw my room door (which I had locked) open and shut softly, and heard a bustle up the second flight of stairs - I went up, and met the prisoner coming down; I said, "You have been into my room" - he said, "I have." I called for assistance - he was secured, and this coat and breeches, which had been in my drawer, were produced; there was nobody else in the house.

MARY RIVERS
. I lodge at Cragg's. I heard her cry out, ran up, and saw the prisoner; the coat and breeches laid by his side. I found three keys on a ledge on the stairs.

NATHANIEL LAWRENCE
. I took him in charge with the property; the keys fit three locks in the house.(Property produced and sworn to).
Prisoner's Defence. I went to inquire if one Courtney lodged there.
MRS. CRAGG. He did not inquire for anybody - I found the room door unlocked, and the drawer stood open.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

1774.
JOHN COLEMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of July , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a certain person unknown
, from his person .

JOHN WILLIAM DIXON
. I am servant to Mr. Jones, of Budge-row
. On the 27th of July I was in the shop, and saw the prisoner lift up a gentleman's pocket, and take a handkerchief out; he put it into his own pocket - I ran out, and collared him; the gentleman claimed the handkerchief, but said he could not stop to prosecute.

EDWARD JONES
. My apprentice called me; I went out and collared the prisoner; he dropped the handkerchief behind him; the gentleman claimed it, but he could not wait.
Prisoner's Defence. I picked it up.
Two witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.

Confined One Month and
Whipped .

1775.
MARY FOY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August , 2 shawls, 2l. 10s., the goods of
Ann Solomons
, in the dwelling-house of
Nathan Marks
.
ANN SOLOMONS. I live at Carlisle. On the 7th of August I deposited these shawls, among other things, at Mr. Marks, in a reticule, in Mrs. Marks' bed-room - they are not worth much now.

NATHAN MARKS. Solomon is my niece. The prisoner came into my service on the 31st of July, and on the 7th of August she asked leave to fetch her clothes; she never returned - next morning the shawls were missed.

WILLIAM LOCK
. I am a pawnbroker. On the 7th of August the prisoner pawned these shawls.

RICHARD MORRIS
. I am an officer. I apprehended her, and found the duplicate concealed in her shawl.
GUILTY . Aged 27.
Confined Two Months .

1776.
JOHN FITZGERALD
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 1 coat, value 2l., and 1 waistcoat, value 10s. , the goods of
Thomas Halliday
.

THOMAS HALLIDAY. I am a waiter , and lodge in Chequer's-yard
. On the 19th of August, in the morning, I left my coat and waistcoat safe in my box; the prisoner, who slept in the room, was then getting up; I went up after he was gone, and missed them; I followed him down Petticoat-lane, and got assistance; I then said to him"Where are my clothes?" he said "Here they are, I don't want to rob you; I was going to the tailor's to get a suit made like them;" he had them round him, under his coat.

ROBERT BULLERS
. I took the prisoner in charge. After I looked him up, I looked into the cell, hearing a bustle, and saw the clothes there; he had them wrapped round him under his coat.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 31.
Transported for Seven Years .

1777.
WILLIAM MONKS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 16th of September , 3 saws, value 20s.; 5 planes, value 15s.; 7 moulding planes, value 15s.; 1 nest of drawers, value 5s.; 1 pair of compasses, value 1s., and 1 square, value 1s. 6d. , the goods of
John Dyer
.
JOHN DYER. I am a carpenter . On the 10th of September I found the prisoner in my shop with my tool-chest open, and these tools on his person; he said he did not know how he came there.

JOHN BROWN
. I received him in charge; he said he got in at the sky-light.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Confined One Year .

1778.
JOHN CARR
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of July , 179lbs. of lead, value 47s., and 1 fixture (i.e.) 1 copper, value 25s., the goods of
John Thomas Thorpe
, Esq. and others, and fixed to a dwelling-house of theirs .

The house belonging to
Lady Plummer
, and not to Messrs. Thorpe and others, the prisoner was
ACQUITTED .
Second London Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

1779.
GEORGE HOLMES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of September , 1 shilling, the money of
James Ward
, his master .
Mr. PHILLIPS conducted the prosecution.

JAMES WARD. I live in Jewin-street, Cripplegate
, and am a bricklayer ; the prisoner was apprentice d to my brother and servant to me. On the 3d of September I marked a shilling, with a scratch on the edge, and put it into a waistcoat pocket, on the floor of my room; the prisoner slept in the same room; next morning I missed it; he went out; I got up and followed him; he went to a coffee-shop, and returned; I got an officer, who found the marked shilling on him and some keys.

WILLIAM TAYLOR
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner, and found the shilling in his waistcoat-pocket, with a few half-pence.
Mr. WARD. This is the shilling I marked.

Prisoner's Defence (written). I came home on Sunday with a shilling and a sixpence in my pocket, which I put on the drawers, to put into my other pocket in the morning - I was stooping to untie my shoe and picked up this shilling, which I threw on the drawers; and in the morning I took a shilling and a sixpence off the drawers, and thought they were my own.
Mr. WARD. It was impossible that it could have fallen from my pocket; there was no shilling found on the drawers; I put it on the floor carefully; he was in bed before I put it there.
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years . - (See 6th Session, page 498.)

1780.
CATHERINE MURPHY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of June , 1 tea-caddy, value 30s.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d.; 1 sovereign; 16 half-crowns, value 35s.; 12 sixpences, and 960 farthings, the property of
Elizabeth Hyams
, her mistress .

ELIZABETH HYAMS. I live in Stoney-lane, Hounsditch
, and am single - the prisoner was two or three months in my employ, and slept with me. On the 12th of June, between three and four o'clock in the morning, she got up; she had been but two days out of the hospital; I said"What are you up so soon for?" she said the place wasvery dirty, and she would get up and clean it; I fell asleep- and when I arose she was gone; I lost 4l. 1s. in money; there was a quantity of half-crowns, and 1l. in farthings; it was all in my tea-caddy, in my bed-room; I had seen it safe three days before; she saw me put it there - I went and told her sister, who lived opposite; eleven days after a young woman gave me information; I went with the officer and took her; but have found none of my property.

ABRAHAM PINERO ISAACS
. I am an officer. I apprehended her on the 25th of June, and found the duplicate of a handkerchief on her.

THOMAS MILLER
. I am shopman to Mr. Martin, of Tooley-street, a pawnbroker. I have a handkerchief pawned on the 22d of June, in the name of Ann Murphy, and gave the person the duplicate produced.
Mrs. HYAMS. I believe this handkerchief to be mine.
The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that the prosecutrix had been twice divorced, was a common prostitute, and that she had given her the handkerchief in part of her wages.
Mrs. HYAMS. I was divorced about eight months ago; I never gave or sold her the handkerchief; I had worn it on Sunday.
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Seven Years .

1781.
JAMES JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of July , 1 watch, value 12s.; 1 chain, value 2s.; 1 seal, value 2d., and a key, value 1d., the goods of
John Thackara
from his person .

JOHN THACKARA. I have been at a Telegraph station for nineteen years. On the 3d of July I was at the corner of Water-lane, Fleet-street
, about eleven o'clock in the morning; the brass-founder's procession was passing, the crowd carried me off the pavement, almost under the carriage wheels - I did not miss my watch till I was told of it.

JOSEPH MARIMAN
. I am a printer. I was at the end of Salisbury-square - the procession was going by - I saw the prisoner and another man forcing the prosecutor towards the curb-stone; I saw the prisoner with a silver watch in his hand, but did not see him take it; the officer came up, and tried to grasp him and the other man - he pushed them towards the houses - the prisoner was secured on the spot.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. Might there not be a mistake as to who took it, in the crowd? A. I was so near, I am certain he had it.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. I am a City officer. I was on the opposite side, near Shoe-lane, and saw this old gentleman stagger off the curb - I crossed, and saw three men with their hands joined together; I suspected them, and spread out my arms - they went against the windows, and broke the glass, and the watch fell from one of them; the prisoner was taken to the watch-house; the prosecutor claimed the watch which I picked up.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you say it was in the prisoner's hand? A. No.

WILLIAM LANGLEY
. I am a printer, and was walking in the procession. I saw the prosecutor stagger - I saw the officer run over, and fall through the window with the prisoner - I think the prisoner dropped the watch, but I am near sighted, and cannot swear to him - it dropped near his feet; I told the Alderman I saw him drop it, but on consideration, I cannot be positive - four persons were between us; I think he was the man.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was following the procession; there was a great crowd - I was wedged in and could not stir - somebody laid hold of me.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Fourteen Years .

1782.
WILLIAM THOMAS WELLS
was indicted for
stealing on the 9th of September , 1 pair of shears, value 8s., and 200lbs. of nails, value 5l., the goods of
William Woods
and
John Woods
, his masters .

WILLIAM WOODS. I am in partnership with my brother John - we live in New Castle-street, Fleet-market
, and deal in nails
; the prisoner has been four months in our employ. On the 9th of September he left work, and was to return on Monday the 11th, but did not; he had given no notice - he had borrowed 3s. upon the next weeks wages; on Monday I missed these nails and shears from the shop he worked in; I found two bags filled with straw instead of nails; I informed an officer - we found him in Smithfield, and found a duplicate of the shears on him; he said he had pawned them, but would work them out; he said he knew nothing of the nails, but nobody besides him had been in the place.

SAMUEL HAMPSTEAD
. I am shopman to Mr. Nichols, a pawnbroker, of Gray's-in-lane. I have a pair of sheets pawned in the name of Wells, on the 9th of September; I think it was by the prisoner.

WILLIAM WORRALL
. I am an officer. I went with Mr. Wood and the prisoner's father, to an old iron shop on Saffron-hill, kept by Johnson, and found some nails.

RICHARD JOHNSON
. I am a rag and iron merchant, at No. 85, Saffron-hill. The prisoner brought these nails, and asked if I would buy them - my man said he knew him, and I bought them.
Mr. WOOD. I shewed these nails to the prisoner - he said he had sold them.

JOSEPH GURRELL
. The prisoner came to me in July, and asked if I wanted any tin-tacks; he said he served Shepherd, and stocked him - I bought some of him; he said he tinned a good many, and the tin made them overweight; that he kept a few back, and then sold them; I gave him 7d. a pound.
Prisoner's Defence. He gave me 7d. at first, and then only 3d.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported for Seven Years .

1783.
ROBERT BROWN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of June , 1 pair of trousers, value 25s.; 2 waistcoats, value 1l.; 2 pair of shoes, value 16s.; 2 shirts, value 20s., and 1 box, value 10s. , the goods of
Isaac Rowlandson
.
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .

1784.
THOMAS CHALLIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 19th of August , 24 yards of ribbon, value 25s. , the goods of
George Tickell
.

JOSEPH SCOTT
. I am shopman to George Tickell, a linen-draper , of Leadenhall-street
. On the 19th of August, about twelve o'clock, the prisoner came and looked at some ribbons; he was about an hour there, and selected about thirty pieces - I had observed him put one piece into his pocket; he said he was going to Houndsditch, and would call in half an hour; I followed him out, brought him back, and he produced two pieces, and said, "I suppose this is what you want, but it is not Mr. Tickell's;" I said I could swear to it - he was given in charge - he had paid nothing.

JOHN THOMAS GRAY
. I am an officer, and took him; he had no money whatever.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 67.
Strongly recommended to Mercy, believing it was distress that induced him to commit the offence.
Fined 1s. and Discharged .

1785.
THOMAS JOSEPH BACON
and
THOMAS GARROWAY
were indicted for
stealing, on the 11th of July , 1 pair of breeches, value 9s. , the goods of
Edward Adams
and
George Clamp
.

WILLIAM ADAMS
. I live with Edward Adams, my father, who is in partnership with George Clamp; they live in Aldersgate-street
. On the 11th of July these breeches hung about five inches within the door; I heard the cry of Stop thief! I ran to the door, missed some things, crossed over, and found the prisoners in custody, with the breeches, twenty doors off.

CORNELIUS BIRDSEYE
. My father lives in Old-street. I saw the prisoner, Bacon, coming from Adams' shop - I and another person met him; I had seen the prisoners in company about the neighbourhood for a quarter of an hour, and watched them, but did not see the breeches taken.

ROBERT TYRRELL
. I took the prisoners on the 11th of July, in Aldersgate-street, near Adams' shop; we had been watching them; I saw Garroway cross the road - Bacon came to him with something under his coat - I seized him, and took him with the breeches; Birdseys ran and took Garroway.(Property produced and sworn to).
BACON'S Defence. I bought them.

BACON -
GUILTY . Aged 22.

GARROWAY -
GUILTY . Aged 16.
Transported for Seven Years .

1786.
THOMAS BROWN
and
WILLIAM PINK
were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of September , 1 handkerchief, value 1s., the goods of a certain person unknown
, from his person .

ROBERT TYRRELL
. I am a Bow-street patrol. On the 6th of September, about twelve o'clock, I had been watching the prisoners above an hour, in company; I saw them go round several gentlemen, and touch their pockets; when they came to Finch-lane, Pink took a handkerchief from a gentleman's pocket, and ran off - they were close together - I was thirty yards off; I called to the gentleman - he did not hear me; I then followed them, and took them both; Pink twisted from me and ran away, but was stopped; he threw this handkerchief down.
PINK's Defence. I bought the handkerchief.
Several witnesses gave the prisoners good characters.

BROWN -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

PINK -
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Whipped and Discharged .

1787.
THOMAS EDWARDS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 ring, value 20s. , the goods of
John Barfield
.

Mr. JOHN BARFIELD. I am a jeweller , and live in Cheapside
. The prisoner came to my shop on the 7th of September, at a little before eight o'clock in the morning - I was called down - he asked to see some mourning rings; I showed him a tray, and observed that he took up two, and returned but one to the tray - he said we had none to fit him, and was going out; I told him he had stolen a ring; I closed the door, and sent for a constable - he had then had the ring in his possession about five minutes - he was searched - his coat and waistcoat were taken off, and I saw a ring between his fingers, which I supposed to be mine, but it was not; we then ceased searching him - he was taken to the Compter; I swore to the ring before the Magistrate - it was a fac-simile of mine.
Q. Did you miss any ring? A. No.
Cross-examined by Mr. PHILLIPS. Q. And yet you swore to this? A. Yes - I believed it was mine then, but now know it was not; I told the Grand Jury so, and am surprised they have found the bill.
NOT GUILTY .

1788.
THOMAS EDWARDS
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of September , 1 ring, value 20s. , the goods of
Samuel Jones
.

THOMAS JONES
. My brother, Samuel Jones, lives at No. 78, Cheapside
, and is a jeweller . The prisoner came about eight o'clock in the morning of the 7th of September, and looked at several mourning rings - none would fit him: he went away, saying he would call again in the evening if I would get one to fit him - in about half an hour Mr. Barfield sent to me; I went to his shop, and found the prisoner there; I understand the ring found on him is my brother's, but I missed none; I have sold several of this sort.
NOT GUILTY .

1789.
JAMES DRUMMOND
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

EDWARD DAVIS WARREN
. I am shopman to Messrs.
R. and H. Wilson
, woollen-drapers , Bishopsgate-street
. The prisoner came on the morning of the 4th of August - I knew he was servant to Mr. East, of Poplar; he gave me two patterns of cloth, and wanted two yards and a quarter of one, and two yards of the other - he said he came for Mr. East, and that they were for Mr. East, or I should not have let him have them; I delivered him four yards and a quarter of olive cloth, believing his statement.
Cross-examined by Mr. BARRY. Q. Are you sure he said so? A. Yes; he has frequently had pieces on East's account.

WILLIAM EAST
. I live at Poplar, and have dealt with Messrs. Wilson many years. The prisoner was eight years in my service, and was so on the 4th of August; I did not send him for this cloth, nor have I received it - he never fetched goods for me without my order; I have occasionally sent him, as he lived near there - he told me he meant to pay me for the goods, and that he did it in a drunken frolick.

Cross-examined. Q. Were no materials got and applied to your business without your order? A. Yes; I never allowed him to get goods on my account, except a shawl, which his wife had; I gave given him a written order for a parcel on my account - he paid me by instalments.
GUILTY .
Confined Six Weeks .
TENTH DAY. MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 26.
London Jury - before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1790.
JOHN TYLER
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

JANE REES
. I am the daughter of
David Rees
, a milkman , who lives in Ivy-lane
. On the 28th of August , about one o'clock, I was in the back parlour, and saw the prisoner enter the shop, and put an instrument into the key-hole of the till - two more boys were looking in at the window - as soon as he saw me he ran out, and I after him; the officer secured him; he gave the instrument to the other boys; there was money in the till.
GUILTY .
Whipped and Discharged .

1791.
ISAAC ALLEN
was indicted for a
conspiracy .

THOMAS BAINES
. I am a sadler ; and live in North Andley-street. On the 29th of March I was in Leadenhall-street
, looking for employment, between eleven and twelve o'clock in the morning - I heard two persons behind me; one said to the other "I'll see you d-d first, you d-d Jew;" I inadvertently looked round, and saw the prisoner, who had said this to a person who was with him, who is not here - the prisoner then stepped up to me, in the hearing of the other, and assuming the language of a sailor, said he was a sailor just come from sea in distress, and this d-d Jew wanted to buy his watch, but he would rather sell it to me, than that d-d Jew; I told him I did not want it; but he asked me to go and take a glass of grog, and look at it; his companion heard all this; I said I had no objection to that; he then took me down Michael-street, to a wine-vaults, and the Jew went with us, who kept saying that he would give 4l. 10s. for it; and then five guineas; the prisoner repeated as before, that he would not sell it to him at all; we had a pint of beer; the Jew came in while we were drinking it, and the prisoner was showing the watch to me; the Jew then said he would give 5l. 5s. and pulled out a handful of sovereigns and silver, on purpose to make me bid for it; the Jew then whispered in my ear, the sailor would not sell it to him; and said to me"Buy it, buy it, it is capped and jewelled, and runs upon a diamond, and worth nine or ten guineas;" that he could not get it of him; but if I could get it, he would buy it of me, and give me 10s. or 15s. for my bargain; the Jew then left the room; the prisoner asked me what I had got about me, I said I had four sovereigns and two half-crowns; he said "You shall have it;" I gave him the money, and took the watch; I believed the story, or I would not have bought it; the prisoner said "You pay for this pint of porter, Captain;" I said "I am no Captain;" he said "You have been to sea, have you not?" I said I had been one hundred and thirty or one hundred and forty miles across the water; he said "Ah, well;" he then left the house, and I looked for the Jew, as I wanted to get rid of the watch; but he was gone; the prisoner appeared to me like a broken down Captain, or something of that kind; I had been in London but four days; I looked round and saw the prisoner running away. I left the porter, half drank, and followed him down two or three streets into Petticoat-lane, crying Stop thief! but no one stopped him; I ran on and caught him; I said "You villain, you have imposed upon me; you have sold me a thing not worth one quarter the value I gave you for it;" he said "You be d-d;" I said "I shall hold you, unless you give me up my money, and take your watch;" I had scarcely looked round, before four or five people came up with the Jew and struck and kicked me violently; so that I was obliged to let the prisoner go; I saw him get off; I got into Whitechapel, and described him to Forrester, and he knew him.
Cross-examined. Q. Then you thought to get a bargain of this man? A. No; I bought it for the Jew; I did not examine it.

JOHN FORRESTER
. I am an officer. The prosecutor applied to me, and described the prisoner; my son took him; I knew him before.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. I apprehended him in Long-lane on the 3d of July.

WILLIAM DAVIS
. I am a watchmaker. This watch was made for about 25s.; it is a sham diamond; it was never made to go; the only value is the case.
GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

1792.
JOHN LEWIS
was indicted for a
misdemeanor .

EDMUND CLEATON
. I live with my brother,
Edward Cleaton
, a haberdasher , of Southampton-row. On the 12th of August, about seven o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came to our warehouse which is in Cateaton-street
; I was there - he said he came from No. 21, Southampton-row - that Mr. Jones had sent him for a flannel about 2s. a yard, one hundred and fifty yards long; knowing Jones lived with my brother I believed he came from there, though he was a stranger; I delivered it him, believing his statement, or I should not let him have it - it is worth 12l. When he was gone Rowland came in; I told him a man had come from our shop without an order - from what he said I followed him, and took the flannel from him in Lad-lane; he asked me to go to the shop with him, but he was going a contrary way.

EDWARD JONES
. I am servant to Mr. Cleaton, at Southampton-row. The prisoner came about eleven o'clock in the morning of the 12th of August, and asked if Mr. Cleaton was at home - I said No; he asked if he wanted a porter, as he had a brother who wanted a place - he went away. I never sent him to the warehouse.

EVAN RICHARDSON
. I went to the warehouse, and met the prisoner going out. Cleaton's account is correct.

JAMES FORDHAM
. I took him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I heard Mr. Cleaton was in want of a person, and went there; I went to a public-house, and do not know what happened afterwards.
GUILTY .
Transported for Seven Years .

1793.
WILLIAM MARNS
and
GEORGE BIRD
were indicted for a
conspiracy .
The prosecutor did not appear. NOT GUILTY .
